Condyloma acuminata presents as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital area, characteristic of anogenital warts caused by HPV. Recognizing the appearance of these lesions is crucial for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage

questions.text: A child presented to your clinic with complaints of severe respiratory distress, chin swelling, and difficulty in opening mouth. He gives a history of dental infection a week ago. Examination findings given below. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with severe respiratory distress and swelling suggestive of Ludwig's angina, a severe cellulitis of the submandibular space. This condition can rapidly compromise the airway by pushing the anterior respiratory wall posteriorly, leading to obstruction. Given the severity of the respiratory distress, securing the airway is the priority, and tracheostomy is the recommended emergency procedure to ensure an adequate airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early intubation: While securing the airway is critical, intubation can be challenging and potentially hazardous in the presence of significant submandibular swelling.

 

Option B. External Incision and Drainage: This may be necessary after securing the airway but is not the immediate step in severe respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage: Antibiotics are essential, but in the acute setting of airway compromise, they do not provide immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe respiratory distress due to Ludwig's angina, a tracheostomy is the immediate step to secure the airway and prevent obstruction.

questions.text: Which deformity is shown in this image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cubitus valgus

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts an outward deviation of the forearm, which is known as cubitus valgus. In a normal carrying angle, there is a slight outward angulation at the elbow joint, which is more prominent in females. However, in cubitus valgus, the forearm deviates excessively outward, beyond the normal range. This condition is generally associated with ulnar nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cubitus varus: Cubitus varus is the opposite of cubitus valgus, where the forearm deviates inward. This condition is also known as gunstock deformity and is often seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus, where median nerve injury may also be present.

 

Option C. Gunstock deformity: Gunstock deformity is another term for cubitus varus, where the forearm deviates inward, resembling the shape of a gunstock. This is not the deformity shown in the given image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus valgus is an outward deviation of the forearm at the elbow joint, beyond the normal carrying angle, and is generally associated with ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

Explanation:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is mediated by a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of reaction:

 

  • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies.
  • The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation.
  • Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens).
  • Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation.
  • Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation.
  • Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).

 

Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.

 

Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation.
  • Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition. It presents with tender nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation and is commonly associated with lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with hearing loss. On examination, a white pearly mass is seen behind an intact TM as shown below. There is no history of TM perforation or surgery. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital cholesteatoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The presence of a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a young child with no history of tympanic membrane perforation or surgery strongly suggests congenital cholesteatoma. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs due to the presence of residual epithelial cells trapped within the middle ear during embryogenesis, which later proliferate. This condition is typically seen in the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary cholesteatoma: Primary cholesteatoma usually involves a retraction pocket and is associated with a history of eustachian tube dysfunction. It is not typically seen with an intact tympanic membrane without a history of perforation or retraction.

 

Option C. Secondary cholesteatoma: Secondary cholesteatoma arises due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with tympanic membrane perforation or from a previous surgical procedure. It does not present with an intact tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Tubotympanic CSOM: Tubotympanic chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is associated with a central perforation of the tympanic membrane and chronic discharge. It is not consistent with an intact tympanic membrane and a white pearly mass.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in the absence of any history of perforation or surgery. It is typically found in the anterosuperior quadrant of the middle ear.

questions.text: Increased firing of which of the following is responsible for the occurrence of scissoring gait? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Scissoring gait is characterized by the crossing of the legs while walking, which resembles the closing of a pair of scissors. This gait abnormality is primarily due to increased tone and overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs, which are responsible for bringing the legs together.

 

The adductor muscles are innervated by the obturator nerve. Increased firing or hyperactivity of the obturator nerve leads to excessive contraction of the adductor muscles, resulting in the scissoring motion seen in this gait disorder.

 

Treatment options for scissoring gait may include interventions such as obturator nerve cryoneurolysis, where the obturator nerve is intentionally damaged to reduce muscle spasticity and improve gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: This nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the thigh, including the quadriceps muscles, which are involved in knee extension, not adduction.

 

Option B. Superior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, which are involved in hip abduction and stabilization, not adduction.

 

Option C. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle, which is primarily responsible for hip extension and lateral rotation, not adduction.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Scissoring gait is caused by increased firing of the obturator nerve, leading to overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs.

questions.text: A patient presents with a pansystolic murmur and features of carditis. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most common manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF), which often presents with carditis as one of the major manifestations. In ARF, the most common manifestation is arthritis, which is typically a migratory polyarthritis affecting large joints such as the knees, ankles, elbows, and wrists. This arthritis responds well to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chorea: This is also a manifestation of ARF but is less common than arthritis.

 

Option C. Erythema marginatum: This is a characteristic rash seen in ARF but is less common than arthritis.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous nodules: These are also seen in ARF but are much less common than arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute rheumatic fever, arthritis is the most common manifestation, typically presenting as migratory polyarthritis that responds well to NSAIDs.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed some locally produced spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fomepizole

 

The symptoms of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after consuming locally produced spirit suggest methanol poisoning. Methanol is commonly found in illicit liquor and can cause severe toxicity.

 

The treatment for methanol poisoning involves inhibiting the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which is responsible for converting methanol into its toxic metabolites, such as formic acid and formaldehyde.

 

Fomepizole (4-methylpyrazole) is the drug of choice as it is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the formation of these toxic metabolites.

 

Alternative treatment – IV Ethanol (competitive blocker of alcohol dehydrogenase)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil: Used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Option C. Diazepam: Used in the management of alcohol withdrawal and as a sedative but not as an antidote for methanol poisoning.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Used as an antidote for opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fomepizole is the preferred treatment for methanol poisoning, as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the formation of toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a persistent skin rash. Initially, she had an itchy, ring-shaped rash that partially resolved with a topical ointment. However, within a week of discontinuing the treatment, the itching returned and the rash spread. She denies any new products or environmental exposures. Physical examination reveals poorly demarcated, erythematous plaques with slight scaling scattered over her face, as shown in the image below. There are no vesicles, pustules, or signs of systemic illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tinea incognito

 

Explanation:

 

Tinea incognito is a fungal infection that has been altered by the inappropriate use of topical corticosteroids. This condition often presents with atypical features compared to a classic dermatophyte infection. The history of initial improvement with a topical ointment (likely a corticosteroid) followed by a return and worsening of symptoms after discontinuation is characteristic of tinea incognito. The poorly demarcated erythematous plaques with slight scaling observed on physical examination support this diagnosis. The use of corticosteroids suppresses the inflammation and itching temporarily but allows the fungal infection to proliferate more aggressively once the treatment is stopped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: This typically presents with well-demarcated, annular, scaly plaques with central clearing and an active border, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Tinea cruris: Usually affects the groin area and is also characterized by well-demarcated borders and central clearing, which is not consistent with the facial distribution and poorly demarcated lesions observed here.

 

Option D. Tinea capitis: This affects the scalp and hair, presenting with scaly patches, hair loss, and sometimes black dots. The facial distribution and presentation described do not match tinea capitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea incognito should be suspected when a dermatophyte infection worsens after the use of topical steroids, leading to atypical presentation and distribution of the lesions.

questions.text: Aspartate forms which of the following intermediate of TCA cycle:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxaloacetate

 

Aspartate can be converted into oxaloacetate through transamination. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate aminotransferase (AST). Oxaloacetate is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle and is also involved in gluconeogenesis. It can condense with acetyl-CoA to form citrate, thus participating in the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Citrate: Citrate is the first intermediate of the TCA cycle, formed by the condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate. Aspartate does not directly form citrate. Instead, citrate is generated through the actions of citrate synthase at the beginning of the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Alpha-Keto Glutarate: Alpha-ketoglutarate is an intermediate in the TCA cycle, but it is not directly formed from aspartate. It is produced from isocitrate through oxidative decarboxylation. Although aspartate can feed into the production of other TCA cycle intermediates, it does not directly convert into alpha-ketoglutarate.

 

Option D. Glutamate: Glutamate is an amino acid and not an intermediate of the TCA cycle. Although it is involved in amino acid metabolism and can undergo transamination reactions with various compounds, it is not a direct product of aspartate metabolism in the context of the TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspartate an amino acid can be converted to oxaloacetate, an intermediate of the cycle. The conversion of aspartate to oxaloacetate is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate transaminase.

 

 

Therefore, aspartate forms glutamate as an intermediate in the TCA cycle.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 160

questions.text: A 60-year-old presents with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dacryocystorhinostomy

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with chronic dacryocystitis, the treatment of choice is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR). Chronic dacryocystitis involves the inflammation and obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, leading to persistent tearing and infection. In adults, this condition typically requires surgical intervention to create a new drainage pathway.

 

DCR surgery involves creating a passage between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. This bypasses the blocked nasolacrimal duct and allows tears to drain directly into the nose. The procedure effectively resolves the symptoms and prevents recurrent infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lacrimal sac massage: This is typically recommended for congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants, not for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option B. Syringing: This procedure can help to diagnose the site of obstruction and may be used in cases of acute dacryocystitis or in infants, but it is not a definitive treatment for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option D. Probing: This is also more commonly used in infants with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. In adults, especially those with chronic inflammation, probing alone is usually insufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis in adults, involving the creation of a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity to bypass the blocked nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. She also has dysphagia. On examination, dental caries and enlarged cervical lymph nodes are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sjogren syndrome

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are characteristic of Sjogren syndrome:

 

  • Dryness in the mouth and eyes (xerostomia and keratoconjunctivitis sicca): These are hallmark features of Sjogren syndrome, caused by lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • Dysphagia: This can occur due to reduced saliva production, making swallowing difficult.
  • Dental caries: Poor saliva production leads to an increased risk of dental caries because saliva helps protect against tooth decay.
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes: Lymphadenopathy can be associated with Sjogren syndrome due to chronic inflammation.

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disease primarily affecting the exocrine glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed connective tissue disorders: These involve features of several autoimmune diseases (such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis) but do not typically present with the classic symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This can cause dry eyes and mouth but is more commonly associated with lung involvement and other systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): This condition involves vasculitis and can affect the respiratory tract and kidneys, but it does not typically present with the primary symptoms of dry mouth and eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, dysphagia, dental caries, and lymphadenopathy, due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands.

questions.text: Immediately following the delivery, the uterus will correspond to how many weeks of gestational age? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus contracts and shrinks in size, positioning itself just below the umbilicus. This position is equivalent to the uterus at around 20 weeks of gestation.

 

The uterus's rapid involution postpartum helps in controlling bleeding and facilitating the return to its non-pregnant state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus corresponds to the size and position of a 20-week gestation, lying just below the umbilicus.

questions.text: In which condition is pupillary light reaction absent and accommodation reaction present? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurosyphilis

 

Explanation:

 

The condition described is characteristic of the Argyll Robertson pupil, which is associated with neurosyphilis. In this condition, the pupillary light reflex is absent, meaning the pupils do not constrict in response to light. However, the accommodation reflex, which involves pupil constriction when focusing on a near object, is preserved. This phenomenon is often summarized by the -

 

Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).

 

 

 

The underlying mechanism involves damage to the interneurons in the pretectal area of the midbrain, which affects the light reflex pathway while sparing the accommodation pathway.

 

The Near triad, consisting of accommodation, convergence, and miosis, remains intact in neurosyphilis, explaining why accommodation is preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horner’s syndrome: This condition is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to a disruption in the sympathetic pathways. The pupillary light reaction is not typically absent.

 

Option C. Papilledema: This condition involves swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. The pupillary light reaction is usually normal in papilledema.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis: This inflammation of the optic nerve often leads to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil, where the affected eye shows a reduced direct response to light. However, the accommodation reaction is not selectively preserved as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, associated with neurosyphilis, presents with absent pupillary light reaction and preserved accommodation reaction, highlighting a distinctive neuro-ophthalmologic sign of this condition.

questions.text: A middle aged lady presented with difficulty in swallowing food and gritty sensation in the eyes. She is also having autoantibodies in her blood sample. What is the likely diagnosis in her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sjogren syndrome

 

Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of the exocrine glands. The gritty sensation in the eyes and difficulty in swallowing food (which can be due to dry mouth and esophageal involvement) are classic symptoms. The presence of autoantibodies, such as anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB, supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): While SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms and autoantibodies, dry eyes and dry mouth are less specific for SLE compared to Sjogren syndrome.

 

Option B. Systemic sclerosis: This condition involves fibrosis and hardening of the skin and internal organs, and while it can cause difficulty swallowing due to esophageal involvement, it is not primarily associated with dry eyes.

 

Option D. Mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD): MCTD is characterized by features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, and it can include autoantibodies like anti-U1 RNP. However, the specific symptoms of dry eyes and dry mouth are more indicative of Sjogren syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands, often accompanied by specific autoantibodies.

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae binds with which receptors in the intestine? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, a disease characterized by severe watery diarrhea, often referred to as "rice water stools." The pathogenesis of cholera involves the cholera toxin, which plays a critical role in the disease process.

 

Upon ingestion of contaminated food or water, Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin in the intestinal lumen. The cholera toxin (2 subunits – A & B) does not enter the intestinal cells directly; instead, it binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of the intestinal epithelial cells. This binding facilitates the entry of the toxin into the cells.

 

Once inside the cell, the cholera toxin activates the enzyme adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP levels cause the inhibition of sodium absorption and an increase in chloride and water secretion into the intestinal lumen. This results in the characteristic watery diarrhea of cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. GM3: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option D. GM4: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholera toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP and resulting in watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient with prosthetic valve implantation, presented after six months with features of endocarditis. What could be the cause? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. epidermidis

 

Explanation:

 

Endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart, the endocardium, which often involves the heart valves. Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) can be categorized into early-onset and late-onset based on the time of onset after surgery. Early-onset PVE occurs within one year of valve implantation, while late-onset occurs after one year.

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus and is a common cause of early-onset PVE due to its ability to form biofilms on prosthetic materials. Biofilms protect the bacteria from the host immune system and antibiotic treatment, making infections difficult to eradicate.

 

Given that the patient developed endocarditis six months after prosthetic valve implantation, it falls under early-onset PVE. Therefore, the most likely causative organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can cause healthcare-associated infections, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism is a common cause of both native and prosthetic valve endocarditis, particularly in intravenous drug users and hospital-acquired cases. However, for early-onset PVE, Staphylococcus epidermidis is more typical.

 

Option D. S. saprophyticus: This organism is commonly associated with urinary tract infections and is not a typical cause of endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification to diagnose causative organism of Endocarditis -

choices.text: Take mother's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion
Take Husband's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion
Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion
Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

questions.text: Under MTP Act guidelines, to terminate Meningomyelocele fetus at 21 weeks POG (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act guidelines in India, termination of pregnancy is permitted up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

This is divided into two categories: low-risk (up to 20 weeks) and high-risk (20-24 weeks).

 

In the case of a high-risk pregnancy, such as terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation, the opinion of two doctors is required.

 

Additionally, as per the MTP Act, only the mother's consent is necessary for the termination of pregnancy, and no consent is required from the spouse or husband.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take mother's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion - This option is incorrect because terminating a pregnancy between 20-24 weeks requires the opinion of two doctors, not just one.

 

Option B. Take Husband's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion - This option is incorrect because the husband's consent is not required under the MTP Act, and the opinion of two doctors is necessary for a high-risk pregnancy termination.

 

Option D. Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion - While this option correctly states the requirement of two doctors' opinions, it is incorrect because the husband's consent is not needed under the MTP Act.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Act guidelines in India, terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation requires the mother's consent and the opinion of two doctors.

questions.text: As per the new guidelines of MTP Act, Medical termination of pregnancy can be done after 24 weeks for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foetus malformation

 

Explanation:

 

According to the new guidelines of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, as amended in 2021, medical termination of pregnancy is permitted in India up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Beyond 24 weeks, MTP is permissible in cases where there are documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations. In such cases, the opinion of the state medical board is required to proceed with the termination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rape: This option is incorrect because, while rape or sexual assault is one of the indications for MTP up to 24 weeks, it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Option B. Contraceptive failure: This option is incorrect because contraceptive failure is a social indication for MTP up to 24 weeks, but it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Option D. Insanity: This option is incorrect as it is not mentioned as an indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per the new guidelines of the MTP Act in India, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed beyond 24 weeks of gestation only in cases of documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations, and the opinion of the state medical board is required.

choices.text: RL in 5% Dextrose (Ringer's Lactate in 5% Dextrose)

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of malnutrition and dehydration without shock. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ORS


Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the appropriate choice for rehydration in cases of mild to moderate dehydration, especially when there is no shock present. ORS is designed to replace lost fluids and electrolytes due to diarrhea and is the first-line treatment in such scenarios. It is particularly effective and safe for use in children with dehydration due to malnutrition and is typically administered orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NS (Normal Saline): Normal saline is generally used in cases of hypovolemic shock where rapid fluid replacement is necessary. Since the child in this scenario does not have shock, NS is not the first choice.

 

Option C. RL in 5% Dextrose (Ringer's Lactate in 5% Dextrose): This solution is used in cases of severe malnutrition with dehydration and shock. It provides both fluids and nutrients. However, for dehydration without shock, ORS is preferred.

 

Option D. DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline): DNS is typically used for patients requiring both fluid and glucose supplementation. While it has its uses, it is not the first choice in cases of simple dehydration without shock when ORS is adequate.

 

Educational Objective:


For a child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) and dehydration without shock, the fluid of choice is ORS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements. He also complains of facing difficulty with his memory. His wife says he has gotten very emotional recently. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Huntington's chorea

 

This patient presents with the classic triad of symptoms seen in Huntington's disease:

 

  • Hyperkinetic movements (Chorea): Sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements are characteristic of chorea, a key feature of Huntington's disease.
  • Cognitive decline (Dementia): The patient has memory problems, which aligns with the cognitive decline seen in Huntington's disease.
  • Psychiatric manifestations: Emotional lability, as noted by the patient's wife, is common in Huntington's disease and can include depression, irritability, and other mood disturbances.

 

Huntington's disease is an inherited condition characterized by progressive degeneration of nerve cells in the brain, affecting movement, cognition, and behavior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson's disease: This condition typically presents with hypokinetic symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor, which do not match the hyperkinetic movements described in this case.

 

Option C. Friedreich's ataxia: This condition usually presents in younger individuals (typically diagnosed by 15-20 years of age) with symptoms of ataxia and sensory loss. The patient in this case does not exhibit ataxia.

 

Option D. Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's typically presents with progressive memory loss and cognitive decline in older adults (65-70+ years). It does not include hyperkinetic movements, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Huntington's disease is characterized by a triad of hyperkinetic movements (chorea), cognitive decline (dementia), and psychiatric symptoms, fitting the patient's presentation.

questions.text: Identify the hormones A & B giving negative feedback on Hypothalamus – pituitary axis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibin and Testosterone

 

In the diagram, you can see that hormone A is produced by Sertoli cells and hormone B is produced by Leydig cells. In the male reproductive system:

 

Inhibin (A), produced by Sertoli cells within the seminiferous tubules of the testes, specifically inhibits the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland.

 

Testosterone (B), produced by Leydig cells, exerts negative feedback on both the hypothalamus to inhibit the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and on the anterior pituitary to decrease the secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) and FSH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrogen and Progesterone: These are primarily female sex hormones involved in the female reproductive cycle and do not provide negative feedback in the male reproductive axis as represented in the diagram.

 

Option C. Cortisol and Aldosterone: These hormones are involved in the stress response and electrolyte balance, respectively, and are part of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, not the reproductive axis.

 

Option D. Thyroxine and Triiodothyronine: These thyroid hormones exert negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis, not the reproductive axis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin and Testosterone are the hormones produced by Sertoli and Leydig cells, respectively, that provide negative feedback on the hypothalamus-pituitary axis in the male reproductive system.

questions.text: An HIV positive female, who is not on antiretroviral therapy, has delivered a baby. What should be the initial treatment for the newborn? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 6 weeks

 

For a newborn born to an HIV positive mother not on effective antiretroviral therapy, the recommended initial treatment is a combination of Nevirapine and Zidovudine for 6 weeks. This regimen is aimed at reducing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nevirapine for 6 weeks: Nevirapine alone is used in the prophylaxis of neonatal HIV for newborns delivered by females who were taking effective antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 6 months: Extended prophylaxis for 6 months is not typically recommended as the standard initial treatment.

 

Option D. Zidovudine for 6 months: Zidovudine alone for 6 months is not the standard prophylactic regimen for newborns at risk of HIV transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For newborns born to HIV positive mothers not on antiretroviral therapy, the recommended initial treatment is Nevirapine and Zidovudine for 6 weeks to effectively reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the ENT OPD with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. Her mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. She denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrophic Rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge. The patient’s denial of the bad smell indicates anosmia, which is common in atrophic rhinitis. This condition typically leads to the formation of crusts within the nasal cavity, causing obstruction and a foul odor noticed by others but not by the patient due to their reduced sense of smell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa: This condition results from prolonged use of nasal decongestant drops (e.g., oxymetazoline or xylometazoline), leading to rebound nasal congestion, not crust formation or foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option B. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, it presents with polypoid masses in the nasal cavity but not with crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.

 

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, it presents with a hard, woody nose and specific histopathological findings, not just crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge, often accompanied by anosmia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythromycin

 

Erythromycin is not typically used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. It is an antibiotic more commonly used for respiratory infections and certain skin infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole: This is drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option B. Tinidazole: Similar to metronidazole, tinidazole is also effective against bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is another antibiotic that can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin is not typically used for bacterial vaginosis, whereas metronidazole, tinidazole, and clindamycin are effective treatments for this condition due to their efficacy against anaerobic bacteria.

choices.text: Both mean as well as the median will increase
Mean will increase but median will remain same

questions.text: In a class of 25 students, the student with the highest weight (= 39 kg) was wrongly recorded as 93 kg. What will happen to central tendency now? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean will increase but median will remain same

 

In this scenario, the mean will increase because the sum of all weights will increase due to the incorrect recording of 39 kg as 93 kg. This error adds an additional 54 kg to the total sum of weights, thus increasing the mean when this new sum is divided by the total number of students (25).

 

The median, however, remains unaffected because it is the middle value in an ordered list of numbers. Changing the highest value does not impact the middle value in the sorted list.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Mean will decrease: This is incorrect because the mean will increase due to the additional weight recorded.

 

Option B. Median will increase: This is incorrect because the median is the middle value and is not affected by changes in the highest or lowest values unless those changes impact the middle value directly.

 

Option C. Both mean as well as the median will increase: This is incorrect as only the mean increases while the median remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Errors in extreme values (highest or lowest) affect the mean but do not affect the median. In this case, the mean increases while the median remains unchanged.

 

Note - Measures of Central Tendency –

 

1. Mean (Average): Is obtained as sum of all values divided by the no. of values.

Mean = S x/n

2. Median: Middle-most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

Median = ((n + 1)/2)th value in ascending order

3. Mode: Most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution

questions.text: Which of the following subtype of thyroid cancer is having calcitonin positivity? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary cancer

 

Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce the hormone calcitonin. Calcitonin serves as a biomarker for MTC and is used both in diagnosis and monitoring the disease's progression. Elevated levels of calcitonin are indicative of MTC, and immunohistochemical staining for calcitonin in tumor tissue confirms the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary cancer: This is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is associated with good prognosis. It does not produce calcitonin; rather, it is characterized by features like psammoma bodies and nuclear grooves.

 

Option C. Anaplastic cancer: This is a rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer that typically occurs in older adults. It does not produce calcitonin and is known for its poor prognosis.

 

Option D. Follicular cancer: This subtype of thyroid cancer arises from the follicular cells and does not produce calcitonin. It is more likely to spread to distant organs, particularly the bones and lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to ENT OPD with severe dysphagia of recent onset and muffled voice. On examination, a cherry red swollen epiglottis was seen behind the tongue. On X-ray, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The child presents with severe dysphagia, a muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis, which are classic signs of acute epiglottitis. The X-ray shows the characteristic "thumb sign," indicating a swollen epiglottis. Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention. The child will typically sit in the tripod position to help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Also known as croup, this condition typically presents with a barking cough and stridor. The X-ray shows the "steeple sign," which is not seen here.

 

Option C. Acute laryngitis: Acute laryngitis involves inflammation of the vocal cords, leading to hoarseness, but does not typically cause severe dysphagia or a swollen epiglottis.

 

Option D. Syphilis larynx: Syphilis affecting the larynx is rare and presents with different symptoms, such as hoarseness or a sore throat, rather than an acute swollen epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute epiglottitis presents with severe dysphagia, muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis. The "thumb sign" on X-ray is a characteristic finding, and immediate medical intervention is necessary.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with nausea, vomiting, edema and ascites. He had severely deranged liver function tests and a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma was diagnosed. Which of the following is important in the pathogenesis of this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aflatoxin

 

Aflatoxin, produced by the fungus Aspergillus flavus, is a potent hepatotoxin and carcinogen. Chronic exposure to aflatoxin is strongly associated with the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), particularly in regions where food contamination with this toxin is common. Aflatoxin causes mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation and cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benzene: Benzene is primarily associated with hematological malignancies such as leukemia, not hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Chronic arsenic exposure is linked to skin cancer, lung cancer, and bladder cancer, but it is not a primary cause of HCC.

 

Option D. Vinyl chloride: Vinyl chloride exposure is associated with angiosarcoma of the liver, a different type of liver cancer, rather than hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: When is suction and evacuation done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Suction and evacuation, also known as dilation and evacuation (D&E), is a common surgical method for medical termination of pregnancy. This procedure is typically performed up to 12 weeks of gestation (esp. for 9-12 weeks).

 

The process involves:

 

  1. Dilation of the cervix: This can be achieved mechanically using instruments like Hegar's dilators or medically with misoprostol.
  2. Evacuation of uterine contents: This is done using a suction machine, which can be either a manual vacuum aspirator (MVA) or an electric vacuum aspirator (EVA). In some cases, ovum forceps may also be used to assist in the evacuation.

 

Medical methods of termination are usually preferred between 5 to 9 weeks of gestation. After 9 weeks, surgical methods like suction and evacuation become more effective and are the preferred option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 15 weeks: Beyond the recommended period for suction and evacuation; other methods may be considered.

 

Option C. 6 weeks: Medical methods are often preferred at this early stage, though suction and evacuation can be performed.

 

Option D. 18 weeks: Typically, more advanced surgical methods or induction of labor would be considered for termination at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suction and evacuation is best performed up to 12 weeks of gestation, making it the preferred surgical method for early medical termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about triage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow: urgent care needed

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: ambulatory - This is incorrect because red is used for conditions requiring immediate attention, not for ambulatory patients.

 

Option C. Black: minor injuries - This is incorrect because black is used for patients who are moribund or dead, not for minor injuries.

 

Option D. Green: immediate life threatening - This is incorrect because green is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries, not for life-threatening conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yellow in triage signifies that urgent care is needed, such as for open fractures or degloving injuries.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of joint pain and stiffness, primarily in her hands and feet. She mentions that the pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity. On examination, there is noticeable swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints. She also has silvery, scaly plaques on her elbows and knees. Her family history is positive for psoriasis. There is no history of gastrointestinal symptoms or eye inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriatic Arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is characterized by joint pain and stiffness, which is often worse in the morning and improves with activity, indicating the presence of morning stiffness. The involvement of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints is particularly notable in PsA and is a distinguishing feature. The presence of silvery, scaly plaques on the skin, especially on the extensor surfaces like elbows and knees, aligns with the diagnosis of psoriasis, a common comorbidity in PsA. Additionally, a positive family history for psoriasis strongly supports this diagnosis.

 

 

The swelling observed in the DIP joints can be specifically referred to as dactylitis, which is a hallmark of PsA. This form of arthritis is also known as seronegative arthritis, meaning it is negative for rheumatoid factor, distinguishing it from rheumatoid arthritis. PsA is an erosive arthritis that can lead to joint damage if not properly managed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Typically involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints rather than the DIP joints. It is usually seropositive, meaning it often tests positive for rheumatoid factor. The skin lesions described are not characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Gout: Usually presents with acute onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling, often in the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe). It does not typically involve silvery, scaly plaques or have a family history of psoriasis.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints rather than the peripheral joints like the DIP joints. It also does not present with psoriasis or skin plaques as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriatic arthritis often presents with joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the distal interphalangeal joints, along with characteristic silvery, scaly skin plaques and a family history of psoriasis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a fever. He is an intravenous drug user. On examination, a temperature of 38.5°C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. Infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Explanation:

 

Duke's Criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis include both major and minor criteria. In this case, the minor criteria that are satisfied include:

 

  1. Fever > 38°C: The patient has a fever of 38.5°C.
  2. Predisposing heart condition or intravenous drug use: The patient is an intravenous drug user.
  3. Immunologic phenomena: The presence of spots over the fundus suggests Roth spots, which are a form of immunologic phenomenon.

 

The other minor criteria –

 

  1. Vascular phenomena
  2. Blood culture is positive, but not meeting major criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Only fever would be counted.

 

Option B. 2: Fever and IV drug use would be counted.

 

Option D. 4: This would require additional minor criteria that are not mentioned in the question.

 

Additional Information -

 

Duke’s Major criteria for IE –

 

  • Blood culture persistently positive for typical microorganism ( ≥3 blood culture) from different puncture sides and gap between first and last culture should be atleast 1 hour: for diagnosis 2 out of 3 culture should be positive and for the same organism. Except Q fever -Coxiella Brunetti only single culture is enough.
  •  Imaging – Positive Echocardiogram – For IE specifically Transesophageal Echo – will show vegetation near the valves

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this case, three minor Duke's criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis: fever > 38°C, intravenous drug use, and immunologic phenomena (Roth spots).

questions.text: A patient presented with case of diarrhea after eating sea food/ oyster, showing Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahemolyticus

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus causes Food-borne gastroenteritis

 

  • MC presentation
  • Following uncooked sea food (e.g. Oyster and shellfish) intake.
  • Watery diarrhea (MC), dysentery, abdominal cramps.
  • Extraintestinal manifestations → wound infection, otitis and sepsis.

 

 

Bipolar staining – safety pin appearance is seen in 5 bacteria’s –

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Note - Kanagawa phenomenon

 

  • V. parahaemolyticus  produce Beta  hemolysis on special blood agar medium → called the Wagatsuma agar
  • Wagatsuma agar  → High-salt (7%) blood agar (defibrinated human or rabbit blood) medium containing d-mannitol as the carbohydrate source.
  • Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, referred to as the Kanagawa phenomenon (KP).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio cholera: Causes cholera, characterized by severe watery diarrhea but not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option C. E. coli: Can cause gastroenteritis but is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option D. Vibrio vulnificus: Can cause severe infections from seafood consumption but is not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus is the causative organism of gastroenteritis following the consumption of uncooked seafood, identified by the Kanagawa phenomenon. The most common symptoms are watery diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal cramps.

 

Additional Information -

 

Classification based on Salt Requirement

 

1. Nonhalophilic vibrios:

  • Can grow without salt but 1% salt is optimum for their growth.
  • Cannot grow at higher salt concentrations.
  • Examples → V. cholerae and V. mimicus

 

2. Halophilic vibrios: 

  • Cannot grow in the absence of salt.
  • Can tolerate and grow at higher salt concentration of up to 7–10%.  Examples  → V.   parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus and V. vulnificus.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing trouble from the left side of the ear for the last 2 months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry shown below. Interpret the audiogram? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left sided conductive deafness

 

Explanation:

 

The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows results for the left ear, indicated by the blue color. The audiogram demonstrates a significant air-bone gap, which is characteristic of conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, the air conduction thresholds are worse (higher dB levels) than the bone conduction thresholds, but the bone conduction remains within normal limits. This wide air-bone gap confirms the diagnosis of left-sided conductive deafness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural hearing loss would present with both air and bone conduction thresholds being equally impaired, without a significant air-bone gap. This is not the case here.

 

Option C. Right sided conductive deafness: The audiogram is for the left ear (indicated by blue color), not the right ear. Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness: Similarly, this option is incorrect as the audiogram provided is for the left ear, and it shows conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conductive hearing loss is indicated by a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry, with air conduction thresholds being worse than bone conduction thresholds, as seen in this left-sided case

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with back pain for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor, and gamma globulins are elevated. LFT is normal. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following cells are involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasma cells

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with multiple myeloma, a plasma cell neoplasm. Key diagnostic features include:

 

  • Back pain: Common in multiple myeloma due to bone involvement.
  • Pallor: Indicates anemia, a common finding in multiple myeloma.
  • Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis.
  • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.

 

In multiple myeloma, malignant clonal plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow, leading to the production of abnormal monoclonal immunoglobulins, bone destruction, and marrow infiltration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A, B & D: Not primarily involved in multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm characterized by anemia, elevated gamma globulins, and lytic bone lesions, with plasma cells being the key pathological cells involved.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy will have ____ permanent and ____ temporary teeth?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Mixed dentition is a period when both temporary (primary) and permanent teeth are present in the oral cavity. This phase typically occurs between the ages of 6 to 11 years.

 

Key points to remember about mixed dentition:

 

1. Age Range: The mixed dentition period spans from 6 to 11 years.

 

2. Total Number of Teeth: During mixed dentition, the total number of teeth (temporary plus permanent) is consistently 24.

 

3. Calculation of Permanent Teeth: The number of permanent teeth can be calculated using the formula:

 

Permanent Teeth=(Age−5)×4

 

For a 10-year-old child:

 

Permanent Teeth=(10−5)×4=20

 

Hence, the number of permanent teeth is 20.

 

4. Calculation of Temporary Teeth: The number of temporary teeth can be determined by subtracting the number of permanent teeth from the total number of teeth:

 

Temporary Teeth=24−Permanent Teeth

 

Therefore:

 

Temporary Teeth=24−20=4

 

Thus, a 10-year-old boy will have 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the mixed dentition period (6-11 years), a 10-year-old typically has 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth. Use the formula (Age−5)×4  to determine the number of permanent teeth.

 

Number if teeth with age -

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hofmann’s degradation? FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cisatracurium

 

Explanation:

 

Cisatracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is a temperature and pH-dependent process that does not require enzymatic activity for metabolism. This makes it particularly useful for patients with certain types of organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mivacurium: It is a short-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily broken down by plasma cholinesterase and does not significantly undergo Hofmann elimination.

 

Option C. Pancuronium: This is a long-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, and it does not undergo Hofmann elimination.

 

Option D. Vecuronium: Like pancuronium, it is also metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys and does not undergo Hofmann degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisatracurium is unique among the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents for undergoing Hofmann elimination, a process that allows safe use in patients with hepatic and renal insufficiency.

questions.text: A young child had an episode of sore throat followed hematuria after 20 days. Which of the following is the implicated organism for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci

 

The clinical history of a sore throat followed by hematuria after approximately 20 days is indicative of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The causative organism for PSGN is Streptococcus pyogenes, which is a Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. The condition occurs as a result of an immune response to the streptococcal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: Typically associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) and not with post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: More commonly associated with skin infections and endocarditis, not specifically linked to PSGN.

 

Option D. Proteus mirabilis: Commonly causes UTIs and struvite stones but not post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) is the organism implicated in post streptococcal glomerulonephritis following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented lesion on his back. On examination, there is a complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leprosy

 

Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is characterized by hypopigmented or erythematous lesions with a loss of sensation, which is a hallmark feature. The loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion indicates nerve involvement, which is typical of leprosy. Specifically, this question points towards tuberculoid leprosy, which is part of the Ridley-Jopling classification. Tuberculoid leprosy presents with a few well-defined hypopigmented lesions that have significant sensory loss due to nerve damage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option  B. Cutaneous tuberculosis: This condition includes various forms such as lupus vulgaris, scrofuloderma, and tuberculosis verrucosa cutis. These typically present with different skin manifestations like plaques, nodules, or ulcers, not primarily hypopigmented lesions with sensory loss.

 

 

Option  C. Pityriasis alba: This condition commonly affects children and presents as multiple hypopigmented macules, often with fine scaling. There is no associated loss of sensation.

 

 

Option  D. Pityriasis versicolor: A superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species, presenting with hypo- or hyperpigmented patches with fine scaling. The condition does not cause loss of sensation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy should be suspected in patients with hypopigmented or erythematous skin lesions accompanied by a loss of sensation, particularly fine touch and temperature. This sensory loss is due to peripheral nerve involvement, which is a characteristic feature of leprosy.

questions.text: Identify the technique shown in the image: (FMGE JULY 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pringle technique

 

The image shows a surgical technique where the hepato-duodenal ligament is clamped. This procedure is known as the Pringle maneuver or Pringle technique. The Pringle maneuver is used to control intraoperative liver bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein, thereby reducing blood flow to the liver. This maneuver is commonly used in cases of liver trauma or during liver resections to minimize blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cattel’s technique: This is incorrect because Cattel’s technique is used in IVC injury.

 

Option B. Mattox technique: Mattox technique is done in abnormal aortic injury.

 

Option D. Kocherization: This is incorrect because Kocherization refers to the mobilization of the duodenum to expose structures like the pancreas and is used in procedures such as the Whipple procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pringle maneuver involves clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein to control liver bleeding during surgery, by reducing the inflow of blood to the liver.

questions.text: What is the site for needle insertion in emergency thoracocentesis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper border of lower rib

 

In emergency thoracocentesis, the needle is inserted along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid injury to the intercostal vessels and nerve, which are located along the lower border of the upper rib.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lower border of lower rib: This option is incorrect because it still risks injuring intercostal vessels and nerves.

 

Option C. Lower border of upper rib: This option is incorrect because the intercostal vessels and nerve are located here, increasing the risk of injury.

 

Option D. Middle of intercostal space: This option is incorrect because it does not provide a clear anatomical landmark, increasing the risk of accidental injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracocentesis, always insert the needle along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves located at the lower border of the upper rib.

questions.text: What dye is used in staining the anterior capsule of the lens?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trypan blue

 

Trypan blue dye is commonly used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery, specifically to facilitate the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis. This dye helps surgeons to visualize the capsule better, making the procedure safer and more precise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein green: This dye is used to stain corneal epithelial defects and is not used for staining the anterior lens capsule.

 

Option C. Brilliant blue: This dye is used in retinal surgeries to stain the internal limiting membrane (ILM), aiding in ILM peeling during macular hole surgeries. It is not used for lens capsule staining.

 

Option D. Rose Bengal: This dye stains dead or devitalized cells and is used in the diagnosis of conditions like dry eye syndrome. It is not used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trypan blue dye is used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery to aid in the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis.

 

Various Dyes used in Opthalmology -

questions.text: What is the amount of milk given to term baby in first 24 hours after delivery? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60ml/kg


The recommended amount of milk (or fluid) to be given to a term newborn in the first 24 hours after birth is 60 ml per kg of body weight. This guideline ensures that the newborn receives an adequate amount of fluid to meet its nutritional and hydration needs during the initial adaptation period after birth.

 

Educational Objective:


The appropriate amount of milk or fluid to be given to a term baby in the first 24 hours after delivery is 60 ml per kg of body weight.

questions.text: A 25 yr G2P1 presents with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks. On examination, there is hypotension. The abdomen is tender and fetal parts not palpable. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a 25-year-old G2P1 woman presenting with heavy bleeding at 32 weeks of gestation, several key clinical features point towards a diagnosis of abruptio placenta.

 

Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is a condition where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall prematurely, leading to significant bleeding.

 

The critical signs here are:

 

  • Hypotension: This indicates significant blood loss, which can be seen in both placenta previa and placental abruption.
  • Tender abdomen: The tenderness of the abdomen is a hallmark of placental abruption due to the irritation and inflammation caused by the bleeding and the detached placenta.
  • Fetal parts not palpable: This is due to the tense and tender uterus, which is characteristic of placental abruption.

 

Abruptio placenta - Immediate management (delivery) is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

In contrast, placenta previa typically presents with painless bleeding, and the uterus is usually relaxed and non-tender. Placenta previa involves the placenta covering the cervical os, which can lead to painless bleeding without the tenderness seen in placental abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Usually presents with painless bleeding and a relaxed, non-tender uterus.

 

Option C. Show: Refers to the passage of a small amount of blood or mucus plug as labor begins, which does not cause significant bleeding or abdominal tenderness.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: While it can cause significant bleeding and abdominal tenderness, it is less common and typically associated with a history of uterine surgery or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding in Pregnancy after 28 weeks à is due to APH

 

2 MC causes are of APH are – Placenta Previa (Painless bleeding, nontender uterus) and Abruptio placenta (Painful bleeding, tense & tender uterus)

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) History of stroke

 

Explanation:

 

The ABCD2 score is used to assess the risk of developing a subsequent stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

 

The components of the ABCD2 score include:

 

  • A (Age): Age 60 years or older scores 1 point.
  • B (Blood Pressure): Systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher, or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher scores 1 point.
  • C (Clinical Features): Unilateral weakness scores 2 points; speech disturbance without weakness scores 1 point.
  • D (Diabetes): Presence of diabetes scores 1 point.
  • D (Duration of Symptoms): Symptoms lasting 60 minutes or longer score 2 points; symptoms lasting 10-59 minutes score 1 point.

 

History of stroke is not included in the ABCD2 scoring system. Instead, it is a component of other scoring systems, such as the CHADS2 or CHA2DS2-VASc scores, which are used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and to guide anticoagulation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age: Age 60 years or older is a factor in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: The presence of diabetes is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ABCD2 score includes age, blood pressure, clinical features, duration of symptoms, and diabetes. History of stroke is not included in this scoring system but is part of other risk assessment tools like CHADS2 and CHA2DS2-VASc

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hoffman’s degradation? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cis-atracurium

 

Atracurium and Cis-atracurium undergo Hoffman’s degradation, a process independent of renal and hepatic function. These break down at physiological pH and temperature, making them a suitable neuromuscular blocking agents for patients with renal or hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mivacurium: Mivacurium is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase, not through Hoffman's degradation.

 

Option C. Pancuronium: Pancuronium is primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, not by Hoffman's degradation.

 

Option D. Vecuronium: Vecuronium is also metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, and does not undergo Hoffman’s degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cis-atracurium undergoes Hoffman’s degradation, a process independent of renal and hepatic function, making it suitable for use in patients with renal or hepatic impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prepatellar bursa

 

PREPATELLAR BURSA

 

  • Prepatellar bursitis or inflammation of the prepaterllar bursa is called Housemaid’s knee.
  • There is swelling in the front of the knee joint.
  • Prepatellar bursa is a small fluid-filled sac in front of the patella. It provides cushioning and protection.
  • Too much pressure on the bursa produces more fluid to protect the knee. This causes build up of swelling in the knee.
  • Prepatellar bursitis is usually caused by repetitive kneeling (common knee position in housemaids for cleaning hence, named as housemaid’s knee) or sudden blow to the front of the knee due to fall.

 

 

  • It is seen more often in men than women.
  • 80% patients are of age 40-60m years.
  • 1/3rd of prepatellar bursitis are septic and 2/3rd are aseptic.
  • Infectious bursitis emerges more often in children than adults.
  • The bursitis settles down within few weeks by conservative treatment. It rarely require any surgical intervention.
  • Etiology:
    • Repetitive kneeling
    • Sudden force or blow or fall on front of knee
    • Constant friction between skin and patella
    • Coexisting inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or gout
    • Ocassionally, due to a bacterial infection (S.aureus in 80% cases)
  • Clinical features:
    • Swelling in front of the knee
    • Knee pain particularly on moving the knee
    • Difficulty in bending the knee, kneel down, or walk
    • Slight redness, differential warmth, and tenderness over the affected area

 

 

  • If present with infection, pain is associated with fever and chills
     
  • Diagnosis is made through detailed history of onset of symptoms, pattern of pain and effect on lifestyle, and physical examination.
  • It does not require X-ray or MRI or CT scan. They can be done to rule out any fracture or soft tissue injury.
  • If uncertain of infection of bursa, arthrocentesis can be done.
  • Treatment:
    • PRICE regimen in initial 72 hours after the injury or when the first sign of inflammation appears, to reduce pain and swelling
    • NSAIDs, topical medications
    • Stretching exercises
    • If swelling is increased, fluid aspiration with needle is done
    • Cortisone injection into the bursa
    • Antibiotic treatment if cause is an infection
    • Arthroscopic bursectomy or excision of bursa, if all treatment methods fail

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapatellar bursa. Suprapatellar bursitis causes pain and swelling just above the knee joint. It is also called as quadriceps tendon bursitis. It may be caused from repetitive overuse in sports, frequent kneeling, injury, coexisting medical condition, or tightness in the quadriceps muscle.

 

 

Option C. Infrapatellar bursa. Also called as Clergyman’s knee, infrapatellar bursitis causes pain just below the patella. It can be caused from frequent kneeling or crawling; overuse activities like running, jumping, kicking, climbing stairs; injury to the knee; secondary to patellar tendonitis and Osgood Schlatters disease; infection.

 

 

Option D. Pes anserine bursa. Pes anserine bursitis, also called intertendinous bursa, is the inflammation of the bursa of the conjoined insertion of Sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus (Pes anserinus). The pain due to this bursitis occurs on the inside of the knee, mostly during running or climbing up the stairs. There may be a spontaneous anteromedial knee pain on walking up or down the stairs. There is swelling and tenderness around the affected bursa; decreased ROM also.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Housemaid’s knee is caused by the inflammation in the prepatellar bursa. It causes pain in the front of the knee.
  • Inflammation in other bursa of the knee causes pain above, below or anteromedial to the knee.

questions.text: What is the expected MCV in CBC based on the PS image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 100 fL

 

Explanation:

 

The peripheral smear (PS) image shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, which are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, typically due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In megaloblastic anemia, the red blood cells are larger than normal, leading to an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV).

 

Hypersegmented neutrophils are defined as neutrophils with 5 or more lobes, or at least one neutrophil with 6 or more lobes. Macro-ovalocytes are larger-than-normal red blood cells with an oval shape, which are indicative of a megaloblastic process.

 

The expected MCV in such cases is typically more than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. < 80 fL: This would indicate microcytic anemia.

 

Option B. < 60 fL: This would indicate severe microcytic anemia.

 

Option C. 80-100 fL: This is the normal range for MCV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, the MCV is typically greater than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea and a history of frequent abortions. FSH is 7. hCG is < 5. What is the cause of amenorrhea? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine disorder

 

The patient has normal FSH and hCG levels, indicating that the hypothalamus, pituitary, and ovarian functions are intact.

 

Note - FSH levels less than 10 are considered normal, and an hCG level of less than 5 indicates that the patient is not pregnant.

 

Given these normal hormonal profiles, the issue is likely not with the endocrine function but with the uterus itself. One possible uterine disorder that can cause amenorrhea is Asherman syndrome, which involves intrauterine adhesions (synechiae). This condition can follow frequent uterine procedures such as dilation and curettage (D&C) or infections, leading to a history of frequent abortions and subsequent amenorrhea due to scarring within the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary disorder: This would typically result in abnormal levels of FSH and LH due to issues with the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

 

Option B. Ovarian disorder: If the ovaries were not functioning properly, FSH levels would likely be elevated as the body tries to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Option D. Adrenal disorder: These disorders do not typically present with the specific combination of symptoms and normal hormonal profile seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal hormonal profile with amenorrhea and a history of frequent abortions suggests a uterine disorder, such as Asherman syndrome, where intrauterine adhesions disrupt the normal menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A patient experiences bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea following the administration of intravenous irritants during a medical procedure. These symptoms are suggestive of a specific reflex response. Which one of the following reflexes is most likely being represented in this scenario? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bezold-Jarisch reflex

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that can be triggered by certain chemical stimuli or intravenous irritants. It is characterized by a triad of bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea, due to activation of mechanoreceptors or chemoreceptors in the ventricles, leading to increased parasympathetic (vagal) activity and decreased sympathetic tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bainbridge reflex: Incorrect. The Bainbridge reflex involves an increase in heart rate in response to increased venous return. This reflex does not typically cause bradycardia or hypotension.

 

Option C. Cushing’s reflex: Incorrect. Cushing’s reflex is a physiological nervous system response to increased intracranial pressure, and it typically presents with hypertension (not hypotension), bradycardia, and respiratory depression.

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: Incorrect. The Valsalva maneuver involves a voluntary increase in intra-abdominal pressure by exhaling forcefully with a closed glottis. It can affect heart rate and blood pressure but is not a reflex response to intravenous irritants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is characterized by bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea in response to certain chemical stimuli or intravenous irritants due to increased vagal activity and decreased sympathetic tone.

questions.text: A male child presented with easy bruisability leading to detailed investigations which revealed normal PT, prolonged APTT and normal bleeding time. Which of the following cannot be cause of his condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von willebrand disease

 

The combination of normal prothrombin time (PT), prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), and normal bleeding time indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which includes factors VIII, IX, and XI.
