  • Factor 8 deficiency (Hemophilia A), Factor 9 deficiency (Hemophilia B), and Factor 11 deficiency (Hemophilia C) all cause a prolonged APTT with normal PT and bleeding time.

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) affects both platelet function and the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, leading to an increased bleeding time and often a prolonged APTT. However, the presence of a normal bleeding time in this patient rules out vWD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor 8 deficiency: This would present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option B. Factor 9 deficiency: This would also present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option C. Factor 11 deficiency: This would similarly present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isolated increased APTT can be caused by clotting factor deficiency of the intrinsic pathway like hemophilia A/B/C. von Willebrand disease is associated with increased bleeding time and increased APTT.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in varicose vein? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan

 

The investigation of choice for varicose veins is a duplex scan. A duplex scan, also known as a venous Doppler or venous duplex, is a non-invasive ultrasound method that allows visualization of the veins and the blood flow within them. It is particularly useful for identifying the location and extent of venous incompetence, such as at the sapheno-femoral junction and in perforator veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plethysmography: It is not the first-line investigation for varicose veins.

 

Option C. MRI: It may be used in more complex cases where detailed imaging is required.

 

Option D. CT: CT scans are not the primary choice for evaluating varicose veins due to the limited ability to assess venous blood flow and venous incompetence compared to a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duplex scan is the investigation of choice for varicose veins, providing detailed information on venous blood flow and identifying sites of venous incompetence.

questions.text: In Indian health care system, PHC are divided into Type A and Type B PHCs. Number of deliveries in Type A PHC: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less than 20

 

In the Indian health care system, primary health centers (PHCs) are categorized into Type A and Type B based on the number of deliveries performed per month.

 

  • Type A PHCs handle less than 20 deliveries per month
  • Type B PHCs manage 20 or more deliveries per month.

 

This classification helps in resource allocation and planning to ensure adequate maternal and child health services are provided at the PHC level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Indian health care system, Type A PHCs are those that handle less than 20 deliveries per month, while Type B PHCs manage 20 or more deliveries per month.

questions.text: A neonate on breast feeding develops jaundice. Urine Benedict’s test is positive. The enzyme deficiency is_________: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-P Uridyl Transferase

 

This is the enzyme deficient in classic galactosemia, a condition where galactose accumulates in the blood. This occurs because the neonate's diet (breast milk or formula) contains lactose, which is broken down into glucose and galactose. The inability to further metabolize galactose leads to its accumulation, causing symptoms like jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a positive Benedict's test (due to the presence of reducing sugars like galactose in the urine).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactokinase: While a deficiency in galactokinase can cause galactosemia, the clinical presentation is typically milder compared to galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency. Galactokinase deficiency usually leads to cataract formation due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye, but it doesn't typically cause severe jaundice or a positive Benedict's test, which indicates the presence of reducing sugars (like galactose) in urine.

 

 

Option C. Lactose: Lactose is a disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose, not an enzyme. Deficiency of lactase, the enzyme that breaks down lactose, leads to lactose intolerance, which typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and gas, but not jaundice or a positive Benedict's test.

 

Option D. Aldolase B: Aldolase B deficiency leads to hereditary fructose intolerance. When fructose (from fruits, sweeteners, and some infant formulas) is ingested, it cannot be properly metabolized, leading to hypoglycemia and other symptoms. This condition does not lead to the accumulation of galactose, hence not causing the symptoms seen in this neonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neonate's symptoms, including jaundice and a positive Benedict's test for reducing sugars in the urine, are indicative of galactosemia. In galactosemia, there is a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, which is involved in the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. Gal-1-P accumulates causes product inhibition of galactokinase resulting in galactose accumulation which comes out in urine giving positive Benedict’s test.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198

questions.text: Outlet forceps is known as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wrigley forceps

 

 

 

Wrigley forceps, also known as outlet forceps, are short obstetrical forceps used during the final stages of labor when the fetal head is at or near the perineum, typically at +3 station. These forceps are designed for use when the fetal head is low in the pelvis and the internal rotation is either complete or nearly complete (45 degrees or less).

 

Wrigley forceps are specifically used to assist in the delivery when the head is on the perineum and crowning is imminent. They are shorter than other types of forceps, making them suitable for this stage of labor where minimal traction is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piper forceps: These are specialized forceps used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech presentation.

 

 

Option C. Das forceps: These are used in mid-cavity deliveries and are longer and heavier compared to Wrigley forceps.

 

 

Option D. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used for correcting malpositioned fetal heads, especially in cases requiring significant rotation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wrigley forceps, also known as outlet forceps, are used during the final stage of labor when the fetal head is at or near the perineum, specifically at +3 station, to assist in delivery.

questions.text: As per WHO categorization of bioterrorism agents, Anthrax belongs to (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A

 

The WHO categorizes bioterrorism agents into three main categories based on their potential impact on public health and their ease of dissemination.

 

Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) is classified as a Category A agent, which includes the highest priority agents that pose the greatest risk to national security and public health.

 

Category A agents are easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, cause high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: Includes agents that are moderately easy to disseminate and result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates, require enhanced diagnostic capacity with enhanced surveillance.

 

Option C. Category C: Includes NEW emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production and dissemination, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates.

 

Option D. Category D: Not a recognized category by WHO for bioterrorism agents.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Anthrax is the MC used bioterrorism agent
  • Small pox is the most dangerous bioterrorism agent
  • Botulism most lethal toxin wise bioterrorism agent

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge along with the following CT scan. On suction cleaning, there is thick mucin that contains eosinophils, Charcot-Leyden crystals. What would be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal sinusitis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge. The presence of thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, as well as the CT findings, are indicative of allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS). AFS is characterized by the accumulation of eosinophils and allergic mucin in the sinuses, often resulting in hyperdensities on CT scans.

 

Treatment is always surgical exploration (removal of fungal mass)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal Ball: A fungal ball, or mycetoma, typically involves a single sinus (commonly the maxillary sinus) and appears as a mass of fungal elements without significant allergic mucin or eosinophils. It does not usually present with eosinophils or Charcot-Leyden crystals in the discharge.

 

Option C. Chronic rhinosinusitis: Chronic rhinosinusitis involves prolonged inflammation of the sinuses but does not specifically present with the eosinophilic mucin and Charcot-Leyden crystals seen in AFS. The CT findings in chronic rhinosinusitis do not typically show the hyperdensities seen in AFS.

 

Option D. Fulminant fungal sinusitis: Fulminant fungal sinusitis is a rapidly progressive infection seen in immunocompromised patients and involves extensive bony destruction and tissue invasion. The CT scan would show significant bone destruction and possibly extension into adjacent structures, which is not evident in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by unilateral nasal obstruction, thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, and hyperdensities on CT scans, without extensive bony destruction.

questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon performed? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra capsular cataract surgery

 

Explanation:

 

In extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE), a larger incision (approximately 10 to 12 millimeters) is made at the limbus to remove the lens nucleus in one piece. Due to the size of this incision, suturing is necessary to close the wound properly. The suturing is typically performed using 10-0 nylon monofilament. This method can involve interrupted sutures or continuous suturing to ensure the wound is securely closed and to promote proper healing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phacoemulsification: This technique involves making a much smaller incision (around 3 millimeters or less) through which the lens is emulsified and aspirated. Suturing is generally not required because the small incision is self-sealing.

 

Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery): This advanced technique uses a femtosecond laser to create precise incisions and to perform capsulotomy and lens fragmentation. Similar to phacoemulsification, the incisions made are small and typically do not require suturing.

 

Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS): In SICS, the incision size is between 6 to 8 millimeters. Depending on the quality of the incision and tunnel, suturing may or may not be required. Good surgical technique can often avoid the need for suturing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE) requires suturing with 10-0 nylon due to the larger incision size necessary for removing the lens nucleus in one piece.

choices.text: Lower border of the upper rib
Upper border of the lower rib
Lower border of the lower rib

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the needle insertion into the thoracic cavity for the pleural fluid removal? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper border of the lower rib

 

Explanation:

 

The most preferred site for needle insertion during a thoracentesis (removal of pleural fluid) is along the upper border of the lower rib within the intercostal space. This is because the neurovascular bundle (vein, artery, and nerve) runs along the lower border of each rib within the costal groove. Inserting the needle at the upper border of the lower rib minimizes the risk of damaging these vital structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lower border of the upper rib: Inserting the needle here would increase the risk of injuring the neurovascular bundle within the costal groove of the upper rib.

 

Option C. Lower border of the lower rib: This would also pose a high risk of damaging the neurovascular bundle.

 

Option D. Middle of the intercostal space: Inserting the needle here does not provide a safe margin away from the neurovascular structures and could still lead to injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracentesis, always insert the needle at the upper border of the lower rib in the intercostal space to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle located in the costal groove of the upper rib.

questions.text: Farmer with traumatic ulcer in eye and septate hyphae seen. Causative organism is ? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus

 

Explanation:

 

Farmers often suffer from injuries involving organic matter. The presence of a traumatic ulcer in the eye coupled with the identification of septate hyphae points toward a fungal infection.

 

Between Mucor and Aspergillus, the distinguishing factor is the type of hyphae. Aspergillus forms septate hyphae, meaning the hyphae have regular, cross-wall divisions. In contrast, Mucor forms aseptate (or coenocytic) hyphae, which lack these septa.

 

 

Characteristic of Hyphae -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor: Although Mucor is a fungus that can cause infections, it forms aseptate hyphae. This characteristic helps differentiate it from Aspergillus in cases of fungal eye infections.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes: This bacterium can cause various infections, including those in the eye, but it does not form hyphae. Thus, it cannot be the causative organism in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas: This is another bacterium that can cause eye infections, particularly in the context of contact lens wearers, but like Streptococcus pyogenes, it does not form hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of septate hyphae in an eye infection suggests Aspergillus as the causative organism.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not carry parasympathetic fibers? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trochlear

 

Explanation:

 

Among the cranial nerves, only the oculomotor (CN III), facial (CN VII), glossopharyngeal (CN IX), and vagus (CN X) nerves carry parasympathetic fibers. These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity in the head, neck, and face area. The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is not involved in parasympathetic innervation.

 

The parasympathetic ganglia associated with these cranial nerves are:

 

  • Oculomotor (CN III): Ciliary ganglion, related to the eye
  • Facial (CN VII): Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia, causing secretion from nasal, palatine, and submandibular glands
  • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): Otic ganglion
  • Vagus (CN X): Responsible for secretion from the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial: The facial nerve (CN VII) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia.

 

Option C. Oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the ciliary ganglion.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the otic ganglion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic fibers are CN III, CN VII, CN IX, and CN X (3, 7, 9, 10). These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity and secretion in the head, neck, and face area, as well as the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A Doctor comes to the court to present his postmortem report. What kind of witness is the Doctor?(FMGE  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Expert witness

 

Explanation:

 

Expert witness is a person who has been trained or skilled in technical or scientific subject. He can volunteer a statement, if he feels that justice is likely to be miscarried owing to the court having failed to elicit an important point.

 

In this case, a doctor presenting a postmortem report is providing technical opinion based on medical expertise, making them an expert witness. An expert witness is typically required to give opinions on their area of expertise, and in this scenario, the doctor's analysis and interpretation of the postmortem findings classify them as such.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hostile witness: This refers to a witness who deliberately does not tell the truth or speaks lies in court. This can apply to both common and expert witnesses.

 

Option C. Common witness: This refers to a witness providing factual information without any specialized knowledge or opinions. In this scenario, since the doctor is giving an opinion based on medical expertise, they are not a common witness.

 

Option D. Hearsay witness: This is someone who reports what they have been told by another person rather than what they personally observed. Hearsay witnesses are generally not considered reliable in court.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A doctor presenting a postmortem report in court is classified as an expert witness due to their specialized medical knowledge and ability to provide technical opinions. ​

 

Note – Doctor is both common and Expert witness

questions.text: An anticancer drug, 5-Fluorouracil, causes thymineless death of cells. Which type of enzyme inhibition is responsible for this mechanism of action of 5-Fluorouracil? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

5-Fluorouracil exhibits its anticancer effect through competitive inhibition. It is a thymidylate synthase inhibitor, competing with deoxyuridylate for the enzyme binding site. By inhibiting this enzyme, 5-Fluorouracil prevents the synthesis of thymidine, a nucleotide necessary for DNA replication, leading to thymineless death in rapidly dividing cells, like cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an enzyme at a site different from the substrate's binding site, which is not how 5-Fluorouracil works.

 

Option C. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves the binding of an inhibitor to an enzyme at an allosteric site, changing the enzyme's activity, which is different from 5-Fluorouracil's mechanism.

 

Option D. Irreversible: Irreversible inhibitors covalently bind to an enzyme, permanently inactivating it. 5-Fluorouracil, however, is a competitive inhibitor and not an irreversible one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Fluorouracil causes thymineless death of cancer cells through competitive inhibition of thymidylate synthase, blocking thymidine synthesis necessary for DNA replication in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory. On exam, her BMI is 43, BP is 170/100 mm Hg. Her daytime ABG analysis shows HCO3 - 33 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 53 mmHg, and PaO2 - 70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), which is characterized by the following criteria:

 

  • A BMI of 30 or more, indicating obesity.
  • Hypercarbia or hypercapnia, defined as PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg.
  • The awake ABG must be taken (daytime ABG).
  • No other causes (central or peripheral neuromuscular) should be present to explain the hypercapnia.

 

The patient's symptoms and test results align with OHS. OHS patients typically present with symptoms like daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory, which are noted in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstructive sleep apnea: This condition typically causes issues during sleep, not in the daytime. It is characterized by repeated episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep.

 

Option B. Narcolepsy: This is a sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks, but it does not align with the patient’s clinical picture, which includes specific ABG results and severe obesity.

 

Option D. Central sleep apnea: Like obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea occurs during sleep and involves periods of non-breathing. It does not match the daytime ABG findings of this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is diagnosed based on a BMI of 30 or more, daytime hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg), and the absence of other causes for hypercapnia.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the photograph:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal Hopkin's endoscope

 

Explanation: 

 

The instrument shown in the photograph is a Nasal Hopkin's endoscope. This endoscope is commonly used in ENT endoscopic procedures to provide a clear and magnified view of the nasal and sinus passages. It consists of a rigid rod lens system that allows visualization of the internal structures during diagnostic and surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frazier's straight suction tube: Frazier's straight suction tube is a different instrument used for suction during surgeries, particularly in nasal surgeries.

 

 

Option C. Atomizer: An atomizer is a device used to convert liquid medication into a fine mist for nasal application.

 

 

Option D. Tilley antral trochar and canula: The Tilley antral trochar and canula are used for procedures such as antral lavage or drainage of the maxillary sinus, particularly in Caldwell-Luc surgeries.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nasal Hopkin's endoscope is a critical tool in ENT endoscopic procedures, providing detailed visualization of nasal and sinus structures for both diagnostic and surgical purposes.

questions.text: Ottawa Charter includes all except: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potentiate

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion, established in 1986, outlines five key action areas essential for health promotion: building healthy public policy, creating supportive environments, strengthening community action, developing personal skills, and reorienting health services.

 

In addition to these action areas, the Ottawa Charter emphasizes three fundamental strategies for health promotion: advocate, enable, and mediate. These strategies are aimed at fostering conditions that promote health and well-being, empowering individuals and communities, and facilitating partnerships among various sectors to achieve health goals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advocate: Advocacy is a core strategy of the Ottawa Charter aimed at creating conditions conducive to health by influencing public policy and resource allocation.

 

Option B. Enable: Enabling involves empowering people to achieve their fullest health potential by providing equitable access to resources and opportunities.

 

Option D. Mediate: Mediation focuses on coordinating actions among various sectors and stakeholders to resolve conflicts and achieve consensus for health promotion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion includes the strategies of advocate, enable, and mediate, but does not include potentiate.

questions.text: A farmer is spraying an odourless chemical in the fields, which is an Inhibitor of Complex III of ETC. Identify the compound: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antimycin A

 

Antimycin A is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) of the ETC. It binds to the Qo site of cytochrome b and blocks electron transfer from ubiquinol to cytochrome c1, disrupting ATP synthesis. It's used in fisheries and can be employed in agricultural settings for pest control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxin: Carboxin is a fungicide, but it primarily inhibits succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II) in the ETC, not Complex III. It interferes with fungal respiration by inhibiting electron transport at this specific complex.

 

Option B. Rotenone: Rotenone is an insecticide and piscicide that inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the ETC. It acts by blocking electron transport, leading to the cessation of ATP production in the cells it affects.

 

Option C. Cyanide: Cyanide is a potent and highly toxic compound that inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the ETC. It binds to the iron in the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase, stopping cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of ETC:

 

Complex I- Rotenone, Phenobarbitone, Amobarbital

 

Complex II- Malonate (3C), Carboxin

 

Complex III- Phenformin, Antimycin A, BAL

 

Complex IV- CN, CO, Sodium azide, H2S

 

Pesticides used in agricultural fields:

 

  • Rotenone is also an insecticide, pesticide and a herbicide
  • Carboxin is a fungicide that is commonly used in agricultural practices
  • Antimycin – used in agriculture to control certain pests that affect crops
  • Cyanide

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 127

questions.text: A construction worker sustained a head injury from a hammer falling on his head. The CT scan image is shown as below. What is the diagnosis ?(FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depressed skull fracture

 

  • The provided X-ray and CT image specifically shows the inward depression of the skull, which confirms the diagnosis of a depressed skull fracture. This condition requires urgent medical evaluation to assess for underlying brain injury and possible surgical intervention to correct the skull deformity and reduce the risk of complications like brain compression or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural Hematoma: Typically appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) mass between the skull and the dura mater on imaging. It is generally associated with arterial bleeding and is a neurosurgical emergency.

 

Option B. Concussion: A form of mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) usually caused by a blow to the head. It does not typically show up on a CT scan and is diagnosed based on clinical symptoms rather than imaging findings.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: This would appear as areas of increased density within the subarachnoid space on a CT scan, typically caused by trauma or ruptured aneurysms. It doesn’t present with structural deformity of the skull as seen in the image.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • Depressed Skull Fracture is visible on a CT scan as parts of the skull bone being pushed inward toward the brain. It's often caused by direct impact, such as being hit with a hammer, and can pose a risk of brain injury depending on the depth and location of the depression.

questions.text: A child as shown below presented to the ENT department with the following finding. She gives complaint of recurrent bony fractures along with reduced hearing. On further investigation, Tympanometry showed the following finding. What would you name this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Van der Hoeve syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta (imperfectly developed bones).

 

The tympanometry shows an AS type of curve, suggesting otosclerosis.

 

Additionally, the child has a blue sclera, which is a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

This combination of symptoms — osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis — forms a triad known as Van der Hoeve syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waardenburg syndrome: Waardenburg syndrome is characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and pigmentary abnormalities such as a white forelock of hair (piebaldism).

 

 

Option C. Usher's syndrome: Usher's syndrome is associated with retinitis pigmentosa and congenital sensorineural hearing loss.

 

                Retinitis pigmentosa

 

Option D. Pendred syndrome: Pendred syndrome includes congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van der Hoeve syndrome is characterized by the triad of osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis.

questions.text: In a patient with thyroid malignancy, serum calcitonin was found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid, which produce the hormone calcitonin. Elevated serum calcitonin is a characteristic marker for MTC. In addition to calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can also be elevated in MTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because follicular thyroid carcinoma typically does not elevate calcitonin. Instead, it may show elevated serum thyroglobulin.

 

Option B. Papillary thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because papillary thyroid carcinoma is associated with elevated serum thyroglobulin, not calcitonin.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma: This is incorrect as anaplastic carcinoma is an aggressive form of thyroid cancer that does not produce calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is the thyroid cancer associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels, distinguishing it from other types of thyroid malignancies.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following lesions that started 2 days after he developed a fever. On examination, there are generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chickenpox

 

Explanation:

 

The description and image provided indicate a diagnosis of chickenpox (varicella). Key features include:

 

  • Generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk.
  • The lesions appear as "dew drops on a rose petal," which is characteristic of chickenpox.
  • Chickenpox lesions are typically in various stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) at the same time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smallpox: Presents with a more uniform appearance of lesions and typically starts on the face and extremities.

 

Option C. Monkeypox: Presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a rash that is similar to smallpox but usually more severe.

 

Option D. Shingles: Generally presents in a dermatomal distribution and occurs in older individuals or those with a history of varicella.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chickenpox is characterized by generalized vesicular eruptions that look like "dew drops on a rose petal" and appear in various stages simultaneously.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in homocystinuria is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystathionine beta synthase


Homocystinuria is a genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine beta synthase. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the metabolism of the amino acid methionine. When cystathionine beta synthase is deficient, it leads to the accumulation of homocysteine and methionine in the body, which can cause a range of symptoms including cardiovascular problems, skeletal abnormalities, and neurological issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is an amino acid that accumulates in homocystinuria due to the deficiency of cystathionine beta synthase. It is not the enzyme that is deficient, but rather a substance that builds up as a result of the enzyme deficiency.

 

Option C. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that is part of the metabolic pathway affected in homocystinuria. The enzyme cystathionine beta synthase is involved in converting homocysteine to cystathionine, so its deficiency leads to elevated methionine levels. However, methionine is not the deficient enzyme.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the enzyme deficient in homocystinuria is indeed cystathionine beta synthase.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the enzymatic basis of homocystinuria, recognizing that the deficiency of cystathionine beta synthase leads to the accumulation of homocysteine and methionine, contributing to the clinical manifestations of the disorder.

questions.text: Identify the plant (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebra Thevetia

 

Explanation:

 

Cerebra Thevetia (Yellow Oleander): This plant is identified by its yellow, bell-shaped flowers. It is also known as a cardiotoxic plant. The yellow oleander typically has these distinct flowers and should be recognized for its toxic properties.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerium Odorum (White Oleander): White in color and not bell-shaped flower. It is also cardiotoxic.

 

 

Option C. Aconite: Also known as monk's hood, Aconite has hood-like flowers. It is characterized by a hood-like upper part and two-lipped lower part.

 

 

Option D. Cerbera odollam: Also known as the "suicide tree", it produces white flowers, mango like fruit and this is also cardiotoxic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander) - Yellow, bell-shaped flowers, a cardiotoxic plant.

 

Nerium Odorum (White Oleander) - White and flowers are not bell-shaped, also cardiotoxic

 

Note – Other Important flowers

 

Trumpet shape flower – Datura

 

 

Digitalis Purpura flowers – arranged in elongated clusters, flower is tubular & pendant. Inside of the flower is heavily spotted

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following nutrients can lead to delayed wound healing? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including DNA synthesis, cell division, and protein synthesis, all of which are vital for wound healing. Zinc is a cofactor for numerous enzymes, including matrix metalloproteinases, which are involved in the remodeling of extracellular matrix during wound healing. A deficiency in zinc impairs these processes, leading to delayed wound healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important for oxygen transport and cellular respiration, but its deficiency primarily leads to anemia and fatigue rather than directly causing delayed wound healing.

 

Option B. Magnesium: Magnesium is involved in many biochemical reactions, but its deficiency is more likely to cause muscle cramps, arrhythmias, and neuromuscular issues rather than significantly impacting wound healing.

 

Option D. Manganese: Manganese is a trace mineral important for bone formation and metabolism. While it is involved in enzyme function, its deficiency is less commonly linked to delayed wound healing compared to zinc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is required for functioning of matrix metalloproteases and so, required for proper wound healing. Any deficiency of zinc can lead to delayed wound healing.

questions.text: In which condition is Grey Turner's sign, characterized by bruising on the abdominal wall, typically observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pancreatitis with hemorrhage

 

The image provided shows the Grey Turner's sign, which is characterized by bruising on the flank area seen in pancreatitis with hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal hypertension: There is no connection between Grey Turner's sign and portal hypertension, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cancer stomach: There is no connection between Grey Turner's sign and stomach cancer, rendering this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Pancreatic cancer: Grey Turner's sign is seen in hemorrhagic pancreatitis, not pancreatic cancer, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grey Turner's sign, characterized by bruising on the abdominal wall (flank area), is a clinical manifestation typically observed in cases of hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.text: While assessing children's nutritional status in a school, you come across a child with low height for age. What is this known as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stunting

 

Explanation:

 

Low height for age is referred to as stunting. Stunting is an indicator of chronic malnutrition, where the child's growth has been inhibited over a prolonged period.

 

Note – Stunting is also known as Dwarfism

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Underweight: Low weight for age is known as underweight. It can indicate acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option B. Wasting: Low weight for height is referred to as wasting. This indicates acute malnutrition, where there has been a significant recent weight loss. Wasting is also known as Emaciation.

 

Option C. Overweight: This indicates excess weight relative to height.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low height for age is known as stunting and indicates chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: A dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure undergoes cystoscopy. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoscopy with removal of tumor

 

The patient, a dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure, undergoes cystoscopy which reveals a bladder growth. Benzidine exposure is a known risk factor for bladder cancer. The appropriate initial management for a bladder tumor identified on cystoscopy is to perform a cystoscopic removal of the tumor, also known as transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT). This procedure allows for both the resection of the tumor and a biopsy to determine the stage and grade of the cancer.

 

  • If the tumor is non-muscle invasive (T1), intravesical BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guerin) therapy is administered to reduce the risk of recurrence.
  • If the tumor is muscle-invasive (T2 or worse), more radical treatment such as radical cystectomy (removal of the bladder) may be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV BCG: This is incorrect as initial treatment. BCG is used as an adjuvant therapy after TURBT for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

 

Option C. TURP (Transurethral Resection of the Prostate): This is incorrect as TURP is a procedure used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), not bladder tumors.

 

Option D. Radical cystectomy: This is not the initial step. It is considered if the tumor is muscle-invasive or in cases of high-risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of a bladder tumor seen on cystoscopy is to perform a cystoscopic removal (TURBT) to both resect the tumor and obtain a biopsy for staging and grading.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mode of inheritance shown by the pedigree analysis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AR

 

The fact that there is an affected patient with no disease manifesting in the parents is suggestive of the fact that the parents are heterozygous for the particular gene and the child manifests the disease due to being homozygous for the particular genes. So, we are dealing with an autosomal recessive disease.   

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AD (Autosomal Dominant): In an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, affected individuals have at least one affected parent, and the disease appears in every generation.

 

Option C. XLR (X-linked Recessive): This pattern typically affects males more frequently and is passed through carrier females. The affected males do not pass the gene to their sons but can pass it to their daughters, who become carriers.

 

Option D. XLD (X-linked Dominant): Both males and females can be affected, and the disease does not skip generations. Affected males pass the gene to all daughters but none of their sons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An autosomal recessive inheritance pattern is characterized by the presence of affected individuals with unaffected parents, indicating that the parents are carriers and the disease manifests when two recessive alleles are inherited.

questions.text: A person came to the OPD with a history of fall on the outstretched hand and now has an injury at the anatomical snuff box. Which bone is most commonly fractured at this site?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid

 

Explanation:

 

The scaphoid bone, which forms the floor of the anatomical snuff box, is the most common carpal bone to be fractured.

 

The scaphoid bone is the second most common bone to suffer avascular necrosis after the head of the femur. When a person falls on an outstretched hand, the force is transmitted through the wrist, making the scaphoid bone vulnerable to fracture. The anatomical snuff box is an important anatomical landmark with five different clinical points related to it.

 

 

 

To test for a scaphoid fracture, the "glass holding position" can be used, where the thumb adopts a specific position that stresses the scaphoid bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lunate: Although the lunate is a carpal bone, it is not the most commonly fractured bone at the anatomical snuff box site.

 

Option C. Trapezium: The trapezium is one of the bones that can be palpated in the anatomical snuff box ("then try to catch her, she means trapezium"), but it is not the most commonly fractured bone in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pisiform: The pisiform is a small carpal bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist, not in the anatomical snuff box, and is not commonly fractured in a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scaphoid bone, which forms the floor of the anatomical snuff box, is the most common carpal bone to be fractured when a person falls on an outstretched hand.

 

Note –

 

  • MC bone getting avascular necrosis – head of the femur
  • 2nd most common bone getting avascular necrosis – Scaphoid
  • MC carpal bone getting fractured - scaphoid

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotypes is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG

 

Explanation:

 

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). The pathogenesis of AIDP involves autoimmune mechanisms where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the peripheral nerves. This autoimmune response primarily involves the production of IgG antibodies against gangliosides present on the nerve membranes.

 

IgG antibodies are significant in the diagnosis and monitoring of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, and tests for ganglioside antibodies (such as anti-GM1 IgG) are commonly ordered in clinical settings to support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily involved in mucosal immunity and is not a key player in the pathogenesis of AIDP.

 

Option C. IgM: Although IgM antibodies are involved in initial immune responses, they are not primarily associated with AIDP pathogenesis.

 

Option D. IgE: IgE is associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections, not with the autoimmune processes seen in AIDP.

 

Educational Objectives

 

IgG antibodies are involved in the pathogenesis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP), which is the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome.

questions.text: Patient died and relatives said he had a tattoo, but it was not visible on autopsy. Which is the best location to check for the evidence of tattoo?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymph node

 

Explanation

 

When a tattoo is not visible on autopsy, it may be due to fading or complete disappearance. In such cases, the best way to check for evidence of the tattoo is to look for the tattoo ink in the nearby lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: Incorrect because the spleen is not typically involved in draining tattoo ink.

 

Option B. Artery: Incorrect as arteries do not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Liver: Incorrect because the liver is not a primary site for tattoo ink deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a tattoo is not visible on autopsy, checking the nearby lymph nodes for the presence of tattoo ink is the best approach to find evidence of the tattoo.

 

Key points to understand about checking for evidence of tattoos:

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with an extremely painful blister characterized by a woody surface. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing fasciitis

 

The elderly patient presents with an extremely painful lower limb blister characterized by a woody surface, which is indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe, rapidly progressing infection of the fascial planes that leads to tissue necrosis. It commonly affects the elderly or those with compromised immune systems and can follow trivial trauma. The infection begins in the fascia and subcutaneous tissue and can quickly spread, leading to gangrene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gas gangrene: This is incorrect as gas gangrene typically presents with a history of trauma or puncture wounds, and the presence of crepitus (air pockets) in the tissue, which is not described here.

 

Option B. Cellulitis: This is incorrect as cellulitis is an inflammation of the subcutaneous fat, usually without the formation of blisters or a woody texture, and it is not typically as painful as described.

 

Option D. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): This is incorrect as DVT presents with limb swelling and pain but does not cause blistering or a woody surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe infection that affects the fascia and subcutaneous tissues, leading to extreme pain, blistering, and a woody surface, and requires prompt medical attention.

questions.text: A person purchased two bottles of alcohol from a local liquor store and subsequently developed symptoms of drowsiness, blurred vision, and ataxia. What is the appropriate antidote for treatment?  (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethyl alcohol

 

Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is the correct antidote in this scenario, where the symptoms of drowsiness, blurred vision, and ataxia suggest methanol poisoning, potentially from adulterated alcohol. Ethanol acts by competing with methanol for the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which slows down the conversion of methanol into its toxic metabolites, formaldehyde and formic acid.

 

Note: Now, the antidote of choice for methanol poisoning is fomepizole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose. It is not effective in methanol poisoning, as the symptoms and underlying toxicological mechanisms are different.

 

Option C. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine and would not be an appropriate antidote for methanol poisoning. In fact, using diazepam in this context could exacerbate central nervous system depression.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used in opioid overdose cases. It is not effective against the toxic effects of methanol and would not be appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is used as an antidote in methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, thus preventing the formation of toxic metabolites.

questions.text: What TNM stage is appropriate for a woman with a breast lump and peau d'orange appearance affecting more than two-thirds of the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4d

 

Peau d'orange (orange peel appearance) is a clinical sign indicating skin involvement in breast cancer. The TNM staging system for breast cancer classifies tumors with peau d'orange under T4b. However, when the peau d'orange affects a significant portion of the breast, specifically more than one-third of the breast skin, it indicates a more advanced stage known as inflammatory breast carcinoma, which is classified as T4d.

 

Given the information that the peau d'orange affects more than two-thirds of the breast, the appropriate TNM stage is T4d, signifying inflammatory breast carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4a: This is incorrect as T4a refers to the extension of the tumor to the chest wall.

 

Option B. T4b: This is incorrect as T4b includes peau d'orange but only when it involves less than one-third of the breast skin.

 

Option C. T4c: This is incorrect as T4c is a combination of T4a and T4b, indicating extension to the chest wall and skin involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange affecting more than one-third of the breast skin is classified as T4d, indicating inflammatory breast carcinoma.

questions.text: A teenage patient came with pain and a palpable lump in Right iliac fossa. Blood investigation shows increased TLC. What is the management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oschner Sherren regime

 

The patient, a teenager, presents with pain and a palpable lump in the right iliac fossa (RIF), along with an increased total leukocyte count (TLC). These findings are suggestive of acute appendicitis with an appendicular phlegmon. An appendicular phlegmon occurs when inflammation spreads, and the omentum and other structures seal off the inflamed appendix, forming a palpable mass.

 

In this scenario, immediate surgical intervention such as laparoscopy or open appendectomy is not recommended because it involves breaking the seal formed by the omentum, complicating the procedure. Instead, the preferred management is conservative, following the Oschner Sherren regime. This regimen involves:

 

  • Keeping the patient nil by mouth (NPO).
  • Administering intravenous antibiotics to control infection.
  • Providing intravenous fluids for hydration.
  • Observing the patient until the inflammation subsides.

 

Once the lump resolves and the infection is under control, an interval appendectomy can be performed later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopy Appendectomy: This is not recommended in the presence of an appendicular phlegmon.

 

Option C. Alvarado regime: This is a scoring system used to assess the likelihood of appendicitis, not a management strategy.

 

Option D. Open Appendectomy: This is not recommended when a phlegmon is present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oschner Sherren regime is the conservative management approach for an appendicular phlegmon, involving NPO status, IV antibiotics, and fluids, followed by interval appendectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-emetic drugs can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects, particularly with prolonged use. It works by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain, which can lead to symptoms similar to those seen in Parkinson's disease, such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: While it's a dopamine antagonist like metoclopramide, domperidone does not readily cross the blood-brain barrier and is unlikely to cause extrapyramidal effects.

 

Option B. Ondansetron: This is a 5-HT3 antagonist used to prevent nausea and vomiting, and it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects.

 

Option D. Promethazine: An antihistamine and antiemetic, promethazine may cause sedation and anticholinergic effects, but unlikely to. be associated with extrapyramidal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide can result in extrapyramidal adverse effects due to its dopamine receptor antagonist activity in the brain, leading to symptoms similar to Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A 2 years old child present to OPD at PHC with complaints of cough and coryza. On examination, fever and conjunctivitis are present. Mother told that the rash started behind ear pinna then came over the trunk. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measles

 

Explanation:

 

Measles is characterized by symptoms like cough, coryza, fever, and conjunctivitis. The crucial diagnostic clue is the rash starting from behind the ear (retroauricular origin) and spreading to the trunk. This progression, coupled with the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa opposite the second molar before the rash appears, confirms measles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dengue: Typically presents with high fever and severe headache, pain behind the eyes, muscle and joint pains; rash is not primarily retroauricular.

 

Option B. Chikungunya: Presents with fever and severe joint pain but lacks the characteristic early symptoms and rash pattern of measles.

 

Option D. Rubella: While it can cause rash and fever, the rash usually starts on the face and spreads downward, and it lacks the specific Koplik spots associated with measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles should be suspected in children presenting with cough, coryza, fever, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic rash starting from behind the ear, spreading to the trunk, alongside the presence of Koplik spots.

questions.text: Which of the following samples is considered the best for detecting lead poisoning? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood

 

Explanation:

 

Lead poisoning primarily affects the synthesis of heme by inhibiting three crucial enzymes: Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and Ferrochelatase. This inhibition leads to the accumulation of their immediate precursors: aminolevulinic acid, coproporphyrinogen, and protoporphyrin.

 

Due to this, lead poisoning can present with various symptoms, including anemia, punctate basophilia (bluish granules in RBCs), and elevated levels of these precursors. The most reliable diagnostic measure for lead poisoning is the blood lead level (> 70 μg/dl), which correlates best with adverse clinical symptoms and the toxicity profile of lead.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hair: While lead can be detected in hair, it does not correlate as well with the severity of poisoning or clinical symptoms as blood levels do.

 

Option C. Saliva: Saliva is not a standard sample for lead detection and does not provide reliable results.

 

Option D. Urine: Though urine can show lead excretion, it is not as reliable as blood levels for correlating with toxicity and clinical manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood lead levels are the most reliable and best indicator for detecting lead poisoning, correlating well with clinical symptoms and toxicity.

 

Laboratory diagnosis of Lead Poisoning –

 

  • Porphyrinuria due to coproporphyrin III.
  • Blood lead level > 70–100 μg/dl.
  • Protoporphyrin  > 35 μg/dl.
  • Urine lead level > 0.15–0.3 mg/l.

questions.text: A 32 weeks pregnant woman is at risk of GDM. She would have likely had a screening test during which time of pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24-28 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically diagnosed during pregnancy and is due to the hormonal changes associated with pregnancy. These hormonal changes, particularly the placental hormones, cause increased insulin resistance, which generally becomes apparent after 24 weeks of gestation.

 

The optimal time to screen for GDM is between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy.

 

This period is chosen because it is when the effects of placental hormones on glucose metabolism become significant enough to detect any abnormalities in glucose tolerance.

 

Screening Methods:

 

  1. IADPSG Criteria (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups):
    • A 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is performed.
    • Blood glucose levels are checked fasting, at 1 hour, and at 2 hours after glucose intake.
    • Diagnostic criteria:
      • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
      • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
      • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
    • Any one of these values being abnormal is diagnostic of GDM.
  2. DIPSI Criteria (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India):
    • The patient does not need to be fasting.
    • A 75-gram glucose load is given, and blood glucose is checked after 2 hours.
    • A value ≥ 140 mg/dL is diagnostic of GDM.

 

Note - First visit is the time to screen for pre-existing diabetes or overt diabetes in women who may not know they are diabetic. It is not the typical time for GDM screening, which occurs later in pregnancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

The appropriate time to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus is between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy, as this is when the impact of placental hormones on glucose metabolism is most apparent.

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 400 mEq

 

Explanation:

 

The sodium deficit can be calculated using the formula:

 

Sodium Deficit=Total Body Water×(Desired Sodium−Actual Sodium)

 

For females, the Total Body Water (TBW) is 50% of body weight

 

TBW=0.5×Body Weight

 

Here, the body weight is 40 kg:

 

TBW=0.5×40 kg=20 LTBW=0.5×40 kg=20 L

 

The desired sodium concentration is 140 mEq/L and the actual sodium concentration is 120

 

mEq/L:

 

Sodium Deficit=20 L×(140 mEq/L−120 mEq/L) =400 mEq

 

Therefore, the sodium deficit is 400 mEq.

 

Educational Objectives

 

The sodium deficit for a female weighing 40 kg with a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L, aiming for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L, is 400 mEq.

choices.text: 3 Lac IU

questions.text: Under the guidelines used in India, the dose of Vitamin A for 1-3 years old is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 Lac IU

 

Explanation:

 

According to the immunization schedule and the older Vitamin A prophylaxis program in India, the recommended dose for children up to 1 year of age is 1 lakh international units (IU). For infants below 6 months of age, a dose of 50,000 IU is administered.

Once a child crosses the age of 1 year, the dose increases to 2 lakh IU. This dosage is applicable for toddlers, adolescents, and adults, and is used for both prophylaxis and treatment of Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. 50,000 IU: This dose is recommended for infants below 6 months of age.

 

  • Option B. 1 Lac IU: This dose is given to children up to 1 year of age.

 

  • Option D. 3 Lac IU: Not recommended under the guidelines of Vitamin A prophylaxis program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children aged 1-3 years, the recommended dose of Vitamin A under Indian guidelines is 2 lakh international units (IU).

questions.text: What is the mid arm circumference for severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11.5 cm

 

A mid-arm circumference of less than 11.5 cm is often used as one of the anthropometric indicators for severe acute malnutrition in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition is defined as

 

  1. Weight for height <-3 standard deviation
  2. Mid upper arm circumference <11.5cm
  3. Bilateral pedal edema

choices.text: No of those getting adequate treatment

questions.text: In the Rule of halves phenomenon (See image below), Mark what is represented by innermost circle (black color)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No of those getting adequate treatment

 

Explanation:

 

The rule of halves is a phenomenon applicable to hypertension, which states that as blood pressure increases with age, roughly 50% of the adult population will have hypertension at any given point in time.

The image shows concentric circles representing different subsets of the population with hypertension. the innermost black circle represents the number of people who are getting adequate treatment for their hypertension. This is 50% of the subset who seek treatment, which is itself 50% of those who are symptomatic, who are in turn 50% of the total number of people with hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No of hypertensives: This option is incorrect because the number of hypertensives is represented by the yellow circle, which is the second outermost circle, not the innermost black circle.

 

Option B. No of those symptomatic: This option is incorrect because the number of those symptomatic is represented by the green circle, which is the third outermost circle, not the innermost black circle.

 

Option C. No of those seeking treatment: This option is incorrect because the number of those seeking treatment is represented by the red circle, which is the second innermost circle, not the innermost black circle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the rule of halves phenomenon for hypertension, the innermost circle represents the number of people who are getting adequate treatment, which is only 50% of the subset who seek treatment, highlighting the need for improved hypertension management.

questions.text: Identify this maneuver: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ritgen maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the Ritgen maneuver, which is performed during the second stage of labor to control the delivery of the fetal head. This maneuver involves controlled extension of the head to minimize perineal trauma. The pressure is applied on the fetal chin through the perineum while simultaneously controlling the speed of delivery of the head with the other hand.

 

This helps in a gradual delivery of the head, reducing the risk of severe perineal tears.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinard maneuver: This maneuver is used during breech delivery to assist in delivering the legs by hooking them at the popliteal fossa.

 

 

Option B. Lovset maneuver: This is also used in breech delivery, specifically to help deliver the arms that are positioned over the head (nuchal arms).

 

 

Option D. Mauriceau maneuver: This is used for delivering the after-coming head in a breech presentation, involving the application of pressure on the maxilla and supporting the body of the baby to facilitate head delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ritgen maneuver involves controlled extension of the fetal head during delivery to minimize perineal trauma and ensure a smooth birth process.

questions.text: What is the karyotype associated with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 47, XY (+21)


The image shows a single palmar crease, also known as a "simian crease," which is commonly associated with Down syndrome. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21, resulting in the karyotype 47, XY (+21) in males or 47, XX (+21) in females. This condition leads to a variety of physical and intellectual disabilities, and the single palmar crease is one of the characteristic physical findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 45, XO: This karyotype represents Turner syndrome, a condition where a female has only one X chromosome. It is not associated with a single palmar crease.

 

Option C. 47, XY (+18): This karyotype is associated with Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18. Edward syndrome has a different set of physical characteristics, such as clenched fists with overlapping fingers and rocker-bottom feet, rather than a single palmar crease.

 

Option D. 47, XY (+13): This karyotype corresponds to Patau syndrome, or trisomy 13, which is associated with severe congenital anomalies including cleft lip/palate and polydactyly, not a single palmar crease.

 

Educational Objective:


Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common non-preventable cause of intellectual disability and is associated with characteristic physical findings such as a single palmar crease.

questions.text: A patient is showing stubbornness and frugality. According to psychosexual stages of development, the fixation is in which stage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anal

 

According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which is no longer widely accepted, fixation at the anal stage can lead to certain personality traits in adulthood.

 

Individuals with anal fixation are said to be overly concerned with cleanliness, perfection, punctuality, and adherence to rules. They may exhibit stubbornness, frugality (not spending much and using minimal things), and a strong belief in their own rightness. The patient in this question displays stubbornness and frugality, which are characteristics associated with fixation at the anal stage of psychosexual development.

 

According to this theory, fixation at anal stage can cause OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral fixation is not associated with stubbornness and frugality.

 

Option C. Phallic fixation is not related to the given traits of stubbornness and frugality.

 

Option D. Genital fixation does not correspond to the characteristics mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which is no longer widely accepted, fixation at the anal stage is thought to cause personality traits such as stubbornness, frugality, obsession with cleanliness, perfection, punctuality, and adherence to rules. Anal fixation is also believed to potentially lead to obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) based on this theory.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to OPD at PHC for her general health check-up. Parents told the medical officer that currently she isn’t enrolled in any school. Which program is going to benefit the girl? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ICDS

 

Explanation:

 

The Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program, established in 1975, focuses on improving the health, nutrition, and education of young children, adolescent girls, and women.

For a 10-year-old girl not enrolled in any school, the ICDS program, which operates through Anganwadi centers, is most suitable. The Anganwadi center provides health check-ups, nutritional supplementation, immunizations, and counseling services appropriate for her age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid day meal program: This program is available only in schools and thus does not benefit a girl not enrolled in any school.

 

Option C. RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram): Focuses on health screening and early intervention for children enrolled in schools and Anganwadi centers but is not the most direct benefit for a non-school-going girl.

 

Option D. NSSK (Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram): Targets the care of newborns and is irrelevant for a 10-year-old.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ICDS program provides comprehensive health and nutritional benefits for children up to 6 years and adolescent girls up to 18 years through Anganwadi centers, making it the ideal choice for a 10-year-old girl not enrolled in school.

questions.text: Name the material which is used for Lichtenstein mesh repair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polypropylene

 

The material used for Lichtenstein mesh repair is polypropylene, commonly referred to as Prolene mesh. It is a non-absorbable synthetic mesh, meaning it remains in the body permanently to provide ongoing support to the repaired area. The Lichtenstein repair technique is commonly used in hernia surgery to provide a tension-free repair by reinforcing the weakened area with this mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyglycolic acid: This is incorrect because polyglycolic acid is an absorbable suture material and not suitable for long-term reinforcement as required in mesh repair.

 

Option C. Polyacrylamide: This is incorrect because polyacrylamide is not used in surgical mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Polygalactin: This is incorrect as polygalactin (Vicryl) is also an absorbable material used primarily for suturing, not for permanent mesh repair.

 

Extra edge:

 

In intraperitoneal repair, IPOM (Intraperitoneal onlay mesh), the mesh that you use is called a dual mesh or a composite mesh. So it will have proline on one side, it will have a collagen or a Teflon on the other side. So it has two surfaces, one surface facing upwards towards the peritoneum, one surface facing downwards towards the intestines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polypropylene mesh is the material of choice for Lichtenstein mesh repair due to its non-absorbable nature, providing long-term reinforcement for hernia repairs.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident presents with bradycardia and hypertension. On examination, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is found to be less than 8. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intubate and ventilation

 

The patient presents with bradycardia and hypertension, indicating raised intracranial pressure (ICP) due to a head injury. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of less than 8 signifies a severe head injury with significantly impaired consciousness. In such cases, the next critical step is to secure the airway through intubation and provide ventilation.

 

Intubation is crucial in this scenario for several reasons:

 

  • Airway protection: With a GCS below 8, the patient is at high risk of airway obstruction due to a lack of protective reflexes. Intubation ensures the airway remains open.
  • Reducing ICP: Positive pressure ventilation at a higher rate can help reduce intracranial pressure by decreasing CO2 levels and inducing cerebral vasoconstriction.
  • Protection from aspiration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urgent CT head: This is an important step but comes after securing the airway and stabilizing the patient.

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: This is incorrect as it is used for conditions such as stroke or myocardial infarction, not for managing raised ICP in trauma patients.

 

Option D. Saline: This is incorrect as administering saline does not address the immediate need to secure the airway and manage raised ICP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a GCS score less than 8, the immediate step is to intubate and ventilate to secure the airway and manage raised intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following presentation as shown in the image. Physical examination shows high riding medially rotated scapula, shaped like an equilateral triangle. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klippel-Feil deformity

 

KLIPPEL-FEIL SYNDROME

 

  • Klippel-Feil Syndrome is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae.
  • It presents with a classical triad of low hair line, short ‘web' neck (prominence of trapezius muscle), and limited neck motion seen in 50% cases.

 

 

  • Abnormal head position, true torticollis, and restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture is an indication for X-rays of cervical spine for evidence of cervical fusion.
  • It is associated with congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine, involving two or more vertebrae. Such fusions can involve the craniocervical junction (occiput to C2), the subaxial cervical spine or both; and results from a failure of the normal division of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis.

 

Associated Features:

  • Scoliosis (~60%) due to fusion of cervical and cervicothoracic junction.
  • Sprengel's deformity (~50%): it is congenitally elevated or undescended scapula (Omovertebral bone bridges the cervical spine to the scapula and limits the neck and shoulder motion)
  • Webbing of neck, facial asymmetry and torticollis.
  • Radiographic findings of congenital cervical vertebral fusion are diagnostic.
  • Neurological sequelae due to involvement of brain stem or cervical cord may be present.
  • Syndactyly and diffuse or focal upper extremity hypoplasia.
  • Secondary osteoarthritis, disc degeneration, spinal stenosis.
  • Genito-renal anomalies (~35%, so USG is recommended)
  • Congenital heart defects (~15%, so ECHO is recommended)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sprengel’s deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Option B. Separated shoulder deformity. A shoulder separation is not truly an injury to the shoulder joint. The injury actually involves the acromioclavicular joint. The most common cause for a separation of the AC joint is from a fall directly onto the shoulder, injuring the ligaments around the AC joint. If the force is severe enough, the ligaments attaching to the underside of the clavicle are torn, causing the separation of the clavivle and the scapula. The scapula moves downward from the weight of the arm, creating a bump or bulge above the shoulder.

 

 

Option C. Torticollis. Torticollis is a symptom of cervical spine abnormality. Congenital torticollis is due to fibrosis of sternocleidomastoid muscle on one side that fails to elongate as child grows. The cause is muscle ischemia from a distorted position in utero (breech) or birth injury. A history of difficult labour followed by lump over SCM (sternomastoid tumor) in first few weeks of life, which disappears in few months is present. Then, there is neither deformity nor obvious limitation of movements. Deformity does not become apparent until the child is 1-2 years old. SCM on involved side may feel tight and hard and a mass or knot can be detected in the body of SCM. It can disappear spontaneously. There may be asymmetrical development of face (plagiocephaly).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High riding medially rotated scapula, shaped like an equilateral triangle is seen in Klippel-Feil syndrome. This occurs due to congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae in the craniocervical junction and/or subaxial cervical spine.

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structures leads to this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loose areolar layer

 

Explanation:

 

The condition, where blood collects around the eyes following a head injury, is known as "raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".

 

Layers of the scalp -

 

The scalp consists of five layers, which can be remembered using the mnemonic "SCALP":

 

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia)
  3. Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis)
  4. Loose areolar layer
  5. Periosteum (pericranium)

 

 

Among these layers, the loose areolar layer (4th layer) is the key to understanding the development of raccoon eyes. This layer lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids. When a head injury occurs, the emissary veins or other vessels in this layer may rupture, causing blood to accumulate. Since the loose areolar layer is continuous with the eyelids, the blood can easily spread and collect around the eyes, resulting in the characteristic black eye appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial fascia: Incorrect. Although the superficial fascia is one of the layers of the scalp, it is not the layer responsible for the continuity with the eyelids and the development of raccoon eyes.

 

Option C. Periosteum: Incorrect. The periosteum, also known as the pericranium, is the innermost layer of the scalp, firmly attached to the underlying bone. It does not have continuity with the eyelids and is not the cause of raccoon eyes.

 

Option D. Pericranium: Incorrect. The pericranium is another name for the periosteum, the innermost layer of the scalp. It is not responsible for the development of raccoon eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loose areolar layer of the scalp, which lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids, is responsible for the development of raccoon eyes following a head injury due to the accumulation and spread of blood from ruptured vessels.

questions.text: A 75 year old diabetic patient presents with acute right flank pain, chills, and rigors. The following investigation has been conducted. What is the presumptive diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emphysematous Cholecystitis

 

  • The image  shows emphysematous cholecystitis. Here's an explanation of each possible diagnosis:
  • A severe form of gallbladder infection characterized by the presence of gas-forming bacteria in the gallbladder wall and lumen. It presents more dramatically with acute pain, fever, and often visible gas in the gallbladder on imaging. This diagnosis is most consistent with the patient's symptoms and the presence of gas around the gallbladder area on the X-ray, indicated by the dark patches resembling air pockets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholecystitis: Typically presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The condition involves inflammation of the gallbladder, often due to obstruction by gallstones.

 

Option B. Renal Calculi: These present as severe pain (often described as flank pain radiating to the groin), hematuria, and urinary urgency or frequency, depending on the location of the stone within the urinary tract.

 

Option C. Papillary Necrosis: This condition involves ischemic necrosis of the renal papillae, which can be caused by conditions such as diabetes, sickle cell disease, or chronic kidney disease. Symptoms include flank pain, hematuria, and renal colic.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Emphysematous cholecystitis is most commonly seen in diabetic patients and shows presence of gas around the gallbladder area on the X-ray, indicated by the dark patches resembling air pockets.

questions.text: An adult presented with pallor, fatigue and reduced work capacity.  His investigations revealed low RBC count, low hemoglobin, MCV 70fL and MCH24pg. which of the following is the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low RBC count, low hemoglobin, and microcytic hypochromic indices (MCV < 80 fl and MCH < 27 pg). The patient’s symptoms of pallor, fatigue, and reduced work capacity are typical of anemia. The lab findings of MCV 70 fl (microcytic) and MCH 24 pg (hypochromic) are consistent with iron deficiency anemia, the most common type of anemia worldwide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folate deficiency: Causes macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 fl), which is not consistent with the patient's lab results.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Typically presents with normocytic or slightly microcytic anemia. However, iron deficiency anemia is more common and fits better with the lab findings.

 

Option C. Anemia due to renal failure: Usually presents with normocytic anemia, where the MCV is within the normal range (80-100 fl), not microcytic.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis is which category of bioweapon? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A
