In Bioterrorism, there is intentional and deliberate release of biological agents (bacteria, viruses, or their toxins) to cause mass illness or death of people, animals, or plants

 

Bioweapons, or biological agents, are classified into three categories (A, B, and C) based on their risk to national security and public health. Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium that causes anthrax, is classified as a Category A bioweapon.

 

Category A:

 

  • Highest Priority: These agents pose the greatest risk to national security and public health because they can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, result in high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.
  • Examples: The mnemonic "Play with small, fine, bad" can help remember the agents in this category.
    • P: Plague (Yersinia pestis)
    • V: Viral hemorrhagic fevers
    • Small: Smallpox (Variola major)
    • Fine: Filoviridae (Ebola, Marburg)
    • 2B: Botulinum toxin, Bunyaviruses
    • 2A: Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis), Arenaviruses
    • T: Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: These agents are the second highest priority and are moderately easy to disseminate. They result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates. Examples –

 

 

Option C. Category C: These agents are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates. Examples –

 

 

Option D. Category D: This option is not part of the standard classification for bioweapons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Bacillus anthracis is classified as a Category A bioweapon due to its high potential for causing significant public health impact through easy dissemination and high mortality rates.

questions.text: From which structure do the alae of the nose develop? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral nasal process

 

Explanation:

 

The development of the face involves five processes: the frontonasal process, medial nasal processes, lateral nasal processes, maxillary processes, and mandibular processes.

 

The central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, develops from the midline frontonasal process. As the nasal pits develop, they give rise to the medial and lateral nasal processes on each side.

 

The alae of the nose, which are the lateral flaring parts of the nostrils, develop from the lateral nasal processes.

 

The maxillary processes give rise to the maxillae, while the mandibular processes form the mandible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontonasal process: Incorrect. The frontonasal process gives rise to the central part of the face, including the dorsum and tip of the nose, philtrum, and columella, but not the alae.

 

Option B. Medial nasal process: Incorrect. The medial nasal processes contribute to the formation of the median part of the nose, but not the alae.

 

Option D. Bucconasal membrane: Incorrect. The bucconasal membrane is not one of the five processes involved in facial development and does not give rise to the alae of the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The alae of the nose develop from the lateral nasal processes during facial development.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the below image? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Horse Shoe Kidney

 

The CT image provided depicts a horseshoe kidney.

 

Horseshoe Kidney: In this condition, the two kidneys are joined together at their lower ends forming a U shape, often at the lower part of the abdomen across the midline. The image shows the kidneys joined across the midline, indicative of a horseshoe kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycystic Kidney Disease: This condition is characterized by the presence of numerous cysts in the kidneys, which can cause the kidneys to enlarge and lose function over time. The image does not show multiple cysts characteristic of this disease.

 

Option C. Fused Ectopic Kidney: This refers to a kidney that is abnormally positioned and fused with the other kidney. It can appear similar to a horseshoe kidney but generally involves a displacement of one kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horseshoe kidney is a congenital disorder where the kidneys are connected at the lower ends and lie across the midline. It’s often asymptomatic but can be associated with complications like urinary tract infections or stones.

questions.text: The drug used in chemoradiation in cervical cancer:  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cisplatin

 

In the treatment of cervical cancer, chemoradiation is a standard approach, particularly for stages beyond 2A where surgery may not be feasible.

 

Chemoradiation combines chemotherapy and radiation therapy to enhance the effectiveness of treatment.

 

Cisplatin is the drug of choice because it acts as a radiosensitizer. This means. that cisplatin makes the cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation therapy, thereby increasing the overall efficacy of the treatment. The standard regimen involves administering cisplatin concurrently with external beam radiotherapy, and this may be followed by internal beam radiotherapy to maximize treatment impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Used in various chemotherapy regimens but not as a primary radiosensitizer in cervical cancer chemoradiation.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases but not primarily in cervical cancer chemoradiation.

 

Option C. Actinomycin D: Used in the treatment of certain pediatric cancers and other malignancies but not as a standard radiosensitizer in cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisplatin is the preferred drug used in chemoradiation for cervical cancer because it acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of radiation therapy.

questions.text: In which of the following will you NOT do induction of labor? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central Placenta Previa

 

Explanation:

 

Induction of labor involves starting labor artificially in a patient who is not already in labor, usually to expedite delivery due to various maternal or fetal indications such as fetal growth restriction, post-term pregnancy, oligohydramnios, or preeclampsia. The goal of induction is to achieve vaginal delivery.

 

However, induction is contraindicated in situations where vaginal delivery is not possible or safe, as in central placenta previa, where the placenta completely covers the cervical os. Attempting vaginal delivery in this situation can lead to severe hemorrhage as contractions begin. Therefore, a cesarean section is indicated for central placenta previa to avoid the risk of bleeding and ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligohydramnios: Induction is indicated to avoid complications from low amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Induction is recommended at 37 weeks for mild preeclampsia and at 34 weeks for severe preeclampsia to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Option D. PROM: Induction is required if labor does not start spontaneously to prevent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Induction of labor is contraindicated in central placenta previa due to the risk of severe hemorrhage, necessitating a cesarean section for safe delivery.

questions.text: A man complains of difficulty in standing up from a sitting position and scissoring gait was observed in him. Which nerve is damaged in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

 

The obturator nerve innervates the adductor muscles of the thigh, such as the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis muscles. These muscles are responsible for adducting the thigh (bringing it closer to the body's midline). When the obturator nerve is involved, adductor muscles of thigh are getting spasm , which can lead to a scissoring gait, where the legs cross over each other during walking. Additionally, patients may find it difficult to stabilize their lower limbs, which causes problems like standing up from a sitting position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior gluteal nerve: Damage to this nerve typically causes a Trendelenburg gait, characterized by difficulty maintaining pelvic stability, rather than a scissoring gait.

 

Option B. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus, which is primarily involved in hip extension. Damage here would cause difficulty in rising from a sitting position but does not typically cause a scissoring gait.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. Damage to the femoral nerve would cause difficulty in extending the knee but does not explain the scissoring gait pattern.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Involvement of obturator nerve may lead to spam of adductor muscles, causing a scissoring gait and difficulty rising from a sitting position due to the impaired function of the adductor muscles.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensory aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms suggest that he is experiencing a type of aphasia where comprehension is impaired, but speech remains fluent. This is characteristic of sensory aphasia (also known as receptive aphasia or fluent aphasia).

 

  • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia): Patients with Wernicke's aphasia can speak fluently but their speech often lacks meaning and they have significant difficulty understanding spoken language. They may produce nonsensical and made-up words. This type of aphasia is typically due to a lesion in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area).

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Motor aphasia (Broca's aphasia): This is a non-fluent aphasia where patients have good comprehension but struggle to produce speech. Speech is typically halting and effortful, and patients may be able to produce only short phrases. This is not consistent with the fluent speech described in the case.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Patients with anomic aphasia primarily have difficulty naming objects but otherwise have intact comprehension and fluency. This does not align with the patient’s production of nonsensical words.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This type is characterized by good comprehension and fluent speech, but patients have significant difficulty with repetition. The primary issue in conduction aphasia is the disconnection between comprehension and speech production areas, typically due to damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This does not fully explain the nonsensical speech observed in the patient.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Sensory aphasia, also known as Wernicke's aphasia, is characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension, fitting the described symptoms in this patient.

questions.text: A patient had fever, cough and hilar lymph node enlargement. He also had hypercalcemia and has been diagnosed with sarcoidosis. Which of the following is the likely finding in his lung biopsy? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non caseating granuloma

 

Sarcoidosis is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas, which are clusters of macrophages and giant cells without central necrosis. This is a key histological feature of sarcoidosis and helps distinguish it from other granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis, which typically presents with caseating granulomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caseating granuloma: Typically seen in infections like tuberculosis, where granulomas have a central area of necrosis.

 

Option C. Neutrophilic infiltration: More characteristic of acute bacterial infections or conditions with prominent neutrophil involvement, such as acute pneumonia.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis: Seen in certain types of vasculitis and severe inflammatory conditions, characterized by the presence of fibrin-like material within the walls of affected blood vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark histological finding in sarcoidosis is the presence of non-caseating granulomas in affected tissues.

questions.text: All the following side effects of lithium, likely to occur after 1 year of treatment except- (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tardive Dyskinesia

 

Lithium, a commonly used mood stabilizer, is associated with several side effects that may occur after prolonged treatment. However, tardive dyskinesia is not a typical side effect of lithium.

 

Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, usually of the face and tongue. It is more commonly associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications, particularly first-generation antipsychotics, and not with lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tremors are a common side effect of lithium that may occur after prolonged treatment.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism is a well-known side effect of lithium, which can develop after an extended period of treatment.

 

Option D. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is another potential side effect of lithium that may manifest after a year of treatment. Lithium can affect the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine, leading to excessive thirst and urination (polyuria).

 

Educational Objective:

 

While tremors, hypothyroidism, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are potential side effects of lithium that may occur after a year of treatment, tardive dyskinesia is typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications.

questions.text: MC direct cause of Maternal mortality is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post partum haemorrhage

 

Maternal mortality refers to the death of a mother during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days after delivery.

 

The causes of maternal mortality can be categorized into direct and indirect causes.

 

Among the direct causes, post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is the most common cause of maternal mortality in India. Other direct causes are obstructed labor and sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: Incorrect. As Anemia is the most common indirect cause of maternal mortality in India.

 

Option C. Obstructed labor: Incorrect. Although obstructed labor is a direct cause of maternal mortality, it is not as common as post-partum hemorrhage in India.

 

Option D. Sepsis: Incorrect. Sepsis is another direct cause of maternal mortality, but it is not as prevalent as post-partum hemorrhage in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-partum hemorrhage is the most common direct cause and anemia is the MC indirect cause of the maternal mortality in India, and PPH is also the overall leading cause of maternal deaths in the country.

 

India MMR (SRS 2023) – 97 per 1 lakh live births

questions.text: At the 5th postnatal day, a woman presents with sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Postpartum blues

 

Explanation:

 

Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," typically occur within the first few days after delivery and can last up to two weeks. It is characterized by mood swings, sadness, irritability, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping. These symptoms are usually mild and self-limiting, resolving on their own with support and reassurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum depression: This condition occurs after the first two weeks post-delivery and can persist for months. It includes more severe symptoms such as persistent sadness, lack of interest in the baby, feelings of hopelessness, and possibly suicidal thoughts.

 

Option C. Postpartum anxiety: This condition involves excessive worry, anxiety, and often includes physical symptoms like palpitations or hyperventilation. It can occur at any time during the postpartum period.

 

Option D. Postpartum psychosis: This is a rare but severe condition that usually occurs within the first few weeks after delivery. It involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, severe agitation, and risk of harm to the mother or baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum blues are common in the first few days after delivery and are characterized by sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep. The condition is generally mild and self-limiting, resolving with support and care.

questions.text: As per Nutrition Guidelines of India, a 55 kg woman needs how many grams of proteins? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45 grams

 

Explanation:

 

According to the nutrition guidelines of India, the protein requirement for adults is based on body weight.

 

The recommended daily protein intake is 0.83 grams per kilogram of body weight. For an adult reference Indian woman weighing 55 kg, this translates to approximately 45 grams of protein per day (0.83 grams/kg/day x 55 kg = 45.65 grams/day, rounded to 45 grams).

 

Additional Information –

 

The recommended daily energy intake: [NEW GUIDELINES 2021-22]

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 55 kg woman requires approximately 45 grams of protein per day according to the nutrition guidelines of India.

questions.text: No of live births per 1000 women in reproductive age group is?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) General fertility rate

 

Explanation:

 

The general fertility rate is defined as the total number of live births in a community in a year divided by the total number of women in the reproductive age group (usually 15-49 years) per 1,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total fertility rate (TFR): Incorrect. TFR refers to the total number of children born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan.

 

Option C. Age specific fertility rate (ASFR): Incorrect. Age-specific fertility rate is the fertility rate calculated for a given age interval, usually 5 years, per 1,000 mid-year population.

 

Option D. Gross reproduction rate: Incorrect. Gross reproduction rate (GRR) is the total number of girl children born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan at current ASFRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The general fertility rate is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group (usually 15-49 years) in a given year.

 

Note - Net reproduction rate (NRR): Expected number of daughters, per newborn prospective mother, who may or may not survive to and through the ages of childbearing.

questions.text: A patient has a field defect where he cannot see the left side from the left eye and the left side from the right eye, that is from both the eyes the patient is not able to look towards the left, with preserved central vision. What is the field defect?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Explanation:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is a type of visual field defect where the patient cannot see the same side of the visual field in both eyes, but central vision is preserved.

 

This condition typically indicates a lesion in the occipital lobe, specifically on the side opposite to the visual field loss. In this case, the patient cannot see the left side from both eyes, which means the lesion is in the right occipital lobe. The occipital lobe processes visual information, and a lesion here can result in loss of vision in the corresponding visual field of both eyes.

 

Macular sparing occurs because the macular region of the occipital cortex has a dual blood supply from both the middle cerebral artery and the posterior cerebral artery, providing some redundancy that preserves central vision even when other parts of the occipital lobe are damaged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quadrantanopia: This refers to the loss of vision in one quadrant (one-fourth) of the visual field. It is not consistent with the described field defect involving half of the visual field.

 

Option C. Homonymous hemianopia: This is the loss of the same half of the visual field in both eyes without the specification of macular sparing. The inclusion of macular sparing helps to localize the lesion more specifically to the occipital lobe.

 

Option D. Bitemporal hemianopia: This is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes, typically due to a lesion at the optic chiasm. It does not fit the description where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing indicates a lesion in the occipital lobe on the side opposite to the visual field.

questions.text: A child with Celiac disease can be given: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rice


Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, rye, and oats (referred to by the mnemonic "BROW"). Individuals with celiac disease must strictly avoid these grains and any foods containing gluten.

 

Rice is naturally gluten-free and is safe for individuals with celiac disease. It is a staple food that can be consumed without concern for gluten contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sooji: Sooji, also known as semolina, is made from wheat and contains gluten, making it unsuitable for someone with celiac disease.

 

Option C. Oat: Oats can be contaminated with gluten during processing, and even gluten-free oats might not be well tolerated by all individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, oats are generally avoided unless they are certified gluten-free and tolerated by the patient.

 

Option D. Broken wheat/daliya: Broken wheat, also known as daliya, is another form of wheat and contains gluten, making it unsuitable for individuals with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:


Celiac patients must avoid gluten-containing grains like barley, rye, oats, and wheat (BROW). Rice is a safe and gluten-free option for these patients.

questions.text: A patient has a painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone. X-ray done is shown below. What seems to be the most probable diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondromas are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms and are thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by progressive endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap.
  • In contrast to true neoplasms, their growth usually parallels that of the patient and usually ceases when skeletal maturity is reached.
  • Most lesions are found during the period of rapid skeletal growth.
  • About 90% of patients have only a single lesion.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Some cause pain by Bursitis of overlying bursa (most common cause of pain), fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighboring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc.
  • The physical finding usually is a palpable mass.
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad-based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common, and any definite stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin.
  • The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with corresponding components of the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap that often is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs. Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen. They usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • Plain radiographs usually are sufficient to make a diagnosis. It looks smaller than it feels because the cartilage cap is not seen on X-ray.
  • CT or MRI sometimes is needed to confirm the diagnosis.
  • The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place it usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis; however, only seen in about 25% of patients. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. MRI is the best to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures. A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases as the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. Elderly with bone pains, increased ESR and hypercalcemia is multiple myeloma till proved otherwise. Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignancy of bone, representing more than 40% of primary bone cancers. Its peak incidence is in the fifth to seventh decades with a 2:1 male predominance. Bone pain is the most common complaint. Other systemic problems, such as weakness, weight loss, anemia, thrombocytopenia, peripheral neuropathy, hypercalcemia, or renal failure, frequently are present. Symptoms usually are of short duration because of the aggressive nature of the disease. Pathological fractures are relatively common. The spine is the most common location followed by the ribs and pelvis. Radiographically, it appears as multiple, “punched-out”, sharply demarcated, purely lytic lesions without any surrounding reactive sclerosis. The lack of reactive bone formation also is seen as most lesions are negative on bone scan. Occasionally, biopsy of the bone lesion is required to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor, exceeded in incidence only by osteochondroma and non-ossifying fibroma. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus. CT scan is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone is seen in osteochondroma which is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm.
  • It originates from the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule.
  • Most of these lesions cause no symptoms and are incidental findings.

questions.text: Identify this instrument: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verres needle

 

Explanation:

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Verres needle, which is commonly used in laparoscopic surgeries to create pneumoperitoneum. Pneumoperitoneum is the introduction of gas, typically carbon dioxide, into the peritoneal cavity. This step is crucial as it provides the necessary space for the surgeon to visualize and operate within the abdomen.

 

The Verres needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity, and once its correct placement is confirmed, carbon dioxide is introduced through the needle to inflate the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leech Wilkinson cannula: This is not typically used for creating pneumoperitoneum.

 

 

Option C. Laparoscope: This is an instrument used for visual inspection of the abdominal cavity but is introduced after pneumoperitoneum is established.

 

 

Option D. Trocar and cannula: These are used for the insertion of various instruments into the abdomen during laparoscopic surgery, but the creation of pneumoperitoneum is done first using the Verres needle.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Verres needle is essential for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries, allowing for the necessary space for safe and effective surgical procedures within the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: A recently married couple visit the antenatal clinic on getting the news that the lady is expecting.  On investigation both the husband and wife were detected to be suffering from beta thalassemia trait. Which of the following is the chance of their baby suffering from thalassemia major? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25%

 

Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive condition and so, the chances of having a progeny with thalassemia major is 25%  if there is a marriage between 2 people with thalassemia  trait.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When both parents are carriers of the beta thalassemia trait, there is a 25% chance that their child will inherit thalassemia major.

questions.text: A patient has had his molar teeth extracted, following which he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lingual nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The innervation of the tongue is divided into three parts: anterior two-thirds, posterior one-third, and posterior most part.

 

The anterior two-thirds of the tongue is derived from the first pharyngeal arch, innervated by the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, supplies general sensation (pain, temperature, and touch) to this part of the tongue. However, taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).

 

The posterior one-third of the tongue is derived from the third pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which carries both general and taste sensation.

 

The posterior most part of the tongue is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X), which carries both general and taste sensation.

 

Tongue development:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. The glossopharyngeal nerve innervates the posterior one-third of the tongue, not the anterior two-thirds.

 

Option B. Hypoglossal nerve: Incorrect. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to the tongue muscles and does not carry sensory fibers.

 

Option C. Inferior alveolar nerve: Incorrect. The inferior alveolar nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve that supplies the lower teeth, gingiva, and lower lip, but not the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (trigeminal nerve), supplies general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.text: A patient present with complaints of sudden and irresistible urges to take an action, this is characteristic of which symptom? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impulse

 

An impulse is characterized by a sudden and irresistible urge to perform an action. In this case, the patient experiences sudden and irresistible urges to take an action, which is a hallmark feature of an impulse.

 

Impulses are often seen in impulse control disorders such as –

 

  • Trichotillomania (an irresistible urge to pull out one's hair)
  • Pyromania (an impulse to set things on fire).

 

In these disorders, the individual experiences a strong, sudden urge to perform a specific action. They may try to resist the urge, but it continues to grow, causing significant discomfort until they finally give in to the impulse and perform the action, which may provide temporary relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hallucination: Is a perception in the absence of an external stimulus, which is not related to the sudden and irresistible urges described in the question.

 

Option C. Delusion: Is a fixed, false belief that is not in keeping with the person's cultural or religious background and is firmly held despite evidence to the contrary. It does not involve sudden, irresistible urges to take an action.

 

Option D. Pseudohallucinations: Are hallucinations that the person recognizes as unreal, which is not the same as the sudden, irresistible urges mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An impulse is characterized by a sudden and irresistible urge to perform an action.

questions.text: A dead body is recovered from a river. The body has signs of antemortem drowning and also has multiple wounds as shown below. What can be the cause of these wounds? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Self-inflicted

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows multiple superficial, parallel incised wounds on the forearm, which are characteristic of hesitation marks. Hesitation marks are typically seen in cases of suicide attempts where the individual makes multiple superficial cuts while hesitating to make a final, deeper cut.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Active self-defense wound: Incorrect because active self-defense wounds are found on the front of the hands and forearms and usually involve a struggle, not multiple, superficial, parallel cuts.

 

Option C. Postmortem artifact: Incorrect because postmortem artifacts do not present as multiple, organized, parallel incised wounds.

 

Option D. Passive self-defense wound: Incorrect because passive self-defense wounds are found on the back of the hands and forearms and are typically blunt force injuries, not superficial cuts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key points to understand about the different types of wounds:

questions.text: Skull of a dead person was found during investigation. Police asked the relatives to bring the photo of deceased. Which of the following method can be used for identification of dead body? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superimposition

 

Explanation

 

In forensic investigations, when a skull is found and relatives are asked to bring a photo of the deceased, the technique used for identification is superimposition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalic Index: Incorrect because it only helps determine racial or ethnic group, not individual identification.

 

Option B. Dactylography: Incorrect as fingerprint analysis requires fingerprints, which are not available with just a skull.

 

Option D. DNA fingerprinting: Incorrect because the question specifies the use of a photo, which is not used in DNA analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superimposition is the method used for identification when a skull is found and a photograph of the deceased is available. It involves overlapping the skull photo with the photo of the person to establish identity.

questions.text: What are the yoke muscles for levodepression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) R SO and LIR

 

In ocular motility, yoke muscles are pairs of muscles from each eye that work together to move the eyes in the same direction. For levodepression, which is movement of the eyes to the left and downward, the yoke muscles involved are the right superior oblique (R SO) and the left inferior rectus (LIR).

 

When the eye moves to the left (levoversion), the left eye’s inferior rectus muscle depresses the eye, while the right eye’s superior oblique muscle assists in depressing the right eye. This coordinated action ensures both eyes move together smoothly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. R LR and LMR: These are the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles, responsible for horizontal eye movements, not depression.

 

Option B. R SR and LIR: The right superior rectus is an elevator of the right eye, not a depressor.

 

Option D. R IO and LSO: The right inferior oblique elevates the right eye, and the left superior oblique depresses the left eye, which does not fit the movement described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The yoke muscles responsible for levodepression (movement of the eyes to the left and downward) are the right superior oblique and the left inferior rectus.

questions.text: Identify the sign and the tendon ruptured in the image given below: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proximal biceps tendon rupture

 

PROXIMAL BICEPS TENDON RUPTURE

 

  • The biceps brachii muscle has two heads, one originating from the coracoid process (short head) and the other from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula and superior labrum (long head).
  • The distal biceps tendon attaches to the bicipital tuberosity of the radius.
  • The biceps tendon is a strong supinator of the forearm and serves as a weak elbow flexor.
  • The long head (proximal biceps tendon) contributes to the stability of the glenohumeral joint. The majority of biceps rupture involves the long head.
  • Etiology:
    • Proximal biceps rupture is generally not due to a unique mechanism of injury but is highly correlated with rotator cuff disease.
    • Risk factors include age, smoking, obesity, use of corticosteroids, and overuse.
    • Rare causes include the use of quinolones, diabetes, lupus, and chronic kidney disease.
       
  • Epidemiology:
    • Proximal biceps rupture is commonly seen in older patients, and its exact incidence is unknown, but it is more common than distal biceps rupture in older patients.
       
  • Pathophysiology
    • The proximal tendon rupture, in most cases, occurs at the tendon-labral junction or the bony attachment.
       
  • Clinical features:
    • Patients may complain of sudden sharp pain in the elbow or shoulder, depending on the site of the rupture.
    • Usually, there is a history of sudden eccentric force to a flexed elbow. They may feel an audible "pop" in the affected arm at the time of the injury.
    • Pain can persist for weeks to months.
    • Pain may diminish if the tendon is completely torn.
    • Patients usually complain of bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly, known as "Popeye deformity." In obese individuals, it is generally hard to appreciate this popeye deformity.

 

  • Proximal biceps rupture does not result in any long-term change in the elbow or shoulder strength.
  • It is important to check for atrophy of the shoulder girdle muscle and shoulder impingement because proximal biceps tendon disorders are usually associated with rotator cuff pathology.
     
  • Evaluation:
    • Diagnosis is often clinically made, while imaging is helpful when the diagnosis is unclear or partial rupture is considered.
    • Three criteria are described for diagnosis:
      1. History of a single traumatic event. The patient will report a sudden, painful pop while the elbow is eccentrically loaded from flexion to extension. e.g., while doing a biceps curl.
      2. Grossly palpable and visible signs of retraction of the biceps muscle belly (reverse popeye deformity).
      3. Weakness of elbow flexion and supination of the forearm in cases of distal biceps rupture.
         
  • Treatment:
    • Non-surgical treatment is usually sufficient for proximal tendon rupture, as it is more common in elderly patients. However, residual cosmetic deformity and some intermittent biceps muscle cramping may persist.
    • Younger patients and female patients who are unwilling to accept cosmetic deformities and athletic patients with frequent cramping may opt for surgical intervention in the form of biceps tenodesis.
    • The presence of associated rotator cuff pathology can also influence surgical management.
    • Subpectoral tenodesis is the preferred approach for biceps tenodesis, where the tendon is attached to the bone in the bicipital groove. Sometimes this procedure is done concurrently with arthroscopic rotator cuff pathology treatment. Implants like interference screws and bio-absorbable suture anchors can be placed either through the open or arthroscopic approach to secure the tendon in the subpectoral space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Distal biceps tendon rupture. The distal biceps tendon inserts onto the ulnar aspect of the bicipital tuberosity (also called radial tuberosity). The likely pathophysiological mechanism predisposing the distal biceps to rupture is a compromised zone of hypovascularity due to watershed zone of arterial blood supply and reduced distance between the upper parts of radius and the ulna during pronation. An aching sensation in the anterior elbow is seen in 10% of the patients. Majority of the patients with a full thickness distal biceps rupture reports a painful “pop” sensation. Anterior elbow pain, anterior arm and elbow swelling and weakness of elbow flexion and forearm supination are commonly reported symptoms. Activities such as operating a manual screw driver or opening jars are difficult to perform by involved arm. In a torn distal biceps, there would be anterior ecchymosis, swelling and a prominent biceps bulge at the anterior mid-arm level (Popeye the sailor sign).

 

 

Option C. Triceps tendon rupture. Triceps Ruptures are rare injuries to the elbow extensor mechanism that most commonly occurs as a result of a sudden forceful elbow contraction in weightlifters or older males with underlying systemic illness. Patients tend to be men who practice sports and are from 30 to 50 years of age. The triceps lesions are characterised by pain or tenderness and a palpable defect in the tendon, seen proximal to the olecranon. The patient describes an unexpected “pop” or giving way, with subsequent pain and weakness in the extremity. A complete triceps rupture can be expected when the patient is unable to extend his arm against gravity. A palpable defect is not always present, but sometimes can be found in the posterior arm. Swelling and echymosis are other nonspecific findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deformity shown in the given image in the question is seen in proximal biceps tendon rupture and is called Popeye deformity.

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with cola colored urine, his mother gives history of odynophagia, dysphagia, fever, and membrane over tonsils as given in image. Which among the following is likely cause?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Streptococcal Tonsillitis

 

Explanation:

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis is characterized by a tenacious exudate that forms a membrane over the tonsils. The image shows a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, which is typical for streptococcal tonsillitis. This condition can present with symptoms such as fever, odynophagia (painful swallowing), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and cola-colored urine (a sign of possible post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Faucial diphtheria: Presents with a thick, grayish membrane that bleeds when removed. It is typically accompanied by significant cervical lymphadenopathy and neck swelling, which is not described in the case.

 

 

Option B. Vincent angina: Also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, is associated with ulcerations and necrotic areas rather than forming a thick membrane over the tonsils. The description and image do not match this presentation.

 

 

Option D. Oral Candidiasis: Generally presents with widespread white plaques that can be scraped off, revealing red, inflamed tissue underneath. The membrane shown in the image is more localized to the tonsils, which is more characteristic of streptococcal tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis can present with a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, accompanied by fever, painful swallowing, and potential complications such as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, indicated by cola-colored urine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a hospital with symptoms including persistent sadness, loss of interest in activities, difficulty sleeping, and poor appetite that have been ongoing for several months. After being diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD) by a psychiatrist, which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoxetine

 

Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is the most appropriate initial treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD). SSRIs like fluoxetine are typically first-line treatments for MDD due to their efficacy and favourable side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: An antipsychotic medication used primarily for schizophrenia and acute psychotic states, not as a first-line treatment for MDD.

 

Option C. Lithium: Commonly used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, not typically as a first-line treatment for MDD.

 

Option D. Buspirone: An anxiolytic used for generalized anxiety disorder, less effective as a primary treatment for MDD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is the most appropriate initial treatment for major depressive disorder due to its efficacy and favorable side effect profile in improving mood, sleep, and appetite.

questions.text: What type of deposition is typically observed in patients with dialysis-related amyloidosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta 2 microglobulin

 

Explanation:

 

Dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA) occurs in patients who have been on long-term hemodialysis.

 

The primary protein responsible for amyloid deposits in DRA is beta 2 microglobulin. This protein tends to accumulate in patients undergoing chronic hemodialysis because it is not efficiently removed by dialysis filters.

 

The deposition of beta 2 microglobulin can lead to various musculoskeletal complications, including:

 

  • Arthritis: Particularly common in the shoulder joint, referred to as "shoulder arthropathy."
  • Tenosynovitis: Inflammation of the tendon sheath.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome: Compression of the median nerve in the wrist, leading to pain, numbness, and weakness in the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amyloid beta: This type of amyloid is primarily associated with Alzheimer's disease and is not related to dialysis.

 

Option B. Beta 1 macroglobulin: This is not related to dialysis-related amyloidosis.

 

Option D. Transthyretin: This protein can cause amyloidosis but is associated with other forms, such as senile systemic amyloidosis (wild-type transthyretin) and familial transthyretin amyloidosis (mutated transthyretin), which typically affect the heart and nervous system rather than causing musculoskeletal issues.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Dialysis-related amyloidosis is primarily caused by the accumulation of beta 2 microglobulin, leading to musculoskeletal complications such as arthritis, tenosynovitis, and carpal tunnel syndrome.

choices.text: Inhibition of ATP synthesis by mycobacteria
Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria
Inhibition of RNA polymerase in mycobacteria
Inhibition of protein synthesis in mycobacteria

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of bedaquiline, a new drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB)? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibition of ATP synthesis by mycobacteria

 

Bedaquiline works by inhibiting ATP (adenosine triphosphate) synthase in mycobacteria. By disrupting the production of ATP, an essential energy molecule, bedaquiline effectively hinders the growth and survival of the tuberculosis bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria: Drugs like isoniazid. pretomanid and delamanid work by this mechanism.

 

Option C. Inhibition of RNA polymerase in mycobacteria: Rifampicin is an example of a drug that inhibits RNA polymerase in mycobacteria.

 

Option D. Inhibition of protein synthesis in mycobacteria: Streptomycin, amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin work by inhibiting protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline treats multidrug-resistant tuberculosis by inhibiting ATP synthase in mycobacteria, thereby disrupting the production of ATP and hindering the bacteria's growth and survival.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for urinary incontinence following a hysterectomy. In the 3-swab test, the middle swab is stained with dye. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vesico-vaginal fistula

 

Explanation:

 

The 3-swab test is used to diagnose the presence and location of a fistula between the urinary tract and the genital tract following a hysterectomy.

 

 

3-swab Test:

 

  1. Three dry swabs are placed in the vagina:
    • Swab 1: Upper vagina
    • Swab 2: Middle vagina
    • Swab 3: Lower vagina
  2. Methylene blue dye is then injected into the bladder through a urinary catheter.
  3. After waiting for 5-10 minutes, the swabs are removed and examined for staining and wetness:
    • If the upper swab is wet but not stained with dye, it suggests a uretero-vaginal fistula since urine from the ureter is leaking into the vagina without dye.
    • If the middle swab is wet and stained with blue dye, it indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula because the dye from the bladder is leaking directly into the vagina through the fistula.
    • If the lower swab is stained and wet, it indicates a urethro-vaginal fistula.

 

In this case, the middle swab being stained with dye indicates that the fistula is between the bladder (vesica) and the vagina, confirming a vesico-vaginal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uretero-vaginal fistula: The upper swab would be wet but not stained with dye.

 

Option C. Utero-vaginal fistula: This is not relevant post-hysterectomy as the uterus has been removed.

 

Option D. Urethro-vaginal fistula: The lower swab would be stained and wet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive 3-swab test with the middle swab stained with dye indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula, which is a common complication following a hysterectomy where the bladder and vagina are abnormally connected.

 

Note – the best IOC in this case is – CT Urography

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with dysphagia to solids, weight loss and regurgitation. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca Esophagus

 

In this case, an elderly patient presents with dysphagia to solids, weight loss, and regurgitation, which are classic signs of carcinoma esophagus (Ca esophagus). Carcinoma esophagus is often suspected in elderly patients, especially smokers, presenting with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsion diverticulum: This is incorrect because pulsion diverticulum, such as Zenker's diverticulum, often presents with symptoms like halitosis and regurgitation but typically does not cause significant weight loss or dysphagia to solids specifically in the elderly.

 

Option B. Achalasia Cardia: This is incorrect because achalasia usually presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, and it is more common in younger, non-smoker females. The presence of weight loss and the elderly age group make achalasia less likely.

 

Option D. GERD: This is incorrect because gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) generally causes symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation but does not typically cause significant weight loss or progressive dysphagia to solids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly smoker presenting with dysphagia to solids, weight loss, and regurgitation, Ca esophagus should be considered as the probable diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-eclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

Maternal deaths can be classified into direct and indirect causes. Direct causes are those that result from complications of pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period, whereas indirect causes are conditions that are exacerbated by pregnancy.

 

Pre-eclampsia: This is a direct cause of maternal death. Pre-eclampsia is a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy that can lead to severe complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, stroke, and organ failure, all of which can directly result in maternal mortality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: This is considered an indirect cause of maternal death. While severe anemia can exacerbate complications during pregnancy and childbirth, it is not a direct cause but increases the risk of infections, hemorrhage, and other complications.

 

Option B. Heart disease: This is also an indirect cause of maternal death. Pre-existing heart disease can worsen during pregnancy due to the increased cardiovascular demands, but it is not a complication arising directly from pregnancy.

 

Option C. Embolism: Pulmonary embolism is considered an indirect cause of maternal death when it occurs due to pregnancy-related factors like deep vein thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, directly associated with complications arising from pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Common intermittent source epidemic

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows cases occurring at irregular intervals with gaps between them, indicating that people are exposed intermittently to the source of infection. This pattern is characteristic of a common intermittent source epidemic, where exposures occur sporadically, leading to multiple peaks over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic: Characterized by a sudden rise and fall in the number of cases within a single incubation period, showing a single peak.

 

 

Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic: Shows multiple peaks due to repeated exposures, but the rise and fall are not as sudden and are marked by secondary waves.

 

 

Options C. Propagated epidemic: Involves person-to-person transmission, typically showing a slow rise, a plateau, and a slow fall in the number of cases over time.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A common intermittent source epidemic is marked by cases appearing at irregular intervals, reflecting intermittent exposures to the source of infection.

questions.text: A person presents in ENT OPD having nasal blockage with crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia. On examination, nose is hard, and biopsy reveals following histopathological findings. What is the likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of nasal blockage, crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia, along with the finding of a hard nose and the specific histopathological findings in the biopsy (such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies), are indicative of rhinoscleroma caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition that leads to the hardening of the nasal tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinosporidium seeberi: This condition would show sporangia containing endospores on histopathology, which is not seen in this case.

 

 

Option B. Klebsiella ozaenae: Typically causes atrophic rhinitis characterized by foul-smelling discharge and crusting, but it does not cause a hard nose or the specific histopathological findings seen here.

 

 

Option D. Autoimmunity: Autoimmune conditions can cause nasal symptoms but are not characterized by the specific histopathological findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presents with a hard nose, nasal blockage, crusting, foul-smelling discharge, and specific histopathological findings such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of discomfort, pain, and a sensation of pressure behind her left eye. She has intermittent proptosis that is reducible. Her symptoms and signs are accentuated when she bends forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital varices

 

Explanation:

 

Orbital varices are dilated venous channels in the orbit that can cause intermittent proptosis, which becomes more pronounced with maneuvers that increase venous pressure such as bending forward, straining, or performing a Valsalva maneuver. This intermittent and reducible nature of the proptosis is a key feature distinguishing orbital varices from other conditions.

 

Additional Information –

 

Three types of vascular malformations of the orbit:

 

Type 1 Vascular Malformation (Lymphangioma of the Orbit): This is characterized by no flow and is specifically referred to as lymphangioma of the orbit.

 

Type 2 Vascular Malformation (Orbital Varices): These are identified by having venous flow. Orbital varices typically result in intermittent proptosis, which is particularly exacerbated when the patient is straining, such as during violent coughing, Valsalva maneuvers, or bending forward.

 

Type 3 Vascular Malformation (Arterial or Arteriovenous Flow): This type involves arterial or arteriovenous flow, with orbital arteriovenous (AV) malformations being a classic example.

 

Among these, orbital varices (Type 2) are unique, as they cause intermittent proptosis exacerbated by specific physical maneuvers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital hemangioma: This is the most common benign tumor of the orbit in adults but does not typically cause intermittent proptosis.

 

Option C. Orbital metastasis: Can cause proptosis but typically presents with persistent proptosis and often with associated signs like eyelid ecchymosis.

 

Option D. Orbital dermoid cyst: Can cause proptosis, but it is usually not intermittent and reducible as described in this case.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Intermittent and reducible proptosis, accentuated by straining or bending forward, is characteristic of orbital varices.

questions.text: Graph of cooling of the body? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sigmoid shaped

 

The cooling of the body after death follows a typical pattern. Initially, there is little to no decrease in temperature for the first hour. After this period, the body temperature decreases steadily until it stabilizes, generally around 20 hours post-mortem. This pattern creates a curve that resembles an inverted "S" shape, which is also known as a sigmoid shape. Both S-shaped and inverted S-shaped curves are referred to as sigmoid shapes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted sigmoid shaped: This is a misnomer. The correct term for the cooling pattern is sigmoid shaped, which encompasses both the regular and inverted S shapes.

 

Option C. Parabola: This does not accurately describe the cooling curve of the body.

 

Option D. S shaped: While the curve may resemble an S shape in some interpretations, the term sigmoid shaped is more accurate and preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The graph of cooling of the body is best described as sigmoid shaped, indicating the initial slow cooling followed by a steady decrease and stabilization of temperature. ​​

questions.text: A patient presented with dermatitis and loss of appetite. He also gives a frequent history of diarrhoea. On examination, alopecia also seen and patient has observed that he has delayed wound healing. This patient is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc

 

Zinc deficiency can cause a range of symptoms, including dermatitis, alopecia, loss of appetite, impaired immune function leading to frequent infections, and poor wound healing. Zinc is crucial for skin health, immune function, and overall protein synthesis, explaining the diverse symptoms including skin issues and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: While Vitamin C deficiency, known as scurvy, can lead to poor wound healing and gum bleeding, it does not typically cause dermatitis or alopecia. The primary features of scurvy are related to its role in collagen synthesis, including skin bruising, bleeding gums, and joint pain.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Deficiency in Vitamin D commonly leads to bone-related problems like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. It does not typically present with dermatitis, alopecia, or gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "three Ds": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia. While some symptoms overlap, such as dermatitis and diarrhea, pellagra is typically associated with neurological symptoms and doesn't usually include alopecia or delayed wound healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms described, including dermatitis, loss of appetite, diarrhea, alopecia, and delayed wound healing, are consistent with a disease known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica due to zinc deficiency. Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including immune function, wound healing, and maintenance of skin and hair. Symptoms of this disease are:

 

  • Simultaneous diarrhoea + dermatitis
  • Inflammation around nose, mouth, anus, cheeks, elbow etc.
  • It also occurs in some infants after weaning from breast milk as breast milk has picolinic acid (piconilic acid increases Zn absorption from intestine)           

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 414

questions.text: Diarrhoea by cholera toxin involves which receptors:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

Cholera toxin binds specifically to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding is the initial step in the pathogenesis of cholera. The toxin's B subunits bind to GM1 gangliosides, facilitating the entry of the A subunit into the cells. The A subunit then activates adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels and subsequent chloride and water secretion, causing diarrhea.


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GD-1b Ganglioside Receptor: The GD-1b ganglioside receptor is not the target for cholera toxin. This receptor has other physiological roles in the body and is not primarily associated with the mechanism of cholera toxin-induced diarrhea.

 

Option C. GM2 Ganglioside Receptor: GM2 ganglioside receptors are not involved in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin. They have different functions and are not known to interact with cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of diarrhea.

 

Option D. GM3 Ganglioside Receptor: While GM3 ganglioside is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor that cholera toxin binds to. The specific interaction between cholera toxin and GM1 gangliosides is critical for the toxin's effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding of cholera toxin to GM1 facilitates its entry into the cells, where it exerts its toxic effects by activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). Elevated cAMP levels lead to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl lately having poor scholastic performance. She complains of hearing loss for which she was brought to the clinic by her parents. She breathes with her mouth and has a low tone voice. The X-ray has been performed. On audiometry, 30dB of Bilateral CHL is diagnosed. What could be the best treatment for her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Explanation: 

 

The girl presents with symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy, including mouth breathing, low tone voice, and poor scholastic performance.

 

The lateral view X-ray shows soft tissue opacification in the nasopharynx, indicative of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

The audiometry results show bilateral conductive hearing loss (CHL) at 30dB, likely due to eustachian tube blockage and serous otitis media caused by the enlarged adenoids.

 

The best treatment for this condition is adenoidectomy to remove the hypertrophied adenoids and grommet insertion to drain the middle ear fluid and alleviate the conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy with Myringotomy: While adenoidectomy addresses the root cause, myringotomy without grommet insertion may not adequately resolve the middle ear fluid and could lead to recurrent effusions.

 

Option B. Bone anchored hearing aid: This option is typically used for specific types of hearing loss and is not the first-line treatment for conductive hearing loss caused by adenoid hypertrophy and associated otitis media.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: This addresses the middle ear effusion but does not treat the underlying cause of the adenoid hypertrophy, which would likely result in recurrent issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of adenoidectomy and grommet insertion effectively addresses both the cause (adenoid hypertrophy) and the symptom (middle ear effusion), providing a comprehensive treatment for bilateral conductive hearing loss in children.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents in the ENT OPD with complaints of pain and discharge from the ear. Examination reveals the following findings. What is the best line of treatment? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clotrimazole ear drops

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with pain and discharge from the ear, and the examination shows black-headed filamentous growths on the otoendoscopic picture. This indicates a fungal infection, specifically otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger. The best treatment for otomycosis is an antifungal agent.

 

Clotrimazole an antifungal and is typically used to treat otomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops: Not an antifungal drug.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic and is used to treat bacterial infections. It does not have antifungal properties.

 

Option D. Wax softening ear drops: Wax softening ear drops contain ingredients like paradichlorobenzene, chlorbutol, and turpentine oil, which are used to soften ear wax. This treatment is irrelevant in the context of a fungal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otomycosis, a fungal infection of the ear, caused by Aspergillus niger, should be treated with antifungal agents like Clotrimazole ear drops.

questions.text: What type of particles does a linear accelerator use? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) X rays

 

  • This is the correct answer. Linear accelerators use high-energy X rays to treat cancer. The X rays are generated by accelerating electrons and colliding them with a metal target. The resulting high-energy photons are directed to conform to a tumor’s shape, minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue.
  • A linear accelerator primarily uses X rays for therapeutic purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutron: Neutrons are neutral particles that do not have an electrical charge. They are typically used in neutron therapy, a specialized and less common form of radiotherapy that targets certain types of cancer.

 

Option B. Proton: Proton therapy is another form of radiation therapy that uses protons rather than X rays. It is highly precise and is used to treat specific types of cancers, especially in sensitive or hard-to-reach areas.

 

Option D. Gamma Rays: These are typically not used in linear accelerators. Gamma rays are similar to X rays but originate from the nucleus of an atom. They are used in other types of radiation treatments, such as those involving radioactive isotopes in brachytherapy or stereotactic radiosurgery.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Linear accelerators are crucial in modern oncology, allowing high precision in targeting tumors while sparing healthy tissue, using high-energy X rays derived from accelerated electrons.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents with altered sensorium and unsteady gait. Vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this case would be (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B1

 

Chronic alcoholism often leads to a deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine). This deficiency is associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff Psychosis, which presents with symptoms such as altered sensorium, unsteady gait, and other neurological impairments. Thiamine is crucial for glucose metabolism and proper functioning of the nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by gum bleeding, delayed wound healing, and bone pain.

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Deficiency causes night blindness and xerophthalmia.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Deficiency results in rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, characterized by bone pain and muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency in chronic alcoholics can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, presenting with neurological symptoms such as altered sensorium and unsteady gait.

 

Note - Vit. B1 deficiency also leads to Beri Beri in polished rice eaters

questions.text: A child presented in the pediatric OPD with fever for past 5 days along with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis. The mother also complained of a non itchy rash that appeared just a day back starting from behind the ears involving the face and spreading to the trunk also involving palms and soles. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles


The clinical presentation described is characteristic of measles, a viral infection caused by the measles virus. Measles typically presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza (runny nose), and conjunctivitis, often referred to as the "3 C's" of measles. These symptoms are followed by the appearance of a maculopapular rash that typically starts behind the ears, spreads to the face, and then to the rest of the body, including the trunk, palms, and soles.

 

The hallmark features of measles include the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a characteristic rash that spreads from the head downward to the rest of the body. This description fits the scenario provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella, also known as German measles, presents with a milder illness compared to measles. The rash in rubella usually starts on the face and spreads to the body but is typically accompanied by mild fever and swollen lymph nodes, especially behind the ears. The rash in rubella is often itchy, which contrasts with the non-itchy rash described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Dengue: Dengue fever presents with symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, rash, and bleeding tendencies. Thrombocytopenia and other signs of bleeding are common in dengue, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is not applicable as the clinical features align with a diagnosis of measles.

 

Educational Objective:


Measles is characterized by the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a non-itchy rash that spreads from behind the ears to the rest of the body, including the palms and soles.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the ER with a two-day history of worsening ear pain and drainage. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing down and out as shown below. The most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Mastoiditis

 

The patient's presentation of worsening ear pain, drainage, and redness behind the ear, along with a prominent right pinna pointing down and out, is indicative of a complication of acute otitis media, specifically acute mastoiditis. Acute mastoiditis is characterized by inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells, often resulting in a post-auricular abscess, as seen in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Otitis externa, or external ear canal infection, typically presents with pain, discharge, and sometimes swelling of the ear canal, but does not usually cause post-auricular redness or a displaced pinna.

 

Option B. Otitis media with effusion: Otitis media with effusion involves the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It does not present with post-auricular redness or abscess.

 

Option D. Coalescent Mastoiditis: Coalescent mastoiditis is a more advanced stage of mastoiditis where the bony septa between mastoid air cells break down, forming a common cavity. This diagnosis could be considered if the condition had been present for a longer duration. However, the acute presentation described fits acute mastoiditis more accurately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media, can present with post-auricular redness, abscess, and displacement of the pinna, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Not included in STEPS approach for Non-communicable diseases is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood grouping

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO STEPS approach for non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance involves three steps: behavioral measurements, physical measurements, and biochemical measurements. These steps focus on key indicators related to NCDs and stroke surveillance.

 

The specific indicators include:

 

  • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus.
  • Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate.
  • Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.

 

Blood grouping is not a part of the STEPS approach as it does not relate to the risk factors or measurements for NCDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood sugar: Included as a core biochemical measurement (blood glucose).

 

Option B. Blood pressure: Included as a core physical measurement.

 

Option D. Blood lipids: Included as a core biochemical measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO STEPS approach for NCD risk factor surveillance includes behavioral, physical, and biochemical measurements, but blood grouping is not included in these indicators.

questions.text: A patient developed sudden hypertensive episode after taking wine. He is suffering from a psychiatric illness and is on medications for the same. Which is the drug he is likely to be using? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MAOIs

 

The patient in the question is likely taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) for his psychiatric illness.

 

MAOIs are known to cause a "Cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas. Normally, tyramine is broken down by monoamine oxidase enzymes in the body. However, when a person is taking MAOIs, these enzymes are inhibited, leading to an accumulation of tyramine. The excess tyramine can cause a sudden and dangerous increase in blood pressure, resulting in a hypertensive episode.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SSRIs work by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option C. SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SNRIs work by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option D. TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants): Incorrect. While TCAs can have some effects on blood pressure, they do not inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes and do not lead to the accumulation of tyramine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) can cause a "cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas due to the inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzymes and the accumulation of tyramine.

questions.text: A young male is complaining of pain, and the image shows a lesion in the diaphysis. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • The X-ray shows a lesion in the diaphysis of the bone, consistent with an osteoid osteoma. This is characterized by a small, benign, and painful tumor usually found in the cortex of long bones, such as the femur or tibia.
  • Osteoid osteomas are typically less than 2 cm in size and can cause significant pain, often worse at night, which is relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteochondroma: A common benign bone tumor that usually arises near the growth plate of a long bone. These tumors manifest as a cartilage-capped bony projection on the surface of the bone and do not typically present as a central diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option B. Giant Cell Tumor (GCT): This tumor often occurs near the end of the bone and extends to the joint. It usually affects adults between 20 and 40 years old and may be more aggressive than an osteoid osteoma.
