Option C. Unicameral Bone Cyst (Simple Bone Cyst): This is a fluid-filled bone cavity typically found in the metaphysis of long bones in children and young adults. It generally does not cause significant pain unless there is a pathological fracture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • When encountering a patient with localized bone pain and a small radiolucent lesion in the cortex of the bone, consider osteoid osteoma in the differential diagnosis. Early and accurate diagnosis can lead to effective treatment, primarily with NSAIDs or surgical excision, providing significant symptom relief.

questions.text: A patient presenting with headaches, hypertension, and elevated metanephrines should undergo which diagnostic investigation? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MIBG scan

 

  • Given the symptoms and the elevated metanephrines patient seems likely to have pheochromocytoma , and  an MIBG scan or a CT abdomen would be the most appropriate investigations to confirm the diagnosis of a pheochromocytoma. The MIBG scan offers more specific targeting of the type of tissue involved in pheochromocytoma, making it particularly useful if initial CT results are ambiguous or if surgical planning is necessary.
  • This is a specific type of scintigraphy used to locate neuroendocrine tumors, particularly pheochromocytomas. MIBG is structurally similar to norepinephrine and can be labeled with iodine-123 or iodine-131, allowing it to be visualized using a gamma camera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sestamibi Scan: This is primarily used for detecting parathyroid adenomas and is not suitable for diagnosing pheochromocytoma.

 

Option C. PET Scan (Positron Emission Tomography): While a PET scan is useful in oncologic imaging and can detect metabolically active tumors, it is not as specific as MIBG for pheochromocytoma but may be utilized depending on availability and specific circumstances.

 

Option D. CT Abdomen: This is an effective and rapid diagnostic tool to visualize the adrenal glands and assess for the presence of a tumor. A CT scan can provide detailed images that help in determining the size and location of adrenal masses.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Diagnostic investigation of choice for pheochromocytoma is MIBG scan.

questions.text: Visual blurring in papilledema is called as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amaurosis fugax

 

Explanation:

 

Amaurosis fugax refers to transient episodes of visual blurring or vision loss.

 

It is often seen in conditions where there is temporary reduction in blood flow to the eye, such as in papilledema. Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head (optic disc) due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling can cause transient visual disturbances, which are described as amaurosis fugax.

 

In papilledema, the optic nerve head becomes swollen due to stasis of axoplasmic flow, often because of compression or increased pressure on the optic nerve. Despite this swelling, optic nerve function remains normal initially, meaning that central vision, color vision, and pupil reactions are typically preserved. The transient visual blurring episodes (amaurosis fugax) are a key symptom.

                       

Note - Finding in visual field charting (Papilledema)– enlargement of physiological blind spot

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blindness: This refers to complete loss of vision, which is not the case in papilledema where vision disturbances are transient.

 

Option C. Malingering: This term refers to the intentional feigning of illness or symptoms for secondary gain, and is not related to the visual disturbances seen in papilledema.

 

Option D. Corectopia: This is a condition where the pupil is displaced from its normal central position. It is unrelated to the transient visual blurring seen in papilledema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amaurosis fugax refers to transient episodes of visual blurring seen in conditions like papilledema, which is characterized by swelling of the optic nerve head due to increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A child has been brought into the emergency department with symptoms of bilious vomiting. Below is an X-ray image of the abdomen: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

 

  • The image provided is a classic radiographic representation known as the "double bubble" sign, indicative of duodenal atresia.
  • This condition is characterized by a congenital absence or complete closure of a portion of the lumen of the duodenum. The "double bubble" sign, seen here, represents two dilated areas separated by a pinched segment: one in the stomach and another in the proximal duodenum. This leads to vomiting, typically bilious because the obstruction is distal to where the bile duct enters the intestine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS): This involves the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter muscle, which leads to obstruction and a “single bubble” appearance. While it can cause projectile vomiting, this usually occurs without bile, and the typical radiographic finding is an elongated pyloric channel .

 

Option C. Jejunal Atresia: The typical radiographic finding might include multiple dilated loops of the bowel, with air-fluid levels depending on the level of obstruction, rather than the “double bubble.”

 

Option D. Volvulus: This is a condition in which there is a twisting of the bowel on itself, leading to an obstruction. And does not present with “double bubble sign ”

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "double bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray in a neonate with bilious vomiting is highly suggestive of duodenal atresia. This condition requires surgical intervention, and timely diagnosis is crucial to manage potential complications and outcomes effectively.

questions.text: Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in which type of dementia? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dementia with lewy body

 

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification where the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by a similar-looking stranger.

 

While Capgras syndrome is usually seen in Schizophrenia, it can also occur in patients with dementia. Among the various types of dementia, Capgras syndrome is most commonly associated with Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), followed by Alzheimer's disease. In a patient with Capgras syndrome and dementia, the patient may believe that their spouse or a family member has been replaced by an identical impostor, leading to conflicts and distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease is the second most common type of dementia associated with Capgras syndrome, after dementia with Lewy bodies.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia is not typically associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Option D. Frontotemporal dementia is not commonly associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capgras syndrome, a delusion of misidentification where a patient believes a familiar person has been replaced by an identical impostor, is most commonly seen in dementia with Lewy bodies, followed by Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: GLUT2 is a glucose transporter that plays a significant role in maintaining glucose homeostasis. It is predominantly expressed in specific tissues, where it facilitates the bidirectional transport of glucose. In which of the following tissues is GLUT2 predominantly expressed? (FMGE  JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kidneys

 

GLUT2 is expressed in the kidneys, as well as in the liver, pancreatic β-cells, and small intestine. In the kidneys, it plays a role in the reabsorption and excretion of glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skeletal muscle: Incorrect. Skeletal muscle predominantly expresses GLUT4, not GLUT2. GLUT4 is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake in muscle tissue.

 

Option B. Adipose tissue: Incorrect. Adipose tissue primarily expresses GLUT4, which is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake in fat cells.

 

Option D. Cardiac muscle: Incorrect. Cardiac muscle mainly expresses GLUT4, which is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake in heart tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT2 is primarily expressed in the kidneys, liver, pancreatic β-cells, and small intestine, facilitating bidirectional glucose transport.

questions.text: Identify the device used in surgery: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verees needle

 

The device shown in the image is a Verees needle, which is commonly used for establishing pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. The Verees needle is a spring-loaded needle with a blunt tip that retracts when it punctures the peritoneum, thereby reducing the risk of injury to internal organs. It is used to introduce carbon dioxide (CO2) gas into the peritoneal cavity, creating a working space for laparoscopic instruments.

 

CO2 is preferred for creating pneumoperitoneum because it is non-combustible and the risk of air embolism is low due to its rapid excretion from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural catheter:

 

 

Option C. Optical trocar:

 

 

Option D. Spinal needle:   

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Verees needle is a specialized instrument used to safely establish pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries by introducing CO2 into the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not constrained by time? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goal

 

Explanation:

 

A goal is the ultimate desired state that a health program aims to achieve. It is not constrained by time, meaning that a goal does not have a specific timeline associated with it. Additionally, a goal is not necessarily attainable, as it represents the ultimate desired outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Objective:  An objective is a specific, planned activity in a health program. Objectives are designed to help achieve the goal and are usually associated with a timeline.

 

Option B. Target:  A target is the degree of achievement of objectives and is always associated with a timeline.

 

Option D. Principle:  The principles are generally guidelines or fundamental truths and do not specify timelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of health programs, a goal is the ultimate desired state and is not constrained by time or resources. It represents an "all or none" phenomenon and may not always be attainable.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with wounds that aren’t healing properly, diarrhea, alopecia, and dermatitis. This could be due to which nutrient deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

 Zinc deficiency, also known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, is characterized by symptoms such as impaired wound healing, diarrhea, alopecia, and dermatitis.

Zinc is crucial for immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. A deficiency in zinc disrupts these biological processes, leading to the symptoms mentioned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Deficiency leads to scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums, weakness, and bruising, not primarily with the symptoms listed in the question.

 

Option C. Niacin: Deficiency results in pellagra, characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and eventually death, but does not typically include alopecia as a primary symptom.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Deficiency can cause neurological and muscular symptoms, such as tremors and muscle spasms, which are not mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of diarrhea, impaired wound healing, alopecia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flumazenil

 

Flumazenil is the drug used for treating benzodiazepine overdose. It acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, effectively reversing the sedative effects of benzodiazepines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folinic acid: Folinic acid is used to reduce the toxicity of methotrexate and as an antidote for folic acid antagonists, not for benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Option C. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to treat opioid overdose, not benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Option D. Fomepizole: Fomepizole is an antidote used for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not for benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose due to its action as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, effectively reversing sedative effects.

questions.text: 6 x 6 x 6 Strategy under Anemia Mukt Bharat does not include: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 Ministries

 

Explanation:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points per year from 2018 to 2022. The program is implemented using the 6 x 6 x 6 strategy, which includes:

 

 

The strategy does not include 6 Ministries as one of its components.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Beneficiaries: Children below 5 years, children aged 5-9 years, adolescents aged 10-19 years, women of reproductive age (20-49 years), pregnant women, and lactating women.

 

Option B. 6 Interventions: This includes iron and folic acid supplementation, deworming, intensified year-round behavior change communication (BCC), testing and treatment of anemia using digital methods and point of care treatment, mandatory provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs, and addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets with special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

 

Option D. 6 Institutional mechanisms: These are designed to support the implementation of the program effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6 x 6 x 6 strategy under Anemia Mukt Bharat includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms, but not 6 ministries.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth, which appears bluish-red and transilluminates positively. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ranula

 

A ranula is a type of mucous cyst that forms in the floor of the mouth. It typically presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling that transilluminates positively due to its fluid content. Ranulas are caused by the obstruction of salivary glands, leading to the accumulation of mucous.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: This is incorrect because dermoid cysts contain sebaceous material and hair, and they do not transilluminate. They are also not typically bluish-red in appearance.

 

Option C. Sublingual growth: This is incorrect as a general term that does not specify a cystic or transilluminating nature.

 

Option D. Sublingual cyst: This is incorrect as it does not have transillumination and bluish-red color.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ranula presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth that transilluminates positively, due to the accumulation of mucous from an obstructed salivary gland.

questions.text: Identify the classification: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mallampati score

 

Explanation:

 

The image shown is the Mallampati classification. It classifies the ease of visualization of the oral structures (uvula, soft palate, and tonsillar pillars) when a patient opens their mouth and protrudes their tongue. This classification helps predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aldrete score: This scoring system is used to assess the recovery of a patient post-surgery, focusing on activity, respiration, circulation, consciousness, and oxygen saturation.

 

Option C. Ramsay score: The Ramsay Score is a scale for assessing the level of sedation in patients, particularly in a critical care setting.

 

Option D. Z score: The Z score is a statistical measurement that describes a value's relationship to the mean of a group of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is utilized to assess the potential difficulty of endotracheal intubation by examining the visibility of anatomical structures in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A patient developed involuntary purposeless movements and was found to have atrophy of the caudate nucleus on investigation. Which of the following is the trinucleotide repeats would be seen in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CAG

 

The presence of involuntary purposeless movements (chorea) and atrophy of the caudate nucleus are hallmark features of Huntington’s disease. Huntington’s disease is caused by an expanded trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the HTT gene, which leads to the production of a mutant protein that causes neuronal degeneration, particularly in the caudate nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GAA: Associated with Friedreich's ataxia.

 

Option B. CTG: Associated with Myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option D. CGG: Associated with Fragile X syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Huntington’s disease is associated with CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions in the HTT gene, leading to chorea and caudate nucleus atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medial margin of sartorius

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral triangle is a triangular muscular depression located in the upper part of the thigh. Its boundaries are formed by the inguinal ligament (base), the medial margin of the sartorius muscle (lateral boundary), and the medial border of the adductor longus muscle (medial boundary). The apex of the triangle is formed by the intersection of the sartorius and adductor longus muscles.

 

The sartorius muscle, the longest muscle in the body, originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle with its medial margin. The adductor longus muscle, originating from the pubic tubercle area, forms the medial boundary of the triangle.

 

The floor of the femoral triangle is formed by the adductor longus, pectineus, psoas major tendon, and iliacus muscle (Mnemonic "APPI"). The roof of the triangle is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The medial margin of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius: Incorrect. The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, but it is the medial margin of the sartorius that specifically forms this boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial margin of the sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, while the medial border of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary.

questions.text: What is the drug used for refraction in a child with squint? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1% Atropine

 

Explanation:

 

1% Atropine is the preferred drug for refraction in a child (<7 yr children) with squint, particularly because it is the strongest cycloplegic agent available.

 

Children often have strong accommodation, which can interfere with accurate refraction, especially in cases of accommodative esotropia. Using a potent cycloplegic like 1% atropine helps to fully relax the accommodation, allowing for precise measurement of refractive errors.

 

Atropine 1% is typically preferred in ointment form due to its longer duration of action and ease of application. The ointment can be applied to the eyelashes or lower lid, ensuring widespread coverage over the entire eye surface. This is especially useful for children under the age of 7 who require thorough cycloplegia for accurate refraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tropicamide: This is a short-acting cycloplegic used primarily in adults. It is not strong enough to overcome the strong accommodation seen in children.

 

Option C. Homatropine: Although it has cycloplegic properties, it is less potent than atropine and not the first choice for children with squint.

 

Option D. Cyclopentolate: This is another cycloplegic agent used in children, but it is less potent than atropine. It can be used if atropine is not available or in specific cases where a slightly less strong cycloplegic is sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1% Atropine is the drug of choice for refraction in children with squint due to its strong cycloplegic effect, ensuring accurate measurement of refractive errors by fully relaxing accommodation.

 

Mnemonic – ACHT  - Order of Potency -

Atropine strongest potency
Cyclopentolate
Homatropine
Tropicamide

choices.text: Most commonly seen in adolescent male

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding in ENT emergency. On physical examination: Patient seems pale having Hb: 9 gm/dl. On CECT: a mass is seen which pushes septum to the contralateral side & anterior bowing of maxillary antrum is seen. All of the given statements are true regarding this mass except?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Best treated by radiation

 

Explanation

 

The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding, pallor, and a mass pushing the septum to the contralateral side with anterior bowing of the maxillary antrum (Colman-Miller sign), are indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is most commonly seen in adolescent males, can spread to the orbit and intracranially, but it is not best treated by radiation. The primary treatment for JNA is surgical resection, not radiation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male: This is correct. JNA predominantly affects adolescent males.

 

Option B. Can spread to orbit: This is correct. JNA can extend into the orbit due to its aggressive nature.

 

Option D. Can spread intracranially: This is correct. JNA can invade the cranial cavity, leading to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a condition that is most commonly seen in adolescent males and primarily treated with surgical resection, not radiation.

questions.text: As per the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, the following combination is incorrect? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blue container – Incineration

 

The blue container is intended for the disposal of glassware and metallic implants. According to the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, these items should undergo autoclaving, hydroclaving, microwaving, or chemical treatment, followed by recycling. Incineration is not a recommended method for the blue container category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow bag – Deep burial: This is partially correct as deep burial is permitted for placentas at primary health centers, but generally, yellow bag waste is for incineration.

 

Option B. Yellow bag – Incineration: Correct as the yellow bag is primarily used for incinerating human anatomical waste, animal waste, microbiological and biotechnological waste, etc.

 

Option C. Red bag – Autoclaving: Correct as the red bag contains contaminated recyclable plastic and rubber material, which is treated via autoclaving, hydroclaving, or microwaving.

 

Additional Information

 

White container – For Sharps → autocalving/ dry heat → destruction shredding → iron foundries/ land fill/ sharp pits 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blue containers for biomedical waste should not be incinerated but treated and then recycled as per the guidelines.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital and administered parenteral penicillin. This was followed by development of haemolytic anemia in the patient. Which of the following is the explanation for the pathogenesis of the condition of the patient?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

 

Type 2 hypersensitivity reactions, also known as antibody-mediated cytotoxic reactions, occur when antibodies, typically IgG or IgM, bind to antigens on the surface of cells. This binding activates the complement system, leading to cell lysis and destruction. In the case of drug-induced hemolytic anemia, the drug (penicillin) can bind to red blood cells and act as a hapten, prompting the immune system to produce antibodies against these drug-coated cells, resulting in hemolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction: These reactions are mediated by IgE antibodies and involve the release of histamine from mast cells and basophils, leading to symptoms like anaphylaxis, urticaria, and asthma. Hemolytic anemia is not a feature of Type 1 hypersensitivity.

 

Option C. Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction: These are immune complex-mediated reactions where antigen-antibody complexes deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and tissue damage. Conditions such as serum sickness and certain forms of glomerulonephritis are examples, but not hemolytic anemia.

 

Option D. Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction: These are delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions mediated by T cells rather than antibodies. Examples include contact dermatitis and tuberculosis skin test reactions, not hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: HIV positive woman, not on any treatment, delivers a baby. Initial treatment for the newborn will include:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nevirapine + Zidovudine X 6 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Low-risk infants: 

  • Infants born to mothers with suppressed viral load (<1000 copies/ml) done any time after 32 weeks of pregnancy up to delivery

 

ARV Prophylaxis Options:

  • Syrup Nevirapine (NVP) or
  • Syrup Zidovudine# (in situations where NVP will not be effective):
    • Infant born to a mother with confirmed HIV-2 or HIV-1 and HIV-2 combined infections
    • Infant born to a mother who had received single dose of NVP during earlier pregnancy or delivery
    • Infant born to a mother who is on PI-based ART regimen due to treatment failure

 

Duration of ARV prophylaxis:

  • From birth till 6 weeks of age

 

High-risk infants

  • Infants born to HIV-positive mother not on ART
  • Maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery
  • Maternal viral load not suppressed between 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery
  • Mother newly identified HIV positive within 6 weeks of delivery

 

Options for dual prophylaxis:

  • Syrup NVP + Syrup Zidovudine

 

Duration of Dual ARV Prophylaxis:

  • In case of Exclusive Replacement Feeding (ERF): From birth till 6 weeks of age
  • In case of Exclusive Breastfeeding (EBF): From birth till 12 weeks of age

 

Educational Objective:

 

For newborns of untreated HIV-positive mothers, initial treatment includes Syrup NVP + Syrup Zidovudine 6 weeks (12 weeks in cases of exclusive breast feeding) to reduce the risk of mother-to-child HIV transmission.

questions.text: A neonate presents with post feed vomiting and hypoglycemia in the first week of life. Urine was positive for reducing substances but there was no glucose and urine also gave positive reaction with Benedict’s reagent. The neonate also had reversible oil drop cataract. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical Galactosemia


Classical Galactosemia is the correct diagnosis based on the clinical presentation. It is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT), which is crucial in the metabolism of galactose. This enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of galactose and its toxic metabolites, causing the symptoms observed in the neonate.

 

  • Symptoms: The neonate presents with post-feed vomiting, hypoglycemia, and cataracts, which are hallmark features of classical galactosemia.
  • Urine findings: The positive reaction with Benedict’s reagent indicates the presence of reducing substances, specifically galactose, in the urine. The absence of glucose further supports the diagnosis.
  • Cataracts: The reversible oil drop cataract is a classic sign of galactosemia, caused by the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential Fructosuria: Essential fructosuria is a benign condition due to fructokinase deficiency, leading to the presence of fructose in the urine. It does not cause the severe symptoms seen in galactosemia, such as hypoglycemia or cataracts.

 

Option C. Galactokinase Deficiency: Galactokinase deficiency can also lead to the accumulation of galactose, but it typically presents with cataracts alone and does not cause the severe systemic symptoms such as vomiting and hypoglycemia seen in classical galactosemia.

 

Option D. Uridine diphosphate-glucose 4-epimerase deficiency: This is a rare condition that affects the conversion of UDP-galactose to UDP-glucose. Its clinical presentation can vary but does not typically include the combination of severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, and cataracts associated with classical galactosemia.

 

Educational Objective:


Recognize the clinical features and diagnostic findings associated with classical galactosemia, including post-feed vomiting, hypoglycemia, positive reducing substances in urine, positive reaction with Benedict’s reagent, and the development of reversible oil drop cataracts.

questions.text: An adolescent fell on an outstretched hand. For management, the doctor ties a cast as shown in the given image. Which fracture did the patient suffer from? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid fracture

 

  • Given scenario and image showing a Glass Holding Cast, most likely depicts a Scaphoid Fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. It is an extra-articular fracture of lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction. It presents with the classical Dinner fork deformity.

 

 

 

Most Colle’s fractures can be successfully treated non-operatively and a Hand-shaking cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization in Colle’s fracture is:

 

 

Option C. Smith fracture. Smith fracture is reverse Colle’s and there is garden spade deformity due to malunion. It is an extra articular fracture of the distal radius featuring a volar displacement or angulation of the distal fragment.

 

 

The mainstay of treatment of undisplaced and stable distal radius fractures is closed reduction followed by immobilization. It is treated by close reduction and immobilization in above elbow cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension (dorsiflexion).

 

 

Option D. Galeazzi fracture. The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex) is called Galeazzi Fracture dislocation (the fracture of necessity). A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results. Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of undisplaced and stable scaphoid fractures, a glass-holding cast is applied.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea. A diagnosis of cardiac tamponade is considered. Which of the following changes in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is most indicative of cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Y descent is blunted/absent

 

Y descent is blunted/absent: Correct. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure within the pericardium limits the right ventricular filling during diastole, which blunts or abolishes the Y descent on the JVP waveform, as it reflects the rapid emptying of the jugular veins into the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prominent X descent: Incorrect. The X descent represents atrial relaxation and downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during ventricular systole. It can be prominent in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis but is not specifically indicative of cardiac tamponade.

 

Option C. Large a waves: Incorrect. Large a waves are associated with increased resistance to right atrial emptying, as seen in tricuspid stenosis or right atrial hypertrophy, not typically in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option D. Steep Y descent: Incorrect. A steep Y descent is associated with conditions that allow rapid venous filling into the right ventricle, such as constrictive pericarditis, and is not characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the Y descent on the jugular venous pressure waveform is blunted or absent due to restricted right ventricular filling during diastole.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with hoarseness of voice with a history of significant weight loss. On laryngoscopy, ulceroproliferative growth involving the left vocal fold is seen, as shown below. The vocal cord is fixed. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

 

Explanation:  


The clinical presentation (hoarseness of voice, weight loss) and the laryngoscopic findings (ulceroproliferative growth with fixed vocal cord) suggest advanced glottic carcinoma. The fixed vocal cord indicates at least T3 stage, as it suggests tumor infiltration into the paraglottic space or fixation due to deeper invasion. Weight loss in an elderly patient further supports an advanced stage malignancy.

 

This is the preferred treatment for T3 or T4 laryngeal cancers, especially when the vocal cords are fixed, and there is a high likelihood of regional spread. If the patient has significant lymph node involvement or is symptomatic (e.g., weight loss), a neck dissection is warranted along with total laryngectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical Radiotherapy: Radical radiotherapy is usually preferred for early-stage laryngeal cancers (T1 or T2) with mobile vocal cords. It is less effective for advanced stages (T3 or T4) due to higher chances of recurrence.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for advanced laryngeal carcinoma unless the patient is unsuitable for surgery or radiation. It is primarily used for palliative care or in cases with distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Concurrent Chemoradiation: Concurrent chemoradiation is a consideration for organ preservation in advanced laryngeal cancers. However, for patients with a fixed vocal cord and significant weight loss, total laryngectomy provides better local control and survival outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:


For advanced glottic carcinoma with vocal cord fixation (T3/T4) and evidence of regional spread, the best treatment option is Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks
IV antibiotics and follow up after a month

questions.text: A child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane as shown below. Most appropriate management would be: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

 

The child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge and a small perforation in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, indicating an attic perforation. This condition is consistent with attico-antral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), also known as unsafe CSOM. This type of CSOM is characterized by scanty, mucopurulent, foul-smelling discharge, which may sometimes be bloodstained.

 

The definitive management for attico-antral CSOM is tympanomastoid exploration. This procedure helps to eradicate the disease from the middle ear and mastoid, preventing further complications such as cholesteatoma and hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks: While topical antibiotics can be used to manage the discharge and infection initially, they are not the definitive treatment for attico-antral CSOM. The primary goal is to control the infection, but definitive surgical intervention is required for complete management.

 

Option B. IV antibiotics and follow up after a month: IV antibiotics may be used in severe cases to control acute infection, but they are not the standard approach for managing attico-antral CSOM. Follow-up after a month without addressing the underlying condition is not adequate.

 

Option C. Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at repairing the tympanic membrane and is typically used in cases of safe CSOM or tubotympanic CSOM. It is not appropriate for attico-antral CSOM, where more extensive surgical intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attico-antral CSOM, characterized by foul-smelling discharge and attic perforation, requires tympanomastoid exploration for definitive management.

questions.text: A 60-year-old with lower backache had low hemoglobin, increased creatinine and multiple osteolytic lesions on radiograph. His serum electrophoresis revealed normal albumin but disproportionately high globulin. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple myeloma

 

The clinical picture presented is suggestive of anemia, renal dysfunction and bony lytic lesions with increased production of globulin levels suggestive of monoclonal proliferation of plasma cells and meeting the CRAB criteria of multiple myeloma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prostate cancer: Prostate cancer can present with bone pain due to metastasis, but it typically causes sclerotic (rather than osteolytic) bone lesions and does not cause the marked increase in globulin levels seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Pott's spine: This refers to tuberculosis of the spine and can present with back pain and osteolytic lesions, but it is not associated with increased globulin levels or the hematological findings seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis can cause bone pain and fractures but does not cause anemia, renal dysfunction, or increased globulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, renal dysfunction, osteolytic bone lesions, and a high globulin level due to monoclonal proliferation of plasma cells.

questions.text: Hypokalemia is seen in all of the following conditions, except? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal tubular acidosis 4

 

Renal tubular acidosis type 4 (hyperkalemic RTA) is distinct from the other types as it is characterized by hyperkalemia (high potassium levels). It is typically caused by aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium secretion. This condition is often associated with Addison's disease, or can be induced by medications such as ACE inhibitors, ARBs, calcineurin inhibitors, heparin, NSAIDs, and potassium-sparing diuretics.

 

Other Options:

 

Hypokalemia, or low potassium levels, is commonly seen in several conditions that lead to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). These include:

 

Option A. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) type 1 (Distal RTA): This condition is characterized by a defect in hydrogen ion secretion in the distal nephron, leading to hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, and recurrent kidney stones.

 

Option B. Renal tubular acidosis type 2 (Proximal RTA): This condition involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to hypokalemia, bicarbonate wasting, and associated Fanconi syndrome (a combination of aminoaciduria, glycosuria, phosphaturia, and bone disorders such as rickets and osteomalacia).

 

Option D. Ureterosigmoidostomy: This surgical procedure can lead to hypokalemia due to the reabsorption of urinary ammonium and chloride, resulting in a metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal tubular acidosis type 4 is the exception among conditions causing hypokalemia, as it leads to hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance.

questions.text: Acute Hepatitis B is characterized by? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg + IgM anti-HBc

 

Explanation:

 

Acute Hepatitis B is diagnosed based on specific serological markers. The presence of Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and IgM antibodies to Hepatitis B core antigen (IgM anti-HBc) indicates an acute infection. Here’s a detailed explanation:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen is present on the surface of the Hepatitis B virus and indicates an active infection. It is one of the first markers to appear in the blood following infection.
  2. IgM anti-HBc (IgM antibodies to Hepatitis B core antigen): The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection, as IgM is produced early in the immune response. This marker is crucial in differentiating acute from chronic infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgG anti-HBc: The presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates a past or chronic infection. It is not specific for acute infection.

 

Option C. anti-HBs: The presence of anti-HBs antibodies indicates recovery and immunity from Hepatitis B infection, either due to past infection or vaccination.

 

Option D. HBeAg: This antigen indicates active viral replication and high infectivity but does not differentiate between acute and chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Hepatitis B is characterized by the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc, which indicate an active and recent infection.

questions.text: In the adjacent graph phase Ib represents which one of the following property? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plasticity

 

Correct. Plasticity refers to the ability of the bladder to accommodate increasing volumes of urine with little to no increase in intravesical pressure. The plateau phase (Ib) where the pressure remains relatively stable despite increasing volume is indicative of the bladder's plasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elasticity: Incorrect. Elasticity refers to the ability of a material or tissue to resume its normal shape after being stretched or compressed. In the context of bladder physiology, the initial part of the curve would represent elasticity as the bladder wall stretches without a significant increase in pressure.

 

Option C. Contractility: Incorrect. Contractility refers to the ability of the bladder muscle (detrusor muscle) to contract. This would be assessed during the voiding phase of the cystometrogram, not during the filling phase which is depicted in the graph.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. One of the properties listed (Plasticity) does describe phase Ib of the graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase Ib in the bladder pressure-volume graph represents the property of plasticity, where the bladder accommodates increasing urine volume with minimal increase in intravesical pressure.

questions.text: Which congenital deformity is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anencephaly, craniorachischisis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a congenital deformity characterized by the absence of the cranial vault (anencephaly) and the exposure of the entire spinal cord due to the non-fusion of the neural tube (craniorachischisis).

  • Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This occurs due to the failure of the anterior neuropore to close during embryonic development.
  • Craniorachischisis involves the failure of closure of both the anterior and posterior neuropores, leading to the exposure of the brain and spinal cord. The entire neural tube remains open, resulting in severe defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Anencephaly: This option only accounts for the absence of the cranial vault but does not include the exposed spinal cord.

 

Option C.  Meningomyelocele, anencephaly: Meningomyelocele refers to a form of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meninges protrude through a defect in the spine. While the image does show an exposed spinal cord, it is not a localized defect as seen in meningomyelocele.

 

Option D.  Spina bifida occulta, anencephaly: Spina bifida occulta is a mild form of spina bifida where the vertebral arches fail to fuse but without protrusion of the spinal contents. The image shows a more severe defect.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly with craniorachischisis involves the non-closure of the neural tube, resulting in the absence of the cranial vault and exposure of the spinal cord along its entire length.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presented in ENT OPD with hoarseness of voice following a quarrel in public. On laryngoscopy, the following picture is seen. Management of this patient is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MLS removal

 

Explanation:

 

The laryngoscopic image shows a unilateral large mass at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, which is consistent with a vocal polyp. Vocal polyps typically result from vocal abuse or trauma and can cause hoarseness of voice. The definitive management of a vocal polyp is Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS) removal, which involves surgically excising the polyp to restore normal voice function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not indicated for benign lesions such as vocal polyps. It is used primarily for malignant conditions.

 

Option C. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is not a standard treatment for vocal polyps. It is more commonly used for other types of lesions.

 

Option D. Voice rest & Speech therapy: Voice rest and speech therapy are generally recommended for vocal nodules, which are smaller and often bilateral. While these therapies can help in reducing strain on the vocal cords, they are not the primary treatment for vocal polyps, which require surgical removal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of a vocal polyp, which presents as a unilateral mass on the vocal cord, is surgical removal via Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS). Voice rest and speech therapy are more suitable for smaller, bilateral vocal nodules.

questions.text: During climbing the staircase, a person suddenly fell & a sharp object hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder & he is having difficulty in turning his head. What structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal accessory nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) innervates both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. The trapezius muscle is responsible for the elevation or shrugging of the shoulder, while the sternocleidomastoid muscle is responsible for turning the head. Injury to the spinal accessory nerve results in an inability to perform these actions, which matches the patient's symptoms of being unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder and having difficulty turning the head. Therefore, the most likely structure damaged in this case is the spinal accessory nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for the protraction and upward rotation of the scapula. Damage to this nerve causes winging of the scapula, not an inability to shrug the shoulder or turn the head.

 

Option C. Sternocleidomastoid: While the sternocleidomastoid muscle is indeed involved in turning the head, its dysfunction alone would not explain the inability to shrug the shoulder. The issue lies with the nerve that innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option D. Deltoid: This muscle is innervated by the axillary nerve and is responsible for shoulder abduction. Damage to the deltoid or axillary nerve would cause difficulty in shoulder abduction, not in shrugging the shoulder or turning the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) is responsible for innervating the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles, which are essential for shrugging the shoulder and turning the head, respectively.

choices.text: Opinion of 1 doctor
Opinion of 2 doctors
Husband’s permission with 1 doctor
Permission of medical board

questions.text: A fetus diagnosed with neural tube defect at 21 weeks. The parents want an MTP at 21 weeks. What opinions are required? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Opinion of 2 doctors

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, which was amended in 2021, significant changes were made to the requirements for performing an MTP in India.

 

Under the old act, MTP was allowed up to 20 weeks, with the opinion of one registered medical practitioner (RMP) required up to 12 weeks, and the opinion of two RMPs required from 12 to 20 weeks.

 

The 2021 amendment extended the permissible period for MTP to 24 weeks. The new guidelines specify that:

 

  • Up to 20 weeks, the opinion of one RMP or gynecologist is required.
  • From 20 to 24 weeks, the opinion of two gynecologists is required.
  • For pregnancies beyond 24 weeks, MTP can be performed only if there is a substantial fetal anomaly, which must be determined by a medical board. This board typically consists of specialists such as a radiologist, a gynecologist, a pediatrician, and other relevant subspecialists based on the nature of the anomaly.

 

In this scenario, since the fetus is diagnosed with a neural tube defect at 21 weeks and the parents request an MTP, the opinion of two doctors is required.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opinion of 1 doctor: This is required only up to 20 weeks of pregnancy, not beyond.

 

Option C. Husband’s permission with 1 doctor: The husband’s permission is not a requirement under the MTP Act.

 

Option D. Permission of medical board: This is required for performing MTP after 24 weeks if there is a substantial fetal anomaly.

 

Educational objective

 

For an MTP between 20 to 24 weeks of pregnancy, the opinion of two gynecologists is required as per the 2021 amendment to the MTP Act in India.

questions.text: A young female presented with flank pain, smoky urine and edema. Her urine examination revealed the presence of 20 RBCs/HPF with dysmorphic red cells. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

The presence of dysmorphic red cells in the urine and smoky-colored urine indicates glomerular hematuria, which is characteristic of glomerulonephritis. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a common cause of glomerulonephritis, especially in children and young adults. It typically follows a streptococcal infection (such as pharyngitis or impetigo) by 1-3 weeks and presents with symptoms like hematuria, edema, and hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrolithiasis: Kidney stones usually cause hematuria with non-dysmorphic red cells and flank pain but not typically associated with smoky urine or dysmorphic RBCs.

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: This condition can cause proteinuria and hematuria but is less likely to present acutely with the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: This condition primarily causes nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria and edema but not usually hematuria with dysmorphic red cells.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Presence of dysmorphic red cells and smoky urine is suggestive of glomerulonephritis. Out of the given options, post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is the most important condition associated with glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: What percentage of increase in FEV1 represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 12%

 

Explanation:

 

To diagnose bronchial asthma, it is essential to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction. This is typically assessed by measuring the increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) after the administration of a bronchodilator.

 

The criteria for significant reversibility in FEV1 are:

 

  • An increase in FEV1 of more than 12% from the baseline.
  • An absolute increase in FEV1 of more than 200 ml.

 

These criteria confirm that the obstruction is reversible, which is a hallmark of asthma.

 

Note - Criterion is used for assessing peak flow rate (PFR) variability is > 20%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A minimum increase of more than 12% in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration is required to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction in bronchial asthma.

questions.text: What hormones are secreted by the Leydig cells and the Sertoli cells respectively? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Testosterone and AMH

 

In the testes, Leydig cells and Sertoli cells have distinct roles and secrete different hormones crucial for male reproductive development and function:

 

  • Leydig cells: These cells are responsible for the production of testosterone. Testosterone plays a pivotal role in the development of male secondary sexual characteristics and is crucial for the growth of the ipsilateral Wolffian duct, which develops into the male internal genitalia. Additionally, testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is essential for the development of male external genitalia.
  • Sertoli cells: These cells produce Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), also known as Mullerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS). During male embryonic development, AMH is vital for inhibiting the growth of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia. The suppression of Mullerian duct development by AMH ensures the proper formation of male internal reproductive structures.

 

Note - Inhibin is secreted by Sertoli cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leydig cells secrete testosterone
  • Sertoli cells secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) and Inhibin

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

 

Explanation:

 

The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.

 

CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.

 

Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.

 

Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

questions.text: Diarrhea, falling leaf motility, 4 pairs of flagella, tennis racket shape are seen in? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

Explanation:

 

Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes gastrointestinal illness, typically presenting with diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and malabsorption. The characteristic "falling leaf" motility and the presence of four pairs of flagella (eight flagella in total) are key diagnostic features.

 

Giardia lamblia exists in two forms:

 

  1. Trophozoite: The active, motile form. It has a distinctive shape often described as a tennis racket, teardrop, or monkey face. The trophozoite has two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, and two parabasal bodies.
  2. Cyst: The infective form. It is oval-shaped with a thick wall, containing four nuclei when mature. The cyst form is responsible for transmission through contaminated water or food.

 

The images provided show the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia with its characteristic features, including the flagella and the distinctive shape.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria is a bacterium, not a protozoan. It does not exhibit the described features of falling leaf motility or multiple flagella.

 

Option C. Trichomonas: Trichomonas is a flagellated protozoan but does not have the same morphological characteristics as Giardia lamblia. It typically affects the urogenital tract rather than causing diarrhea.

 

Option D. Balantidium coli: This is a ciliated protozoan that causes dysentery, not typically associated with the described motility or flagella characteristics of Giardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia is identified by its unique "falling leaf" motility, presence of four pairs of flagella, and its characteristic tennis racket or teardrop shape in its trophozoite form. It is a common cause of diarrhea and gastrointestinal discomfort.

 

Additional Information:

 

Classification:

 

 

Life cycle

 

 

Malabsorption  syndrome

 

  1. Abdominal pain , Nausea and vomiting
  2. Malabsorption of fat (steatorrhea)  → leads to foul smelling profuse frothy diarrhea
  3. Malabsorption of Disaccharidase (lactose, xylose) → leading to lactose intolerance
  4. Malabsorption of vitamin A, B12 and iron
  5. Protein loosing enteropathy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 34-year-old experiencing headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

 

The triad of headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension is indicative of pheochromocytoma. This condition is caused by the release of catecholamines, such as norepinephrine, from a tumor typically originating in the adrenal gland. The excessive release of these hormones can lead to headaches, palpitations, and episodes of high blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal adenoma: While adrenal adenomas are tumors of the adrenal gland, they do not secrete catecholamines.

 

Option C. Migraine: Migraine does not explain the palpitations and episodic hypertension.

 

Option D. Temporal arteritis: Temporal arteritis, an inflammatory condition involving the blood vessels, can present with headache but not the other symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension is strongly suggestive of pheochromocytoma, a condition characterized by the excessive release of catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine) from a tumor, typically originating in the adrenal gland.

choices.text: Insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year
Insurance cover of Rs 10 Lacs per family per year

questions.text: As per the Ayushman Bharat program, the following is not an inclusion: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insurance cover of Rs 10 Lacs per family per year

 

Explanation:

 

The Ayushman Bharat program has two main components:

 

  • Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs) - Create a network of health, wellness infrastructure delivering comprehensive primary healthcare services
  • Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY). PM-JAY provides an insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year for secondary and tertiary hospitalization. This program is targeted towards the below poverty line (BPL) population, aiming to cover around 10.74 crore families.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year: This is included under PM-JAY.

 

Option B. Health and wellness centres: These are established to provide comprehensive primary healthcare services.

 

Option C. Meant for BPL families: The program targets families below the poverty line, aiming to benefit around 50 crore individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat program includes an insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year, health and wellness centres, and is meant for BPL families. An insurance cover of Rs 10 Lacs per family per year is not included.

questions.text: A female patient presents five days after delivery with sadness of mood, irritability, restlessness and reduced sleep. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post partum blues

 

The diagnosis of postpartum blues, postpartum depression, or postpartum psychosis is made based on the severity and nature of the symptoms rather than the onset of symptoms.

 

Postpartum blues is characterized by some depressive symptoms such as occasional sadness, crying, and restlessness, without any severe symptoms. In this case, the patient presents with sadness, irritability, restlessness, and reduced sleep five days after delivery, which are indicative of postpartum blues.

 

The absence of severe depressive symptoms like suicidal thoughts, appetite disturbances, anhedonia, inability to take care of oneself, or psychotic symptoms like delusions or hallucinations further supports the diagnosis of postpartum blues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum depression: Postpartum depression is characterized by significant and severe depressive symptoms such as sleep and appetite disturbances, suicidal thoughts, anhedonia, guilt, or thoughts of harming the baby, which are not present in this case.

 

Option C. Post partum psychosis: Post partum psychosis is diagnosed when the patient exhibits psychotic symptoms like delusions or hallucinations, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Post partum anxiety: Post partum anxiety is not a recognized diagnostic entity in the context of postpartum mental health disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of postpartum blues, postpartum depression, or postpartum psychosis is based on the severity and nature of the symptoms, not the onset of symptoms. Postpartum blues presents with some depressive symptoms, postpartum depression with severe depressive symptoms, and postpartum psychosis with psychotic symptoms.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, flank pain, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He has 2+ proteinuria with >20 red cells/HPF and dysmorphic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a 10-year-old child with brown-colored urine, flank pain, fatigue, significant proteinuria, and dysmorphic red blood cells suggests a diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Among the given options, the most likely diagnosis is Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Key points supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • Brown-colored urine (tea or cola colored): Indicates hematuria.
  • Flank pain and fatigue: Common symptoms associated with glomerulonephritis.
  • Proteinuria and dysmorphic red blood cells: Indicate glomerular origin of hematuria, typical in glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary tract infection: Usually presents with isomorphic red blood cells rather than dysmorphic red blood cells and would typically be associated with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria.

 

Option C. Bladder calculi: Can cause hematuria but typically produces isomorphic red blood cells, not dysmorphic ones.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Usually presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and frothy urine, rather than hematuria and dysmorphic red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a common cause of glomerulonephritis in children, presenting with hematuria, proteinuria, and dysmorphic red blood cells following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A middle aged patient had low grade fever and cough with breathlessness. She underwent a lung biopsy which showed presence of asteroid bodies. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sarcoidosis

 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammation is characterized by Th1 mediated immune response.  It is usually a diagnosis of exclusion. The laboratory findings include elevated serum angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE), elevated calcium and elevated ESR.

 

Histological findings include: 

 

  • Discrete or confluent non-necrotizing granulomata composed of epithelioid histiocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Limited lymphocytic cuff surrounding granulomata (so called naked granulomas)
  • Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies include
     

 

 

  • Other associated findings:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, including the lungs. However, it does not typically present with granulomatous inflammation or asteroid bodies. Instead, SLE is more commonly associated with immune complex deposition and widespread inflammation.

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: This is primarily a joint disease that can also have systemic manifestations. While it can involve the lungs (e.g., rheumatoid nodules, interstitial lung disease), it does not typically feature asteroid bodies or the granulomatous inflammation seen in sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Systemic sclerosis: Also known as scleroderma, this condition involves fibrosis of the skin and internal organs. It can affect the lungs, leading to interstitial lung disease and pulmonary hypertension, but it is not associated with granulomas or asteroid bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of asteroid bodies in a lung biopsy, combined with symptoms like low-grade fever, cough, and breathlessness, strongly suggests a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Which is NOT a hyper-estrogenic condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low BMI

 

Explanation:

 

Hyper-estrogenic conditions are characterized by elevated levels of estrogen. Such conditions can arise due to various factors, including hormonal imbalances, medications, and specific medical conditions.


Low BMI: This is not typically associated with high estrogen levels. In fact, individuals with low BMI may have lower estrogen levels due to decreased adipose tissue, which is a source of estrogen production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tamoxifen use: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used primarily in the treatment of breast cancer. It can act as an estrogen agonist in certain tissues, potentially leading to increased estrogenic effects.

 

Option C. Nulliparous: Nulliparous women (those who have never given birth) may have higher lifetime exposure to estrogen due to the absence of pregnancy and lactation periods, which would otherwise lower estrogen exposure.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Certain types of ovarian cancer can lead to increased estrogen production, contributing to a hyper-estrogenic state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low BMI is not associated with hyper-estrogenic conditions.

 

High estrogen levels are more likely to be seen in conditions such as Tamoxifen use, nulliparity, and certain types of ovarian cancer.

 

High estrogen is a risk factors for fibroids, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma and endometriosis.

questions.text: A female patient with celiac disease is recommended a gluten-free diet. Which among the following can she consume?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rice

 

Explanation:

 

Celiac disease requires a strict gluten-free diet to avoid triggering symptoms. Gluten is found in certain grains, specifically:

 

Mnemonic - BROW

 

  • Barley
  • Rye
  • Oats (unless specifically labeled gluten-free due to potential cross-contamination)
  • Wheat

 

Rice is naturally gluten-free and safe for consumption by individuals with celiac disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wheat: Contains gluten and must be avoided.

 

Option B. Barley: Contains gluten and must be avoided.

 

Option C. Oats: Often contaminated with gluten unless specifically labeled gluten-free and should be avoided unless confirmed to be safe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with celiac disease should avoid wheat, barley, rye, and oats unless specifically labelled gluten-free, while rice is a safe option.

questions.text: In a RTA (road traffic accident), a person suffered from injury to the bulbar urethra. What can be the location of the collection of the urine due to this injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior abdominal wall

 

Explanation:

 

Injury to the bulbar urethra, such as from a road traffic accident, can lead to the collection of urine in the anterior abdominal wall. The bulbar urethra is part of the spongy urethra and is located in the perineal region. When this part of the urethra ruptures, urine extravasates into the surrounding tissues.

 

The typical path of urine extravasation due to a bulbar urethral injury includes:

 

  1. Perineum: Initially, urine accumulates around the scrotum and the perineum.
  2. Superficial perineal pouch: Urine then spreads into the superficial perineal pouch.
  3. Anterior abdominal wall: From the superficial perineal pouch, urine can extend into the anterior abdominal wall, following the fascial planes.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Deep perineal pouch: Rupture of the membranous urethra would lead to urine collection in the deep perineal pouch, not typically the case with bulbar urethral injury.

 

Option  B. Peritoneal cavity: Urine does not usually enter the peritoneal cavity from a bulbar urethral injury.

 

Option D.  Ischiorectal fossa: This area is more likely affected in cases involving deep perineal infections or abscesses rather than bulbar urethral injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of bulbar urethral injury, urine typically accumulates in the perineum and can extend into the anterior abdominal wall but not into the deep perineal pouch or the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: Patient came to the emergency department with 32 weeks of pregnancy with pedal edema and BP of 140/90 mmHg. Urine dipstick was 2+. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms that align with the diagnosis of preeclampsia, which is characterized by the following criteria:

 

  • Elevated blood pressure (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Proteinuria (≥1+ on dipstick or 300 mg/24 hours).

 

In this case, the patient has a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a urine dipstick showing 2+ proteinuria, which fits the criteria for preeclampsia. The presence of pedal edema further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abruption: This typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness. While preeclampsia can be a risk factor for abruption, the absence of vaginal bleeding in this case makes abruption less likely.

 

Option C. PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage): This occurs after delivery and is characterized by significant bleeding post-delivery, which is not relevant in this antepartum scenario.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: This is characterized by elevated blood pressure without proteinuria or other signs of preeclampsia. The presence of proteinuria in this patient rules out gestational hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is diagnosed in pregnant patients presenting with hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. This condition requires careful monitoring and management to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

choices.text: They are perceived in the objective space
They are not under the control of the patient

questions.text: All  are features of pseudohallucinations, except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They are perceived in the objective space

 

Explanation:

 

True Hallucinations are characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Perception happens without any real object or stimulus triggering it.
  2. They are as vivid and detailed, similar to real perceptions. For example, if a person is experiencing a visual hallucination, the image they see can appear very clear and detailed to them, almost indistinguishable from reality.
  3. Hallucination are perceived in the outer and objective space (external environment).
  4. They are not under the control of the patient. This means the patient cannot start or stop these perceptions at will; they occur spontaneously.

 

Importantly, Pseudohallucinations are perceived in the inner and subjective space, not the outer and objective space. These are perceived as coming from the inner from his/her mind.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They occur without stimulus: This is correct for pseudohallucinations as they happen without any external trigger.

 

Option C. They are vivid: This is also correct for pseudohallucinations. Despite not being real, the perceptions can be very detailed and clear.

 

Option D. They are not under the control of the patient: This is another correct feature of pseudohallucinations. Patients cannot control when these perceptions occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudohallucinations are vivid perceptions without stimulus, occurring in the inner and subjective space, and are not under the control of the patient.

questions.text: Primary effusion lymphoma is caused by which of the following viruses? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HHV 8

 

Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) is a rare type of lymphoma that is most commonly associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). HHV-8 is implicated in several malignancies, including Kaposi sarcoma, Castleman disease, and PEL. PEL typically presents as lymphomatous effusions in body cavities such as the pleural, pericardial, or peritoneal spaces without detectable tumor masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV 1: While HIV infection can predispose individuals to various lymphomas, including PEL, it is not the direct cause. HIV-1 is primarily associated with immunosuppression, which increases susceptibility to HHV-8 and other oncogenic viruses.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B virus): HBV is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma but not with primary effusion lymphoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr virus): EBV is associated with several types of lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma and Hodgkin lymphoma, but it is not the primary causative agent of PEL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HHV 8 causes Castleman disease, Kaposi sarcoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

questions.text: When is the quadruple marker test done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 16 – 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The quadruple marker test is a prenatal screening test performed during the second trimester of pregnancy, typically between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

This test is used to assess the risk of certain genetic disorders, including Down syndrome (trisomy 21), trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

 

The quadruple marker test measures four specific substances in the mother's blood:

 

  1. Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  2. Free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (free beta-HCG)
  3. Inhibin A
  4. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 

These markers provide information about the likelihood of certain fetal abnormalities.

 

Note - In the case of Down syndrome, free beta-HCG and inhibin A levels tend to be elevated, while unconjugated estriol and alpha-fetoprotein levels are typically decreased.

 

Educational objective:

 

The quadruple marker test is conducted between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation to screen for genetic disorders such as Down syndrome, trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

questions.text: A patient has microcytic hypochromic anemia and was observed to have delayed wound healing after a minor surgery. He gives history of gum bleeding also. He is most likely to have deficiency of:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

This patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia, delayed wound healing, and gum bleeding is most likely suffering from Vitamin C deficiency, which affects collagen synthesis and can lead to scurvy. This condition is characterized by poor wound healing, bleeding gums, and can be associated with anemia. Copper, cobalt, and selenium deficiencies present with different clinical features and types of anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper: Incorrect. While copper deficiency can cause anemia and neutropenia, it's less commonly associated with delayed wound healing and gum bleeding. Copper plays a role in iron metabolism and antioxidant defense, but the clinical picture described is more characteristic of Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option C. Cobalt: Incorrect. Cobalt is a component of vitamin B12 (cobalamin) and its deficiency leads to macrocytic, not microcytic, anemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms and is not typically associated with delayed wound healing or gum bleeding.

 

Option D. Selenium: Incorrect. Selenium deficiency can cause muscle weakness and cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) but is not typically associated with anemia, delayed wound healing, or gum bleeding. Selenium's primary role is as an antioxidant and in thyroid hormone metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is crucial for collagen synthesis, a vital component of skin and vascular tissues. Deficiency leads to scurvy, which manifests with symptoms like gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and anemia. The anemia is typically normocytic but can be microcytic due to associated blood loss and iron deficiency.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

choices.text: Consent of husband and two doctors
Consent of husband and one doctor
Consent of mother and two doctors

questions.text: For MTP to be done between 20-24 weeks, what is required?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consent of two doctors

 

Explanation:

 

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act stipulates different requirements based on the gestational age of the pregnancy. For an MTP to be performed between 20-24 weeks, the consent of two doctors is required. This ensures that the procedure is considered carefully and is justified based on the health conditions of the mother or fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a patient with head trauma whose CT brain scan reveals an epidural hematoma (EDH) with mass effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) An immediate craniotomy

 

When a patient with head trauma has an epidural hematoma (EDH) with mass effect, which means significant compression, the next step in management should be an immediate craniotomy (surgical evacuation of the hematoma).
