Other Options:

 

Option B. Observe: Observation is an option for small EDHs without mass effect, which is a rare scenario as EDHs typically result from arterial bleeding and cause significant compression.

 

Option C. IV fluids: IV fluids may be given for other purposes like hypovolemia due to bleeding but are not the appropriate management for this condition.

 

Option D. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt is performed for the condition of hydrocephalus not in the case of an EDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with head trauma and an epidural hematoma (EDH) causing mass effect (significant compression) on a CT brain scan, the next step in management is an immediate craniotomy (surgical evacuation of the hematoma) to decompress the brain.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver in image below. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pringle's maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a surgical procedure known as Pringle's maneuver, which involves inserting a finger from the greater sac to the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen (also known as the foramen of Winslow). The epiploic foramen is the communication between the greater and lesser sacs, and its boundaries are of great importance.

During hepatobiliary surgery, there is a risk of rupturing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) located along the free margin of the lesser omentum. To prevent leakage from these structures, the surgeon can either clamp them along the free margin or insert a finger behind the lesser omentum and place the thumb above it, compressing the VAD between the finger and thumb. This surgical procedure is known as Pringle's maneuver.

 

 

The maneuver involves inserting the finger in front of the stomach (greater sac) and passing it behind the stomach (lesser sac) through the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mattox maneuver: Incorrect. The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used to control bleeding from the inferior vena cava or hepatic veins during liver trauma. It involves a thoracoabdominal approach and manual compression of the bleeding site.

 

Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver: Incorrect. The Cattell-Braash maneuver is a surgical technique used to expose the retroperitoneal structures, such as the aorta, inferior vena cava, and kidneys, by mobilizing the colon and small bowel to the right side of the abdomen.

 

Option D. Liver hanging maneuver: Incorrect. The liver hanging maneuver is a technique used during liver resection to facilitate the transection of the liver parenchyma. It involves passing a tape or a catheter between the liver and the inferior vena cava to provide traction and guidance during the resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pringle's maneuver is a surgical procedure used to control bleeding during hepatobiliary surgery by compressing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) along the free margin of the lesser omentum through the epiploic foramen.

questions.text: Which of the following is the nature of amyloid in a patient undergoing hemodialysis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A Beta2

 

Patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis are at risk of developing dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA). The primary cause of this condition is the inability of the hemodialyzer to effectively filter out β2-microglobulin, a protein that is a normal component of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules. Over time, the accumulation of β2-microglobulin in the blood leads to its deposition as amyloid fibrils in various tissues, particularly in bones and joints, causing symptoms such as carpal tunnel syndrome, joint pain, and bone cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AL (Amyloid Light chain): This type of amyloid is derived from immunoglobulin light chains and is most commonly associated with primary amyloidosis, often seen in conditions like multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. AA (Amyloid A): This type of amyloid is derived from serum amyloid A protein and is typically associated with secondary or reactive amyloidosis, which occurs in chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis, inflammatory bowel disease, and certain cancers.

 

Option C. ACal (Calcitonin-related amyloid): This type of amyloid is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma and is derived from calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient of HIV with low CD4 count presents with the following finding. Which of the following is used in the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ganciclovir

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a case of retinitis, a common ocular manifestation in HIV patients with low CD4 counts.

 

Retinitis can be caused by various pathogens, but in the context of HIV with a low CD4 count, Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is a significant concern. This condition is typically seen when the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/mm³. CMV retinitis presents with retinal necrosis and can progress rapidly, leading to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice for CMV retinitis is Ganciclovir, which can be administered intravitreally to deliver the drug directly to the affected site in the eye. Ganciclovir inhibits viral replication by targeting viral DNA polymerase, making it effective against CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: This antiviral is used primarily for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) infections.

 

Option B. Valacyclovir: This is a prodrug of acyclovir and is also used for HSV and VZV infections.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: This antiviral is used in the treatment of HIV and Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for CMV retinitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, administered intravitreally to manage the infection effectively and prevent blindness.

 

Additional Information

Ocular manifestation of HIV –

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.text: Key feature of depression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low mood

 

The most important feature of depression is low mood, also known as sadness of mood.

 

Depression is primarily a mood disorder, and while other symptoms such as sleep disturbances, guilt feelings, negative thoughts, suicidal ideations, anhedonia (loss of interest in pleasurable activities), and loss of appetite may be present, the key defining characteristic remains the persistent low mood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal ideations are incorrect as they are not the key feature of depression. While suicidal thoughts may occur in severe cases of depression, they are not the primary defining symptom of the disorder.


Option C. Loss of interest in pleasurable activity, or anhedonia, is incorrect as it is not the most important feature of depression. Although anhedonia is a common symptom in depression, it is not the key defining characteristic of the disorder.

 

Option D. Loss of Appetite is incorrect as it is not the key feature of depression. Changes in appetite, including loss of appetite, can occur in depression but do not represent the core symptom of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low mood, or sadness of mood, is the key defining feature of depression, as depression is primarily a mood disorder.

questions.text: A child has presented with a birth defect as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Craniorachischisis with anencephaly


Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect that involves both the brain and spinal cord. It is a combination of anencephaly and spina bifida, where there is a failure of closure of the entire length of the neural tube, resulting in the absence of the brain (anencephaly) and an open spinal cord (rachischisis). The image provided shows the characteristic features of this condition, including the exposed brain and spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: Anencephaly is considered an anterior neuropore defect. During embryonic development, the neural tube forms, and this process involves the closure of two openings known as neuropores—one at the anterior (head) end and one at the posterior (tail) end. Anencephaly occurs when there is a failure of the closure of the anterior neuropore, leading to incomplete development of the brain and skull.

 

 

Option C. Spina bifida: Neural tube defect with the best prognosis is spina bifida.

 

Option D. Anencephaly with meningocele: Anencephaly with meningocele is a neural tube defect with the following image

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect involving both the brain and spinal cord, with the worst prognosis among neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta, in contrast, has the best prognosis among these conditions.

questions.text: What is the condition shown in the image below? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rupture of biceps tendon

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a patient with a prominent bulge in the upper arm area, which is a classic sign of a proximal biceps tendon rupture. In a normal situation, the biceps muscle appears smooth and uniform. However, when the proximal biceps tendon ruptures, the biceps muscle belly becomes more prominent, creating a characteristic bulge.

 

This bulging appearance of the biceps muscle is known as the "Popeye sign" due to its resemblance to the exaggerated muscular appearance of the famous cartoon character Popeye the Sailor Man. In the American cartoon, Popeye would gain superhuman strength in his arms after eating spinach, which was portrayed as a rich source of iron.

 

Tendon ruptures are relatively common, with the four most frequently affected tendons being:

 

  1. Quadriceps tendon (Q)
  2. Achilles tendon (A)
  3. Rotator cuff tendons, particularly the supraspinatus (R)
  4. Biceps tendon (B)

 

These four tendons can be remembered using the mnemonic "QARB".

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shaft of humerus fracture: Incorrect. A fracture of the humeral shaft would not cause the characteristic bulging appearance of the biceps muscle as seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rupture of triceps tendon: Incorrect. A triceps tendon rupture would cause weakness in elbow extension and a defect near the olecranon process, not a bulge in the biceps region.

 

Option D. Supracondylar fracture: Incorrect. A supracondylar fracture is a fracture of the distal humerus, above the elbow joint. It would not cause the biceps muscle to bulge in the manner shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Popeye sign" is a classic clinical sign of a proximal biceps tendon rupture, characterized by a prominent bulge in the biceps muscle belly.

questions.text: Given the image showing significant limb swelling, which body system is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphatics

 

The image shows significant swelling of the limb, particularly in the calf region, with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance. This presentation is indicative of lymphedema, which is a condition resulting from impairment of the lymphatic system. The swelling, shape, and involvement of the foot and toes (squaring of toes) are classic features of lymphedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artery: Arterial involvement would typically cause limb wasting rather than swelling, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Vein: Venous involvement would present as varicose veins, which are not seen in the image, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Muscle: Muscular involvement does not present in the characteristic way shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Significant limb swelling with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance in the calf region, along with swelling of the foot and squaring of the toes, is a classic presentation of lymphedema, suggesting involvement of the lymphatic system.

choices.text: Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained
Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss
Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery
Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant patient presented with complaints of worsening of hearing since the onset of pregnancy. On PTA the following graph was obtained. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is true? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, being pregnant and experiencing worsening hearing loss, suggests otosclerosis. The provided PTA (Pure Tone Audiogram) shows a significant air-bone gap on the right side, indicating conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Definitely, air travel is contraindicated for patients post-stapedectomy for at least three months. The variations in middle ear pressure during ascent and descent can lead to displacement or dislocation of the prosthetic piston used in the surgery, making this statement true.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained: In otosclerosis, an As type of tympanogram (indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system) is typically obtained, not Ad. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss: A notch at 2000Hz on bone conduction is known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis, not noise-induced hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss typically presents a notch at 4000Hz. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery: Ménière's disease is indeed a contraindication for stapes surgery. The presence of Ménière's disease can lead to complications such as irritation of the saccule during the surgery, causing vertigo and giddiness. Thus, this statement is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Air travel is contraindicated for at least three months post-stapedectomy due to the risk of pressure-induced displacement or dislocation of the surgical prosthesis.

questions.text: A person consumed 2 bottles of alcohol purchased from a local shop and presented to the emergency department with blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension. What should be given for the treatment? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethyl alcohol

 

Explanation:

 

Blurring of vision, along with other symptoms such as nausea, confusion, and hypotension, suggests methyl alcohol (methanol) poisoning. Methyl alcohol is toxic because its metabolism produces formic acid, which is particularly harmful to the eyes and can cause blindness.

 

Key points to understand about methyl alcohol poisoning and its treatment:

 

  1. Methyl Alcohol (Methanol) Poisoning:
    • Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects.
    • Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision.
  2. Treatment of Methanol Poisoning:
    • Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol.
    • Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.
    • Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis.
    • Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flumazenil: Incorrect because flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning.

 

Option C. Atropine: Incorrect as atropine is used for organophosphate and other cholinergic poisonings.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Incorrect because naloxone is the antidote for opioid poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension in the context of alcohol consumption from a local shop strongly suggest methanol poisoning. The appropriate treatment is ethyl alcohol, which competes with methanol for metabolism and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.

 

Table for Treatment of Methanol and Ethylene Glycol Poisoning

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. A CT scan was done, and the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antrochoanal polyp

 

The CT scan shows a mass originating from the maxillary sinus extending into the choana and nasopharynx, indicative of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps are benign lesions that arise from the maxillary sinus, extend through the sinus ostium, and grow into the nasopharynx. This causes nasal obstruction, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid hypertrophy: Adenoid hypertrophy occurs in the nasopharynx and is characterized by enlarged adenoids, leading to nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. It does not typically present with a mass extending from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option B. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs predominantly in adolescent males. It arises from the nasopharynx and extends into adjacent areas, not from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This malignant tumor arises from the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. It usually presents with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The mass in the CT scan originating from the maxillary sinus is not consistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

An antrochoanal polyp originates from the maxillary sinus and extends through the choana into the nasopharynx, causing nasal obstruction. The presence of a gap between the tumor and the posterior pharyngeal wall on imaging, known as the "dot sign," supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which is the most common intraocular malignancy in adults? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Choroidal metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common intraocular malignancy in adults is choroidal metastasis.

 

Metastatic tumors to the eye, particularly to the choroid, are more common than primary intraocular malignancies. These metastases usually originate from primary cancers in other parts of the body, such as the breast or lung. The choroid is a vascular layer of the eye that provides a conducive environment for metastatic cells to thrive.

 

The most common primary intraocular malignancy is choroidal melanoma. Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular cancer in adults, but overall, metastases are more prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, not adults.

 

Option B. Choroidal melanoma: While this is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults, it is less common than metastatic tumors overall.

 

Option C. Uveal melanoma: This term encompasses melanomas of the choroid, ciliary body, and iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most common intraocular malignancy in adults - Choroidal melanoma
  • Most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults -Capillary Hemangioma.
  • Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children – Retinoblastoma
  • Most common intraorbital malignancy in children – Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text: Triage is categorization of victims of Disaster. Correct match for the categories of Triage is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yellow – Stable, Need observation

 

Explanation:

 

Triage is the process of sorting and categorizing victims based on the likelihood of survival and the urgency of their need for medical treatment.

Triage categorizes victims to prioritize treatment based on the urgency and likelihood of survival, with yellow indicating stable patients who need observation but can wait for treatment.

Yellow is the Minimal Category

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red – Least priority: This is incorrect as red indicates the highest priority, requiring immediate intervention (Emergency category).

 

Option B. Black – Minor injuries, Immediate priority: This is incorrect as black represents deceased or moribund patients, not those with minor injuries.

 

Option D. Green – Life threatening: This is incorrect as green indicates minor injuries that are not life-threatening and can wait for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a disaster, victims are categorized into four primary colors:

 

  • Red: This category includes patients who require immediate resuscitation or life/limb-saving surgery within 0-6 hours to prevent death.
  • Yellow: These patients may require resuscitation or life/limb-saving surgery, but their treatment can be delayed up to 6-24 hours without immediate risk to life.
  • Green: These patients have minor, non-life-threatening injuries such as small fractures, abrasions, bruises, or lacerations. They are ambulatory and can wait for medical care.
  • Black: This category includes deceased or moribund patients who are beyond the possibility of resuscitation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with an acute ischemic stroke is undergoing thrombolysis with IV alteplase. He currently weighs 80 kg. What is the appropriate dose of alteplase to be given to this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8 mg

 

The appropriate dose of IV alteplase (recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, rtPA) for a patient with acute ischemic stroke is 0.9 mg/kg. The total dose for an 80 kg patient would be approximately 72 mg (0.9 mg/kg x 80 kg = 72 mg). According to the standard administration protocol:

 

  • 10% of the total dose is given as an initial bolus over 1 minute.
  • The remaining 90% is infused over 1 hour.

 

For this patient:

 

  • Total dose = 72 mg.
  • Bolus dose = 10% of 72 mg = 7.2 mg, rounded to 8 mg.
  • The remaining dose (64.8 mg ≈ 64 mg) is given as a continuous infusion over 1 hour.

 

Thus, the initial bolus dose of alteplase for this patient is 8 mg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient weighing 80 kg, the appropriate initial bolus dose of alteplase for acute ischemic stroke is 8 mg, followed by the remainder of the dose given as an infusion over 1 hour.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with a history of burn wound on the lower limb. His wound is given in the picture. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marjolin's Ulcer

 

The patient has a history of a burn wound on the lower limb. The image shows a chronic wound with changes typical of Marjolin's ulcer. Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds. This transformation is due to chronic irritation to the skin, which increases the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venous Ulcer: This is incorrect because venous ulcers typically occur in patients with chronic venous insufficiency and are usually located on the medial aspect of the ankle.

 

Option C. Arterial Ulcer: This is incorrect because arterial ulcers are associated with peripheral arterial disease and are usually found on the toes, feet, or lateral aspect of the ankle.

 

Option D. Infected burn wound: This is incorrect because an infected burn wound would not necessarily show the chronic changes typical of Marjolin's ulcer, which includes malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds, including long-standing burn wounds.

questions.text: A lady with history of smoking presents with nipple discharge. She is diagnosed with duct ectasia. What is the procedure to be done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hadfield procedure

 

In this case, the patient has a history of smoking and presents with nipple discharge, leading to a diagnosis of duct ectasia. Duct ectasia typically affects multiple ducts rather than a single duct. The appropriate procedure for duct ectasia, where multiple ducts are involved, is the Hadfield procedure. This involves excising the affected ducts using a conical incision.

 

If the discharge was coming from a single duct and was bloody, the diagnosis could be ductal papilloma. The treatment for ductal papilloma is microdochectomy, which involves excising the single affected duct with the tumor inside it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microdochectomy: This is incorrect in the context of duct ectasia, as it is used for excising a single duct with a tumor, such as in ductal papilloma.

 

Option C. Simple mastectomy: This is incorrect because it involves removing the entire breast, which is not necessary for ductal disorders like duct ectasia.

 

Option D. Wide local excision: This is incorrect as it is not typically used for treating ductal disorders like duct ectasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hadfield procedure is used to excise multiple affected ducts in patients with duct ectasia.

questions.text: Identify the air cell marked with red arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinus: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulla Ethmoidalis

 

The red arrow in the CT scan points to a large air cell within the ethmoid sinus, which is the Bulla Ethmoidalis. The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus. It is centrally located within the ethmoid labyrinth and serves as a key landmark in endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agger Nasi Cell: The Agger Nasi cell is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell, situated anteriorly and superiorly to the insertion of the middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Haller Cell: Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit. They are located inferiorly, near the orbit floor.

 

 

Option D. Onodi Cell: The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid bone and is situated near the optic nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus.

questions.text: Which nerve seems to be damaged in the given picture? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

RADIAL NERVE

 

  • It is usually injured in fractures of shaft humerus, injection palsy, Saturday night palsy and Crutch palsy.
  • There is sensory loss in area supplied posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost (i.e. wrist, thumb and finger drops).

 

Types of Radial Nerve Lesion

 

  1. Very high (i.e. above spiral groove): there is Total palsy, i.e. Elbow, wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost. There is loss of sensation over dorsum of 1st web space.
  2. High (i.e. between spiral groove and lateral epicondyle): Elbow extension is spared. Brachioradialis is involved. Wrist, thumb, finger extension and sensation over dorsum of 1st web space are lost.
  3. Low (i.e. the elbow): Elbow and wrist extension are spared. Thumb, finger extension and sensation over dorsum of 1st web space are lost.
  4. Posterior interosseous nerve palsy (no Sensory deficit): Elbow and wrist joint extension, and sensations are spared. There is loss of MCP joint extension, i.e. thumb and finger drop.

 

 

  • The loss of synergic action between wrist flexors and extensors causes excessive and unwanted wrist flexion. This can be observed in a simple gripping task or asking the individual to make a fist. Both tasks will be difficult to complete as movement will be ineffective.
  • The hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve. In ulnar nerve injury, there is weakness of ulnar deviation & wrist flexion, atrophy of hypothenar eminence, weakness of palmar interossei (positive card test), weakness of finger adduction (Wartenberg’s sign), paralysis of adductor pollicis (positive froment’s sign), weak abduction of middle finger due to weak dorsal interossei (positive igawa’s test). The characteristic deformity seen is Ulnar claw hand i.e., hyperextension of MCP joint & flexion of IP joint.

 

 

 

 

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. The axillary nerve is injured in the fracture of surgical neck of humerus, anterior & inferior shoulder dislocation, & intramuscular injections. This causes deltoid muscle palsy; loss of rounded shoulder contour, giving shoulder a flattened appearance & producing a hollow inferior to acromion. 15-90⁰ of shoulder abduction becomes weak, and there is teres minor palsy also.

 

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve supplies coracobrachialis, the biceps brachii and the brachialis, and is continued into the forearm as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm. In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm. It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial nerve injury is associated with wrist drop i.e., loss of wrist, thumb and fingers of the affected hand, as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: Fluid of choice for elective surgery is preferably: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crystalloid

 

Crystalloids are aqueous solutions of mineral salts or other water-soluble molecules. Common crystalloids include normal saline and lactated Ringer's solution. They are the preferred choice for fluid resuscitation in elective surgery due to their availability, cost-effectiveness, and safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood: Blood transfusions are generally reserved for cases of significant blood loss where the patient's blood volume or hemoglobin levels are critically low. It is not the fluid of choice for routine elective surgery as it carries risks of transfusion reactions, infections, and immunological effects.

 

Option B. Colloid: Colloids (like albumin, dextrans, gelatins) are high molecular weight solutions that can stay in the vascular compartment longer than crystalloids. They are used to manage hypovolemia due to their volume expansion effect. However, they are more expensive and have not shown superiority over crystalloids in numerous studies.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): FFP is used to correct coagulation abnormalities, not as a fluid of choice for hydration or volume expansion in elective surgery. It is indicated when there is a deficiency of coagulation factors, such as in disseminated intravascular coagulation or massive transfusion protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred fluid for elective surgery is crystalloid due to its efficacy in volume expansion, safety, and cost-effectiveness compared to blood, colloid, or FFP.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with cervical cancer and was started on cisplatin therapy. Which of the following is likely to be an adverse effect of cisplatin? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nephrotoxicity

 

Cisplatin commonly causes nephrotoxicity, which is one of its major adverse effects. It can lead to renal impairment, making careful monitoring of kidney function essential during treatment. Other important side effects of cisplatin include vomiting and ototoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peripheral neuropathy: While cisplatin can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is more commonly associated with nephrotoxicity.

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is primarily an adverse effect of drugs like busulfan and bleomycin.

 

Option D. Hepatotoxicity: Cisplatin is more renowned for its nephrotoxic effects rather than hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotoxicity is a major adverse effect of cisplatin, requiring careful monitoring and preventive measures during therapy to protect renal function.

choices.text: Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels
Most patients have a good prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not the correct statement about papillary thyroid cancer? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels

 

Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is the most common type of thyroid cancer and generally has a good prognosis. It is often associated with a history of radiation exposure, and it commonly affects individuals in their early third decade (20s-30s). However, elevated serum calcitonin levels are not a feature of PTC; this finding is specific to medullary thyroid cancer (MTC), which arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid and produces calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. History of radiation exposure: This is a known risk factor for the development of PTC.

 

Option B. Affects in early third decade: PTC commonly presents in young adults, particularly in the third decade of life.

 

Option D. Most patients have a good prognosis: PTC generally has an excellent prognosis, especially when diagnosed early and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid cancer is not associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels; this is a characteristic feature of medullary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: Treatment of benzodiazepine overdose? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flumazenil

 

Flumazenil is the drug of choice for treating benzodiazepine overdose. It acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, effectively reversing the effects of benzodiazepines. By administering flumazenil, the respiratory depression and sedation caused by benzodiazepine overdose can be counteracted, making it a crucial antidote in such situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fomepizole is incorrect as it is used in the treatment of methanol toxicity, not benzodiazepine overdose. Fomepizole acts as an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, preventing the metabolism of methanol to its toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Naltrexone is incorrect as it is primarily used for the treatment of alcohol relapse and opioid dependence, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist that helps reduce cravings and prevents the rewarding effects of alcohol and opioids.

 

Option D. Naloxone is incorrect as it is the drug of choice for opioid overdose, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioids, including respiratory depression and sedation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, acting as a competitive antagonist at the GABA-A receptor.

choices.text: Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

questions.text: A patient who had kidney stones removed presents with flank pain 4-5 years postoperatively and a foreign body is observed on imaging. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

 

The patient presents with flank pain years after having kidney stones removed, and imaging reveals a foreign body, likely a retained double J ureteric stent. Double J stents are often placed during procedures to manage kidney or ureteric stones to ensure urine drainage but should be removed once they are no longer needed.

 

The appropriate management in this case is to perform an endoscopy to remove the retained stent. Retaining a stent for too long can cause complications such as stone formation on the stent, obstruction, or infection, which explains the patient's current symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy and Cystoscopic removal: Not required in this situation

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is incorrect as it is used to assess the urethra, not the ureter or kidneys. It is used for diagnosing urethral strictures or ruptures.

 

Option D. Leave the foreign body inside: This is incorrect and not a viable option as the foreign body (stent) is causing symptoms and potential complications, and must be removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopy is the appropriate procedure for the removal of a retained ureteric stent, which can cause complications if left inside the body for too long.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents to the hospital with urinary hesitancy and retention of urine. An ultrasound reveals an enlarged prostate and a residual urine volume of 130 ml. Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of this patient? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are appropriate for the treatment of urinary symptoms associated with an enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia, BPH). These drugs work by shrinking the prostate, thereby relieving urinary symptoms like hesitancy and retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: These are primarily used for managing hypertension, not for BPH.

 

Option C. ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are used for treating hypertension and heart failure, not directly for urinary symptoms due to an enlarged prostate.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonist: These are used in conditions like heart failure and resistant hypertension, not typically for BPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are used to treat urinary symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by reducing the size of the prostate and relieving urinary hesitancy and retention.

questions.text: On retinal examination of a hypertensive patient, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema were seen. Which grade of hypertensive retinopathy will it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade 4

 

The presence of multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema on retinal examination in a hypertensive patient indicates Grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy. This grading is based on the Keith-Wagener-Barker classification system.

 

Keith-Wagener-Barker Classification:

 

  • Grade 1: Mild retinal arteriolar narrowing and sclerosis.
  • Grade 2: More severe arteriolar narrowing with focal irregularities and AV nicking (Salus sign).
  • Grade 3: Presence of retinal hemorrhages (such as flame-shaped hemorrhages) and exudates (cotton wool spots), often referred to as moderate to severe retinopathy.
  • Grade 4: Severe retinopathy with the presence of papilledema (optic disc edema). This is also known as malignant hypertensive retinopathy, is characterized by the presence of papilledema along with retinal hemorrhages and exudates, indicating severe hypertension that requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Papilledema is a hallmark of Grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy, indicating a severe and urgent condition that requires immediate medical attention to manage the underlying hypertension and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1: Characterized by mild arteriolar narrowing without hemorrhages, exudates, or disc edema.

 

Option B. Grade 2: Involves more pronounced arteriolar narrowing and AV nicking but lacks hemorrhages, exudates, and disc edema.

 

Option C. Grade 3: Involves hemorrhages and exudates but without the presence of disc edema (papilledema).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keith-Wagener-Barker Classification:

questions.text: An elderly male patient who is a known case of COPD, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus visits the OPD to review his medications. Which of the following criteria should be followed by the physician during the review?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beer's criteria

 

Explanation:

 

Beer's criteria is a guideline used by physicians to help improve the safety of prescribing medications for older adults. It is specifically designed to avoid potentially inappropriate medications that can cause adverse drug reactions and interactions in the elderly individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duke's criteria: Used for diagnosing infective endocarditis.

 

Option B. Light criteria: Used for diagnosing exudative pleural effusions.

 

Option D. Jones criteria: Used for diagnosing acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beer's criteria should be used by physicians to review and manage medications in elderly patients to minimize the risk of adverse effects and drug interactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2HRZE + 4 HRE

 

The correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children is typically 2 months of HRZE (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol) followed by 4 months of HRE (isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol). This regimen aligns with WHO guidelines for treating pediatric tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4HRZE + 2HR: This regimen is not a standard treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children.

 

Option C. 2HRZE + 4 HR + corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are not routinely used in the standard treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis in children.

 

Option D. 4 HRZE + 2 HRE: This regimen is not consistent with standard treatment guidelines for pediatric tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children involves 2 months of HRZE followed by 4 months of HRE, aligning with WHO guidelines for pediatric TB treatment.

questions.text: A child presents with curved lowered spine, shortened arms and legs, poor muscle tone and delayed milestones. His upper arms are affected more than the lower legs. Which of the following   is the inheritance of the disease? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AD

 

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that is characterized by dwarfism, with specific features including a curved lower spine (lordosis or kyphosis), shortened arms and legs (rhizomelic shortening), poor muscle tone, and delayed milestones. The upper arms (humerus) are more affected than the lower legs (femur). The condition is caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene and follows an autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance pattern. This means only one copy of the mutated gene, inherited from one parent, is sufficient to cause the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AR (Autosomal Recessive): This pattern requires both parents to pass on a copy of the mutated gene for the disorder to manifest. Achondroplasia does not follow this pattern.

 

Option B. XLD (X-linked Dominant): This inheritance pattern affects both males and females, but is not relevant to achondroplasia.

 

Option C. XLR (X-linked Recessive): This pattern primarily affects males and requires the mother to be a carrier. Achondroplasia does not follow this pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia has autosomal dominant inheritance, requiring only one copy of the mutated FGFR3 gene to cause the disorder.

questions.text: All of the following are exclusive features of irreversible injury except: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Densities in mitochondria

 

 Although mitochondrial densities are often seen in irreversible cell injury, they can also be present in reversible injury. This makes them not exclusive to irreversible injury.

 

Other Options:

 

In the context of cell injury, irreversible injury is characterized by certain distinctive features that signify the cell's inability to recover. These features include

 

Option A. Cell membrane damage: This is a hallmark of irreversible cell injury. Once the integrity of the cell membrane is lost, the cell cannot maintain homeostasis, leading to cell death.

 

Option B. Cell shrinkage: This is associated with irreversible injury where the cell undergoes apoptosis, leading to a reduction in cell volume.

 

Option C. Nuclear condensation: Also known as pyknosis, this is a key feature of irreversible injury. It involves the condensation and darkening of the nucleus, which eventually leads to karyorrhexis (fragmentation) and karyolysis (dissolution).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irreversible cell injury is characterized by features such as cell membrane damage, cell shrinkage, and nuclear condensation, while mitochondrial densities can be seen in both reversible and irreversible injuries.

questions.text: Thyroid hormones play a crucial role in metabolism, growth, and development. They exert their effects through specific receptor types in target cells. Through which type of receptor does thyroid hormone primarily act?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nuclear receptors

 

Thyroid hormones act via nuclear receptors. These receptors, when bound by thyroid hormones, regulate the transcription of specific genes, influencing various physiological processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic receptors: Incorrect. While some steroid hormones act via cytoplasmic receptors, thyroid hormones primarily function through receptors located in the nucleus.

 

Option B. Tyrosine kinase receptors: Incorrect. Tyrosine kinase receptors are typically associated with growth factors and cytokines, not thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormones do not activate tyrosine kinase pathways directly.

 

Option D. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR): Incorrect. GPCRs are a large family of cell surface receptors that respond to a variety of external signals, but thyroid hormones do not act through these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones primarily exert their effects through nuclear receptors, influencing gene transcription and various physiological processes.

questions.text: Which clinical test will be positive in a patient who comes with a neglected traumatic dislocation of the hip? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telescopy test

 

TELESCOPY TEST

 

  • Telescopy Test is a provocative test used to evaluate the stability of the hip joint.
  • It also indicates the congenital hip dislocation in pediatric patients.
  • Steps to perform the test:
    • The patient is positioned supine on the examination table, and the examiner stands on the side that is to be examined.
    • The hip and knee are flexed to 90° and the hip is kept in mild adduction.
    • The pelvis is supported with one hand by placing the thenar eminence over the ASIS and the fingers on the greater trochanter to feel the instability.
    • The knee/ distal thigh is held with the other hand, and a gentle push and pull force is applied along the long axis of the thigh.
       
  • If the hip is unstable, an up and down trochanteric excursion can be felt with the other hand, the test is said to be positive.
  • When the excursion is more than that compared to the other side, think of conditions like a femoral neck fracture nonunion, hip dislocation, old unreduced posterior hip dislocation, dislocated total hip replacement.
  • Causes of positive telescopy test:
    1. Girdlestone arthroplasty
    2. Old unreduced dislocation with lax structures
    3. Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip
    4. Pathological dislocation e.g. TB
    5. Charcot’s joint
    6. Perthes disease
    7. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)
    8. Squeal of septic arthritis
    9. Osteonecrosis with collapse
    10. TB hip: Mortar and pestle type, destroyed head, wandering acetabulum
    11. Non Union fracture neck femur
    12. Non Union fracture intertrochanteric

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thomas test. It is done to measure fixed flexion deformity of hip by neutralizing lumbar lordosis. Up to 30 degree flexion deformity of hip can be compensated by lumbar lordosis. It measures hip flexor length and distinguishes tightness between one joint and two joint muscles.

 

 

Option C. McMurray test. McMurray's test is used to determine the presence of a meniscal tear within the knee. If there is meniscal injury, the test will be positive. A positive McMurray test will have findings of pain, snapping, an audible clicking, and locking in the knee on performing the test. Any of these symptoms can indicate a compromised medial or lateral meniscus.

 

 

Option D. Lasegue test. The Straight Leg Raise (SLR) test is commonly used to identify disc pathology or nerve root irritation, as it mechanically stresses lumbosacral nerve roots. It also has specific importance in detecting disc herniation and neural compression. It is also classified as a neurodynamic evaluation test as it can detect excessive nerve root tension or compression. Inclusion of ankle dorsiflexion in the SLR is documented as Lasegue's test. A true positive SLR test should include:

 

  • Radicular leg pain (symptoms below the knee).
  • Pain on hip flexion at 30 and 60 or 70 degrees from horizontal.
  • Neurological pain reproduced in the leg and lower back between 30-70 degrees of hip flexion is suggestive of lumbar disc herniation at the L4-S1 nerve roots.
  • Pain at greater than 70 degrees of hip flexion might indicate tightness of the hamstrings, gluteus maximus, or hip capsule, or pathology of the hip or sacroiliac joints.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Telescopy test is positive in cases of old, neglected, and traumatic hip dislocations.

questions.text: Transport of glucose on contraluminal side of intestinal cell is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GLUT-2

 

GLUT-2 is involved in the transport of glucose on the basolateral (contraluminal) side of intestinal epithelial cells. After glucose is absorbed into these cells from the intestinal lumen via SGLT-1, it is then transported out into the bloodstream through GLUT-2. This transporter facilitates the exit of glucose from intestinal cells into the blood, playing a crucial role in postprandial glucose homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-1: SGLT-1 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1) is located on the apical (luminal) side of intestinal epithelial cells. It is responsible for the active transport of glucose into the cell from the intestinal lumen, alongside sodium ions. This is the initial step in intestinal glucose absorption but not involved in the basolateral transport.

 

Option C. GLUT-5: GLUT-5 is a fructose transporter, predominantly found on the apical side of intestinal cells. It is responsible for the uptake of fructose from the intestinal lumen, not glucose transport on the contraluminal side.

 

Option D. GLUT-1: GLUT-1 is widely expressed in many tissues and is responsible for the basal uptake of glucose. It is not specifically involved in the transport of glucose on the contraluminal side of intestinal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter, which is primarily found on the basolateral (contra luminal) side of intestinal cells and is involved in the transport of glucose out of the enterocytes into the bloodstream.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 187

questions.text: Patient with depression, which medicine is appropriate?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoxetine

 

Fluoxetine is an SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor) and is considered the first-line treatment for depression. SSRIs are preferred due to their efficacy and better side effect profile  compared to other classes of antidepressants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium: Lithium is primarily used in the treatment of bipolar disorder to manage both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication typically used for conditions like schizophrenia and delusional disorders.

 

Option D. Imipramine: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) and can be used to treat  depression. However, TCAs generally have more side effects and are less safe compared to SSRIs, making fluoxetine a more appropriate choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is the first-line treatment for depression due to its efficacy and favorable side effect profile.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be seen after one year of using lithium therapy ? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tardive dyskinesia

 

Tardive dyskinesia is least likely to be seen with lithium therapy. This condition is more typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic drugs, not lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tremors: Tremors are a common side effect of lithium, often observed in patients undergoing therapy.

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: Lithium use can lead to hypothyroidism, especially with long-term treatment.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Lithium can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by affecting kidney function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tardive dyskinesia is least likely to be seen with lithium therapy; it is more commonly associated with long-term use of antipsychotic drugs.

questions.text: Under the sustainable development goal given by United Nations target for reduction of MMR by the year 2030 is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70/lac LB

 

  • The United Nations has set 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be achieved by 2030.
  • Goal number 3, which is directly health-related, focuses on "Health and well-being for all." Under this goal – 
    • Target 3.1 specifically states that the Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) should be reduced below 70 maternal deaths per 1 lakh live births by 2030.
    • Target 3.2 – U5MR <25 per 1 lakh live births by 2030.
      -  NNMR <12 per 1000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal target 3.1 aims to reduce the global Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) to below 70 maternal deaths per 1 lakh (100,000) live births by the year 2030.

questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Explanation:

 

The lesion shown in the image exhibits characteristics commonly associated with melanoma, which include:

 

  • Color variability: The lesion displays various shades of color, indicating the uneven distribution of melanin, which is a hallmark of melanoma.
  • Asymmetry: If the lesion is divided into four quadrants, the halves do not match, suggesting asymmetry, another key feature of melanoma.
  • Irregular borders: The borders of the lesion are not smooth or regular but rather irregular and jagged.
  • Diameter: The lesion is likely greater than 6 millimeters in diameter.
  • Evolution: There are changes in the lesion's appearance over time, including alterations in color, shape, and surface.

 

These features correspond to the "ABCDE" criteria used to identify potential melanomas:

 

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variation
  • Diameter greater than 6 mm
  • Evolution over time

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a papulosquamous lesion rather than a pigmented one. It appears as a scaly, red, crusted nodule or plaque, often on sun-exposed areas.

 

Option C. Basal cell carcinoma: Usually manifests as a translucent nodule, surface telangiectasias and extensive local growth. Basal cell carcinoma lesions often have a rolled border and can ulcerate, forming what is known as a "rodent ulcer." They do not generally present with significant pigmentation or the described irregularities.

 

 

Option D. Seborrhoeic keratosis: Appears as a benign, well-demarcated, pigmented lesion with a "stuck-on" appearance. It typically has a uniform color and texture and lacks the irregular borders, asymmetry, and color variation seen in melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma should be suspected in lesions that show asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter greater than 6 mm, and evolution over time. The "ABCDE" criteria are essential in identifying potential melanomas.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic alcohol use was admitted with complaints of unsteady gait, difficulty in seeing, and appears confused. Which vitamin is he deficient in? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vit B1

 

The patient's symptoms of unsteady gait (ataxia), difficulty in seeing (ophthalmoplegia), and confusion (global confusion) are characteristic features of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine). The mnemonic "GOA" (Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia) is often used to remember the triad of symptoms associated with this condition.

 

Chronic alcohol use is a common cause of thiamine deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. The treatment involves administering high doses of parenteral thiamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vit B12: Deficiency of Vitamin B12 typically presents with symptoms such as anemia, glossitis, peripheral neuropathy, and in severe cases, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which does not match the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vit C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing, which are not observed in this patient.

 

Option D. Vit B3: Deficiency of Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with the triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. This does not align with the patient's symptoms of ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic GOA), is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) and commonly occurs in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

questions.text: The green line corresponds to which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L5

 

Explanation:

 

The green line shown in the image corresponds to the trans-tubercular plane, which passes through the L5 vertebral level. The abdominal planes are used as anatomical landmarks to describe the location of structures and features within the abdomen. The important horizontal planes include:

 

  1. Transpyloric plane: Passes through the lower border of L1 vertebra.
  2. Subcostal plane: Passes through the upper border of L3 vertebra.
  3. Transtubercular plane: Passes through the upper border of L5 vertebra, as seen in the image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L1: This corresponds to the transpyloric plane, which is higher up in the abdomen.

 

Option B. L3: This corresponds to the subcostal plane, located midway between the transpyloric and transtubercular planes.

 

Option D. T12: This vertebral level is not associated with the horizontal planes typically used in abdominal anatomy and is located in the thoracic region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transtubercular plane passes through the L5 vertebral level, and it is a key anatomical landmark in the lower abdomen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old brought to the emergency department with complaints of mild bloody rhinorrhea. On examination, he was awake and oriented. Drainage has soiled his shirt, and the appearance of which is given below. This is seen in case of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic CSF Rhinorrhea

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with mild bloody rhinorrhea, and the drainage has created a characteristic "halo sign" or "double ring sign" on his shirt. This sign indicates the presence of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) mixed with blood. The halo sign is seen when CSF forms a clear ring around a central bloody spot on absorbent material. This finding is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where trauma causes a breach in the meninges, allowing CSF to leak and mix with nasal secretions or blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea: Spontaneous CSF rhinorrhea typically involves clear CSF leakage without blood. The absence of blood would not produce the halo sign as described.

 

Option C. Meningocele: Meningocele involves herniation of the meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column but does not typically cause nasal CSF leakage mixed with blood. It usually presents as a mass or bulge.

 

Option D. Tumors: Tumors might cause nasal discharge, but the presence of a halo sign specifically points to a CSF leak, which is more characteristic of traumatic causes rather than tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The halo sign or double ring sign on absorbent material is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where CSF leaks and mixes with blood, creating a central red spot surrounded by a clear or yellowish ring.

questions.text: Under the Urban health care system of India, the following health centre is not included: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) District hospital

 

Explanation:

 

District hospitals, however, are not a part of the urban healthcare system's primary or secondary level facilities, hence they are not included.

 

Urban Health care system of India

 

  • There is a provision for creating urban health and wellness centres, which cater to a population of 15,000 to 20,000.
  • These centres are akin to primary health centres (PHCs) in rural areas. Additionally, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), previously known as Urban Health Centres, serve a population of 50,000.
  • Urban polyclinics are created for a population of 2.5 to 3 lakh.
  • At the secondary level, Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC) are established for a population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

District hospitals are not included in the urban healthcare system of India; instead, urban health facilities include Urban Health and Wellness Centres, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), Urban Polyclinics, and Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC).

questions.text: A dead body is brought for postmortem examination with stellate shaped gunshot wound and muzzle imprint. What can be the distance? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contact shot

 

The presence of a stellate (star-shaped) gunshot wound with a muzzle imprint is indicative of a contact shot.

 

key factor in determining the range of fire -

 

  • Singeing (due to burning of hair/ flame).
  • Blackening (smoke deposits – burnt gun powder).
  • Tattooing (embedding of unburnt gunpowder particles)
  • Muzzle imprint is the imprint of the firearm – only in the contact shot

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Close range: Incorrect because close range typically has blackening and tattooing around the wound but lacks the distinct stellate pattern and muzzle imprint seen in contact shots.

 

Option C. Intermediate Range: Incorrect as intermediate range wounds show only tattooing without singeing, blackening, or muzzle imprint.

 

Option D. Distant Range: Incorrect as distant range wounds do not have any of the features mentioned above (singeing, blackening, tattooing, stellate pattern, or muzzle imprint).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a stellate shaped wound with a muzzle imprint indicates a contact shot. This is a crucial finding in forensic examinations to determine the distance of the firearm at the time of discharge.

 

Key points to understand about gunshot wounds and range of fire:

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D-dimer measurement

 

Explanation:

 

In a bedridden patient presenting with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain, one of the primary differential diagnoses is pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient has already undergone CT pulmonary angiography, which is a gold standard for diagnosing PE.

 

However, for initial screening, D-dimer measurement is very useful:

 

  • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE.
  • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR Angiogram: This is an imaging modality that can be used for vascular imaging but is not typically used as a screening test for PE.

 

Option B. Echocardiography: This is useful for assessing heart function and diagnosing conditions like heart failure or valvular disease but is not a primary screening test for PE.

 

Option D. Coagulogram: This test assesses blood coagulation status but is not specifically used for screening for PE.

 

Educational Objectives

 

D-dimer measurement is an effective screening test for ruling out pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of VTE.

choices.text: Fracture of the base of the skull

questions.text: A man is working in an industry without wearing a helmet. A heavy hammer falls on his head due to slipping from the head of his colleague working on the top floor. The X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depressed Fracture

 

A depressed fracture occurs when a heavy object with a small striking surface impacts the skull, causing a localized depression. In this scenario, the heavy hammer is the object that creates such a fracture. The X-ray provided shows a depression in the skull, indicative of a depressed fracture.

 

Note –

 

Ping Pong #/Ponds #/ Intended # - (a type of depressed #) This is a smooth concave depression without a fracture line, resulting from in-buckling of skull, occurring only in the elastic skull of infants.

 

Gutter # - Long narrow depressed #; It is formed when part of the thickness of the bone is removed so as to form a gutter, e.g. oblique bullet wounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Linear Fracture/ primary #/ Fissured #: This type of fracture is a simple break in the bone, typically caused by a broad surface impact, such as falling on the ground. It is not usually caused by a hammer.

 

Option C. Fracture of the base of the skull: This type of fracture occurs in severe trauma situations, like road traffic accidents, esp. motorcyclists. Types are -

 

  • Ring # - fall from height; # around foramen magnum
  • Motorcyclist # / Hinge # - skull is divided into anterior and posterior half
  • Spider web #/ Mosaic #/ Comminuted # - Multiple # of skull

 

Option D. Sutural Fracture (Diastatic Fracture): This type occurs in children below three years of age when the sutures of the skull separate. It is not relevant to the described scenario of an adult in an industry.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A heavy object with a small striking surface, such as a hammer, typically causes a depressed fracture in the skull. ​

questions.text: In a patient presenting with recurrent chalazion, which cancer is suspected?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma is a malignancy of the sebaceous glands, which can present as recurrent chalazion.

 

Chalazion is an inflammation of the meibomian glands, which are modified sebaceous glands located in the eyelids.

 

While chalazion is typically a benign condition, its recurrence, particularly in elderly patients, can be indicative of underlying sebaceous cell carcinoma.

 

This carcinoma is notorious for masquerading as benign eyelid lesions, thus a history of recurrent chalazion warrants further investigation to rule out this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This is the second most common type of eyelid cancer, but it does not typically present as recurrent chalazion. It more often presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcerative lesion.

 

Option C. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common eyelid cancer but usually presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia rather than as recurrent chalazion.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma: This vascular tumor is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV/AIDS. It typically presents as red or purple macules, plaques, or nodules, not as recurrent chalazion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent chalazion should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, especially in elderly patients, as this malignancy can mimic benign eyelid lesions.

questions.text: Oil droplet cataract is seen in?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactosemia

 

Explanation:

 

Oil droplet cataract is characteristically seen in galactosemia. This type of cataract presents as a central oil droplet appearance in the lens, which is a distinctive finding in patients with this metabolic disorder. Galactosemia is a genetic condition that affects the body's ability to process the sugar galactose properly, leading to its accumulation in various tissues, including the lens of the eye, resulting in the oil droplet appearance.

 

 

In galactosemia, early detection and dietary management can help prevent or reduce the severity of cataracts and other complications. The mnemonic to remember this association is that "oil" and "gallons" both start with "gal," linking oil droplet cataract to galactosemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myotonic dystrophy: The cataract seen in myotonic dystrophy is typically a Christmas tree cataract, characterized by multi-colored, glittering, needle-shaped crystals within the lens.

 

 

Option C. Wilson's disease: This condition is associated with a sunflower cataract, where deposits of copper cause a characteristic sunburst pattern in the lens.

 

 

Option D. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetic patients are more likely to develop snowflake cataracts, which are characterized by flake-like opacities within the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil droplet cataract is a distinctive feature seen in patients with galactosemia, a genetic disorder that impairs the metabolism of galactose, leading to characteristic changes in the lens of the eye.

 

Note – Oil droplet reflex on retinoscopy seen in - Keratoconus

questions.text: A 6-day old child presents with bilious vomiting with double bubble sign on X-ray. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

 

A 6-day-old neonate presenting with bilious vomiting and a "double bubble" sign on X-ray is indicative of duodenal atresia. The "double bubble" sign refers to the presence of two distinct air bubbles on the X-ray: one in the stomach and one in the proximal duodenum, separated by an obstruction, which is characteristic of duodenal atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infantile pyloric stenosis: This is incorrect because infantile pyloric stenosis typically presents after four weeks of age, not in a neonate. Additionally, the vomiting in pyloric stenosis is non-bilious, and the X-ray would show a single bubble due to stomach distention.

 

Option C. Jejunal atresia: This is incorrect because jejunal atresia presents with a "triple bubble" sign on X-ray.

 

Option D. Ileal atresia: This is incorrect because ileal atresia usually presents with multiple dilated loops of the intestine on X-ray, not a double bubble sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duodenal atresia is diagnosed in neonates presenting with bilious vomiting and a double bubble sign on X-ray, indicating obstruction between the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs. To correct that, he tilts the head on one shoulder. Which nerve palsy is suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th CN palsy

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presenting with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs and tilting the head on one shoulder to correct the vision suggests a 4th cranial nerve (CN) palsy. The 4th cranial nerve, also known as the trochlear nerve, innervates the superior oblique muscle.

 

The primary actions of the superior oblique muscle include intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye.

 

When there is a palsy of the 4th cranial nerve, the affected eye may have difficulty performing these movements, leading to vertical diplopia. Patients often adopt a compensatory head tilt to align the eyes properly and alleviate the double vision. The head tilt is typically towards the shoulder opposite the affected eye, compensating for the muscle's inability to properly intort and depress the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd CN palsy: This palsy typically presents with ptosis (drooping eyelid) and an eye that is deviated down and out. Patients often lift their chin to see beneath the drooping lid, not to correct vertical diplopia.

 

Option C. 6th CN palsy: The 6th cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction of the eye. A palsy here would result in horizontal diplopia, not vertical diplopia, and the patient might turn their head to compensate, not tilt it.

 

Option D. 7th CN palsy: This nerve controls facial muscles, and its palsy leads to facial muscle weakness or paralysis, not issues related to eye movement or diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

4th cranial nerve palsy (trochlear nerve palsy) leads to vertical diplopia, which patients often compensate for by tilting their head to the opposite shoulder to align the eyes and improve vision.

 

Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3

 

Superior oblique by 4th CN; Lateral rectus by 6th CN and Rest all muscle by 3rd CN

questions.text: MTP after 24 weeks is done for? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal anomaly

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks is permitted only in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. The MTP Act amendment of 2021 allows for this provision to ensure that pregnancies with severe and life-threatening fetal conditions can be terminated to prevent undue suffering for both the fetus and the parents.

 

The process involves a medical board, which is established at the district level or within medical colleges. This board typically includes a radiologist, a gynecologist, a pediatrician, and any relevant subspecialists depending on the nature of the anomaly. The board evaluates whether the fetal anomaly is substantial enough to warrant termination of the pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Minor: Termination for minors is allowed up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Option C. Rape: Termination for pregnancies resulting from rape is allowed up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Option D. Contraceptive failure: Termination due to contraceptive failure is allowed up to 20 weeks and, in some cases, up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP beyond 24 weeks is allowed only for substantial fetal anomalies, as determined by a medical board, to ensure the safety and well-being of the mother and to address severe fetal conditions.

 

Indication for MTP -

questions.text: A female patient presented with the complaint of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh after normal vaginal delivery. Which nerve is injured in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral cutaneous nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, descending behind the inguinal ligament and running along the lateral part of the thigh, is the nerve likely injured in this clinical scenario.

The key clue is the patient's complaint of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh following normal vaginal delivery. Compression of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh can lead to a condition called meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain along the lateral aspect of the thigh. The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh originates from the L2 and L3 nerve roots of the lumbar plexus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: Although the femoral nerve also has the same root values (L2, L3, L4) as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, it is formed by the posterior divisions of these nerves. The femoral nerve primarily supplies the hip joint, not the skin over the anterolateral thigh.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is formed by the anterior divisions of the L2, L3, and L4 nerves. It mainly supplies the knee joint, and its referred pain is felt at the site of the femoral nerve. It is not responsible for the pain in the anterolateral thigh.

 

Option D. Gluteal nerve: The gluteal nerve is not related to the lumbar plexus or the anterolateral thigh region. It is not the nerve injured in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, originating from the L2 and L3 nerve roots, can be compressed, leading to meralgia paresthetica, which presents with burning pain, numbness & tingling over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.

 

Additional Information –
